column101: antes de la introducción del euro. En mi opinión esto refleja el alto grado de credibilidad alcanzado por nuestro marco operativo y nuestra habilidad para gestionar la liquidez en la zona del euro.  Asimismo
column102: la instrumentación de la política monetaria se ha mostrado muy flexible ante los cambios en las condiciones económicas y financieras. En efecto
column103: en los últimos años nos hemos enfrentado a algunos desafíos a los que nuestro marco operativo ha sido capaz de responder adecuadamente.  En 2001
column105: el marco operativo fue capaz de superar con éxito las presiones derivadas del ataque terrorista del 11 de septiembre. En ese caso
column106: las operaciones de ajuste fueron un instrumento importante para ayudar a contener la variabilidad de los tipos de interés a un día. A través de este tipo de operaciones proporcionamos liquidez de manera inmediata. Otra referencia ilustrativa es enero de 2002
column107: con la introducción física del euro. La incertidumbre generada por este proceso produjo una cierta volatilidad en las condiciones de liquidez junto con tensiones en los tipos de interés a corto plazo. En respuesta
column108: el BCE decidió seguir una política de liquidez abundante en todas sus operaciones semanales de enero de 2002 y se mantuvo en contacto con los mercados de manera permanente. Como resultado
column109: el impacto del canje al euro sobre la volatilidad de los tipos de interés fue relativamente reducido. A diferencia de los casos referidos
column111: otros ejemplos de adaptabilidad se pueden asociar a ciertas características específicas de nuestro marco operativo. Un primer reto fue integrar la variedad de los activos de garantía admitidos a las entidades de contrapartida. La gran diversidad de estructuras financieras y tradiciones en los distintos países del área del euro hacía esta cuestión especialmente compleja. Sin embargo
column112: la definición de dos listas de activos se mostró efectiva para responder a esa complejidad. Este sistema de dos listas será sustituido gradualmente a partir de la entrada en vigor el 1 de enero de la “lista única”

Una política monetaria orientada a la estabilidad de precios en el conjunto del área es la mejor contribución al ajuste correcto de los precios relativos y a la asignación eficiente de los recursos entre los diversos sectores y países de la zona del euro cuando se producen perturbaciones asimétricas. Dinámica de los precios de los activos    Un segundo reto surge como consecuencia de la posible aparición de burbujas en el precio de los activos. Episodios históricos han puesto de manifiesto que estas burbujas pueden evolucionar con rapidez y que su estallido puede tener un coste muy elevado para la economía[17]. Además

El debate entre los representantes del mundo académico sugiere que es posible reaccionar ante las burbujas de precios de activos de varias formas[18]. Incluso en los casos poco frecuentes en los que el banco central puede afirmar que se enfrenta a una variación inusual y

column181: la influencia que esta evolución pueda tener en las decisiones de política monetaria.        7. Conclusiones    Permítanme concluir mi intervención. No albergo ninguna duda respecto a que la estrategia basada en una definición cuantitativa de estabilidad de precios y en el análisis económico y monetario constituye el marco adecuado para la política monetaria de la zona del euro. Esta estrategia ha sido esencial a la hora de garantizar el elevado nivel de credibilidad del Banco Central Europeo y de su política monetaria. Una política monetaria que ha permitido estabilizar la inflación en la zona del euro y anclar firmemente las expectativas de inflación en un nivel compatible con la estabilidad de precios
column182: incluso en circunstancias difíciles. Un logro que no debe menospreciarse dada la ausencia de historial de credibilidad con la que contaba el Banco Central Europeo.  Decía el Fénix de los Ingenios que “no hay cosa más fácil que dar consejo ni más difícil que saberlo tomar”. Si la máxima de Lope se aplica a todo tiempo y lugar
column183: con tanto más motivo debe prevenirnos frente a la complacencia. Somos una institución joven y todas las experiencias y críticas nos enseñan a seguir mejorando en el ejercicio de nuestro mandato. column4: Speech by Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa Member of the Executive Board of the European Central Bank delivered at the Bank of Korea's Conference on Payment Systems Seoul
column6: but it is an aspect that is often overlooked. Like any prudent bank
column7: a central bank is concerned about its own soundness as a bank. Like any commercial bank
column8: central banks adopt standards as a well-founded basis for their own operations and for deciding to whom to provide settlement facilities and credit. Access to these central bank facilities is essential to the main participants in the payment system: commercial banks. So
column9: by setting standards for their own clients
column10: central banks implicitly set standards for the banking sector. The central bank’s concern about its own stability becomes equivalent to a concern for the stability of the financial system as a whole. Regulatory tools
column12: are provided on the basis that a central bank is a public authority
column13: not on the basis that it is a bank. Applying “orders and sanctions” to contain risk in payment systems is not however a straightforward task. Perhaps with one exception (i.e. to cover the position of the participant with the largest net debit position)
column15: such as the Core Principles for Systemically Important Payment Systems and the Securities Settlement Systems Recommendations
column16: are based more on judgement than on strict quantifiable ratios to be met. Moreover
column17: a regulator with no banking functions would not be able to count on the level of insight into the payment system that acting as a settlement institution provides. For these reasons
column18: it would be very hard to argue that regulatory power over the payment system could be given to any public authority other than the central bank. As for moral suasion
column19: the ability of central banks to exert this kind of pressure will largely depend on the prestige and reputation they develop. It also depends on their ability to make use of hard power when the outcome is not regarded as appropriate. The capacity to convince others is clearly a fundamental asset for central banks to perform an oversight function. An example of moral suasion is CLS: the market response to G10 central banks’ strategy to contain foreign-exchange settlement risk.  The comparison between banking tools
column20: moral suasion and regulatory tools can be further developed. While the use of banking tools is inherent in the nature of central banks
column21: not all central banks have formal regulatory powers over payment systems. Banking tools and moral suasion are susceptible to being used to influence a cross-border system or cross-border participants in one’s own system
column22: while a regulation can only be enforced vis-à-vis systems and participants which have a territorial link with the jurisdiction of the regulator. Last but not least
column23: the influence exerted by central banks through banking tools is largely dependent on the importance of the central bank’s currency and its markets. My key message on oversight is that regulatory powers which are being assigned to many central banks need to be understood as a possible complement to the source of influence on the payment system that all central banks already have today as providers of the final settlement asset for their currency. The danger is that these regulatory powers may be regarded by central bankers as a substitute for the influence they exert over the payment system as bank of banks. Putting the emphasis on regulatory aspects alone would ultimately result in the central bank putting in the shadow its banking function and seeing themselves solely as a regulator of the payment system. With less insight into the payment system
column24: the risk of issuing a counterproductive regulation could increase. Ultimately
column25: oversight responsibilities might just as well be given to a separate regulatory agency
column26: and central banks would not have valid arguments to oppose this.  The fact is that central banks such as the Federal Reserve have not argued in favour of their need for an explicit reference to an oversight function and yet remain clearly influential in shaping the payment system. In the case of the ECB
column27: although we have an explicit reference in our Statute to oversight and to the ability to regulate the payment system
column28: we consider this regulatory power as a measure of last resort and we have not made use of it so far. My conclusion is that when conducting oversight
column29: central banks may be better positioned by standing on three “legs”: banking tools
column30: moral suasion and regulatory tools
column31: rather than depending on just one. And depending on the specific central bank and the specific system
column32: one leg will often be more influential than another.      Conclusion    The unifying theme of my lecture today has been the role central banks play in shaping the payment system. Together with commercial banks
column33: the central bank has a strong say in fostering the safety and efficiency of the payment system. We have reviewed the policies undertaken by central banks across a broad spectrum: from catalyst of cooperative arrangements in retail payments
column34: to reducing systemic risk in large-value payments. We have also reviewed why and how central banks shape the payment system. In a nutshell
column35: central banks are ultimately responsible for payment systems
column36: because the means-of-exchange function of the currency is largely conducted through these systems. They are able to shape the payment system because they are a bank whose liabilities
column38: represent a superior form of trust.

[3] See Papademos (2003) for a more extensive review and assessment of the contribution of monetary policy to economic growth.    [4] Fischer and Modigliani (1978) and Fischer (1994) present comprehensive accounts and analyses of the real effects and social welfare costs of inflation.    [5] Barro (1997) and Fischer (1994) discuss the empirical evidence on the long-term relationship between inflation and growth.    [6] Andrés and Hernando (1999) have shown that there is evidence of a robust negative relationship between inflation and long-term output growth in countries with low inflation. column12: DK)  I would like to follow up on the question relating to the convention. Over the weekend
column13: the French newspaper "Le Monde" referred to the Commission proposal for the convention on the future of Europe. What I read in "Le Monde" was that the Commission would be proposing changes to the decision-making process on the economic and monetary co-operation. In the light of the question whether Germany should have been given an early warning for not complying with the budgetary objectives
column14: it was very interesting to see one of the Commission proposals because the Commission is supposed to be proposing that they should have sole competence in the future. That is without actually involving the Ministers of Finance and Economies of the countries. They would be able to set out the general economic guidelines so they could decide whether early warnings should be issued to Member States that do not actually comply with the economic objectives that have been set. This
column16: is something that has not been made public by the Commission yet but
column18: how would you look at such as proposal if it came out and if the intention was to strengthen the role of the Commission in economic and monetary co-operation.   Mr Duisenberg  I look upon the proposals with sympathy
column19: provided they do not encompass also exhaustive co-ordination of monetary policy. That would place the monetary authority

Even if monetary policy does only have effects in the medium term I think we should not underestimate its psychological effects. This is something that the International Monetary Fund's economic outlook in fact raises and I would like to know why you have rejected this criticism of the ECB. As a matter of fact we have seen that in the European Union structural reforms alone have not succeeded neither in helping to combat unemployment nor in contributing to greater growth. column124: spoke on behalf of the constituency
column125: we always had to consult our membership before taking a position on whatever issue
column126: be it in the Board of Governors or in the Executive Board. A system where one member of the Governing Council would have to vote in accordance maybe with a majority of his constituency's opinion
column127: to my mind cannot work. The individual members
column128: in voting
column129: would lose their personal independence as they have now.  That would not be the case if we can design some sort of rotation system
column130: which would be similar to the rotation system that is applied in the United States in the Federal Reserve System. The Federal Open Market Committee has as voting members
column131: every six weeks when it meets
column132: the seven members of the Federal Reserve Board of Governors
column133: the President of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York
column134: who has a permanent vote
column135: and rotating voting rights for three out of the other eleven Presidents of Federal Reserve Banks. I still have hope
column136: and I do believe
column137: that we will be able to come up with a solution in this respect regarding the voting modalities of the Governing Council after accession
column138: which will carry the support of all members of the Governing Council. If not
column139: then we have to bring the issue back to either the European Commission or even the Ministers of Finance.   Mr Langen (EPP/ED
column140: D)  Unlike our chairman and vice-chairman Herzog
column141: I agree with you on your analysis of competition in the EU. There is a basic misunderstanding here. Interest rates are about as low as they have been for a long time. That is not why private investment has not been boosted enough. It is because of the competition conditions. Salaries were too high
column142: social security was too high. That's what needs to be tackled. That's what the Member States of the European Union have to deal with. Nobody will be able to hide that. If you say investment would be higher if interest rates were lower it is an erroneous conclusion. It is not true even after state investment. In big economies
column143: a state makes up over a third of GDP. The social sector is so powerful that state consumption is to the detriment of state investment in infrastructure. That's what needs to be tackled in my opinion. These are the reforms that the Member States have to tackle. You cannot blame the European Central Bank's monetary policy for everything. I just want to say that the whole discussion is being led by the left of the house and is leading us to the wrong conclusion. Drop the interest rates and a magical solution will appear. Now you have got to tackle inflation and reform. That is the only way to go.  I have a question
column144: Mr President. What are you going to do about the dialogue with the three states in the European Union which are not members of the euro zone
column145: i.e. UK
column146: Denmark and Sweden? What about the candidate countries? Are you in constant contact with their central banks and what is your assessment of this process?   Mr Duisenberg:  We have in a formal sense permanent contact. Namely
column147: all the central banks
column148: including those coming from the so-called out countries
column149: are members of the General Council. In between we have
column151: intensive contacts with the out central banks
column152: be it on a bilateral or a multilateral basis. Although the members of the General Council are immediately informed about all the decisions of the Governing Council
column153: there still is a feeling of being
column154: perhaps not ignored
column155: but of being not fully aware of what is going on inside the euro system. It is for that reason also that we have intensive bilateral contacts with these central banks
column157: with their staff and which are
column159: much more intense than they have ever been before the euro was introduced.   Mr Tannock (EPP/ED
column160: UK)  There are claims that the euro
column161: because of its depths and size as a zone
column162: saved the French economy and its currency stability during the asymmetric shock of the recent crisis which developed during the Presidential election
column163: when one candidate
column164: Mr Le Pen
column165: fought on a platform of withdrawal from the European Union and the single currency. Is there are truth in this allegation i.e. does the central bank have any figures from the Bank of France about capital flight from French banks during this delicate period
column166: or is this whole story just another example of pro-euro or single currency spin.  A second question - enlargement is now getting very close - 2004 is the possible date - and this is an asymmetric shock as well. How long
column168: does the central bank expect new Member States to retain their national currencies after accession? Also
column169: does the central bank accept that a much larger European Union of 27 Member States will bring added risks of asymmetric shocks developing in the enlarged euro zone and
column171: will the current 1% GDP EU budget be large enough to mount a rescue package to bail out countries in trouble
column172: who cannot devalue their currency or lower their interest rates after joining the single currency?   Mr Duisenberg  First of all
column173: on France I have no figures
column174: but also no indications that there was a change in the intensity of capital inflows or outflows. For France
column175: the same is true as what is true for the entire euro area
column176: that the tremendous outflow of capital that took place in 2000 and 2001 has dramatically decreased and in some cases it has even turned into an inflow of capital
column177: e.g. foreign direct investment.  How long do I expect accession countries to maintain their national currencies? I have no idea because it may
column178: and it should
column179: differ from one country to another. That would very much depend on the circumstances as they develop in these countries
column180: which to a large extent are also so-called catching-up countries. They have to catch up - according to the Copenhagen criteria - to an economic performance which is more or less comparable to that of the euro area. What impact could an asymmetric shock affecting the accession countries have? I believe that this should always be very limited. We talk about ten accession countries being ready to join the European Union before the elections to this Parliament in June 2004. If there are ten
column181: then these ten - and we know who they are - represent about 5% of the GDP of the current euro area. I do not say it is negligible but it is very small indeed. Will there be a bail-out for accession countries? I believe not. In the Treaty it was explicitly foreseen that currency problems would not be a source for bailing out a country in trouble.   Mr Andria (EPP/ED
column182: I)  I want to talk about the monitoring of the credit system. The Member States all have different systems
column183: but I think that through a monitoring of the credit system
column184: we can also have an economic policy. Let me explain to you that in Italy there has been a kind of crusade to eliminate the smallest parts of the credit system. What we see as a result is that this is helping the large banks and the large credit institutions and
column185: in fact
column186: impoverishes the country because the small elements in the system - those who talk to small traders
column187: small and medium-sized enterprises and so on
column188: have no longer someone to talk with. Maybe the European Central Bank could co-ordinate the monitoring in some ways so that you actually have the monitoring of Member States. Let me be more precise. There could be a form of protection from the ECB with respect to the system of credit provision in Member States and the monitoring thereof.  There is something I think is obsessive here - that is the question of flexibility. When we often unjustifiably talk about flexibility
column189: we have in fact social difficulties as we have never seen before
column190: - and I am asking the same as Mr Herzog
column191: but we are looking at it from different angles. We look at productivity because there are profit-sharing ideas where
column193: the employees get stock options and also profit-related pay
column194: as in the UK
column195: where you link salaries to productivity and all this could lead to extraordinary results.   Mr Duisenberg  I am afraid I have to disappoint you because the Treaty explicitly and deliberately excludes the banking supervision and competition policy from the mandate of the central bank. That continues to fall
column196: in line with the subsidiarity principle
column197: to the national authorities. The only thing that the European Central Bank can do
column198: is to contribute to the smooth conduct of policies related to banking supervision and financial stability. It is doing this by fostering the co-operation and exchange of information as much as possible between the various national supervisors and enhancing the co-operation in that area. On competition - I am afraid you have to turn to your compatriot
column200: rather than to me.   Mrs Peijs (EPP/ED
column201: NL  We have tried to shape the stock exchanges and the markets as much as possible. It is not always been the case in the U.S. The New York Stock Exchange does not want European trade to be able to see American trade on screen in real time. Can you not negotiate with the Fed in U.S. to change some of this?   Mr Duisenberg  What you refer to is not in the mandate of the Federal Reserve System
column202: but in the mandate of the Securities and Exchange Commission. It should be a point of discussion in the new committee that has been set up by the securities regulators
column203: which is now being chaired by our compatriot
column204: Mr Docters Van Leeuwen. I think that is the forum to which you should talk about this.   The Chair
column206: D)  Thank you
column207: Mr Duisenberg.

column6: satisfactorily at its trend rate of growth and inflation is under control
column7: then M3 in the long run will grow by a percentage which is roughly equal to that of the reference value i.e. 4.5%
column8: and if we were to forecast a different rate of growth then we would in fact be saying that we have to change our monetary policy at that time. So
column9: we will not forecast it but we will analyse actual developments in the light of the economic circumstances and let me repeat at this time
column10: when the population is living under circumstances of high uncertainty
column11: it is quite normal for investors to keep their assets
column12: if they have them
column13: liquid for a longer period than otherwise would be the case
column14: that they are hesitant to put their money into long term investments
column15: be it portfolio or direct investment
column16: and that they prefer to keep their powder dry in the form of short-term deposits or even currency in circulation for a time
column17: which then leads to higher M3 figures. But to the extent that the uncertainty is fading away and that growth will be resuming and that confidence in the future will be increasing
column18: to that extent the growth figures for M3
column20: will come down again.   Mr Schmidt (ELDR/SV)   Thank you Madame Chairman. Mr Duisenberg
column21: a complete monetary policy for the Union is going to require another three members and you and I agree on that. After the successful introduction of the euro
column22: there is a debate going on in my country
column24: about when a referendum could be held to join the euro. As you know
column25: public opinion is changing and very fast
column26: and there is now a majority in favour of Yes. The prime minister plans a referendum for February or April of 2003
column27: with entry to the euro zone in February 2004 agreements at the summit in 2004 and then change of the currency in 2006. Now my question
column29: is this: according to the present rules
column30: you have to be part of the monetary system for two years
column31: for Finland and Italy that was cut shorter
column32: what do you think the possibilities are for us to spend less time within the system too?   Mr Duisenberg   It is not up to the European Central Bank to take a decision or to even speculate on such a decision. It's in the hands of governments and in particular the Heads of State and Government to judge
column33: when the moment comes to make a judgement
column34: whether the convergence that will have taken place in the individual countries concerned can be regarded as adequate. What the ECB will do - when a country applies for membership of monetary union
column35: is to make a convergence report and the ECB will
column36: in its convergence report
column37: apply all the criteria that are mentioned in the Maastricht Treaty. It will make a fact-finding tour and conclusion. What the ECB will not do is make the final judgement.   Mr Schmidt (ELDR/SV)   But
column39: can you today have a personal view on this issue?   Mr Duisenberg   Oh yes
column41: but I won't give it here. (Laughter)   Mr Schmidt (ELDR/SV)   Could you give it to me afterwards? (More laughter)   Mr Mayol i Raynal (Greens/EFA/ES)   Thank you Madame Chairman. Mr President
column42: my question is inspired by an economist at the CNRS. On the 21st of this month in "Libération"
column43: he wrote that what is at stake with the euro is the ability of your bank
column45: to conduct a monetary policy that is acceptable to all countries in euroland
column46: and he stresses that this may well be a difficult task
column47: because despite cohesion policy there are difference which remain very large
column48: and he takes the example of the unemployment rate. I had a look at the figures and for last year that rate was 2% of the active population in Luxembourg
column50: but 12.8% in Spain. Now
column51: these differences are liable to lead to different monetary requirements and he says this is a policy matter
column52: it can't be just technical. Now the Central Bank
column54: is supposed to be strictly technical. So his conclusion is - should we not go back to the original premises and say that the central bank should remain under the control of politics and of the euro group - I think so too
column55: which is why I pass this question on to you. I think that monetary policy should be political. Look at what is happening in Argentina. It isn't just the consequence of a monetary policy
column56: I think the dollarization policy contributed to it.   Mr Duisenberg   If you have a single currency in a large area
column57: you need to have single monetary policy
column58: and a single monetary authority guarding over that single currency. That there will be differences in economic development in various parts of this monetary region
column63: and is normal. There are differences and there have always been differences in individual countries as well
column64: and there still are within the countries. There are huge differences in economic developments
column65: including employment and unemployment developments in the United States
column66: in Germany
column67: in Italy and I assume also in Spain. One region will develop faster than others. Still
column68: in all these areas I mentioned
column69: there is one monetary policy. But I would like to add one remark
column70: that is your question and the article you mentioned - ascribes a great influence to monetary policy on real economic developments. And
column72: monetary policy in the short run can have an impact on the development of growth and with that the development of employment
column74: the only impact that monetary policy has is on nominal values
column75: on inflation. In the long run
column76: monetary policy is as far as growth and employment is concerned
column77: to be considered as neutral. So
column78: I also would like to urge you: don't ascribe to monetary policy or give monetary policy tasks which it simply cannot fulfil seen over the longer term and it is the longer term that we have in mind when taking monetary policy measures.   Mrs Villiers (PPE-ED/UK)   I have two very short questions for you. If Germany does breach the 3% limit
column79: will that alter your policy in any way
column80: how would you react to that? That is my first question. And secondly
column81: the press reported when you were first appointed that you didn't expect to serve your full term and anticipated that you would certainly serve out your term to see the physical launch of notes and coins. Now we've seen the physical launch of notes and coins
column82: I'm sure the committee would be interested whether you plan to continue to the end of your term or whether you intend to retire early and if so
column83: when you might plan to do that?   Mr Duisenberg   To the last question I can be very brief. I can only repeat what I said when I was appointed and what I said here. I said that I was happy with the appointment and I warned the appointers that in view of my age
column84: I regarded it as unlikely that I would serve the full term. But
column85: the decision on when is mine and mine alone - and I haven't made up my mind yet. The 3% limit is
column86: for the European Central Bank and for the Governing Council
column87: not a relevant factor in determining its monetary policy stance. The 3% deficit limit is part of the Stability and Growth Pact
column88: and in that pact the ECB is not even mentioned.   Mr Katiforis (PSE/EL)   Mr President
column90: am so satisfied with your management of the European Central Bank and the introduction of the common currency that I wish you eternal youth. Now
column91: my substantive question is in a different sphere. Until recently there was
column93: a unity of dogma on the two sides of the Atlantic about fiscal policy. The United States insisted on fiscal orthodoxy
column94: on the limitation and the abolition of fiscal debts. And Europe did the same and you continue insisting on that. But in the United States now
column95: it's deficit financing 'til the eye can see. Does this change influence you at all? Or influence the central bank at all in modifying its opposition to an expansionary fiscal policy
column96: especially in times of recession or slowdown. You have spoken optimistically about the end but in fact we don't know whether it is ending and whether there will be a recovery this year or next or whether that recovery will be worthwhile
column97: will be strong enough to revive economic activity.   Mr Duisenberg   Our monetary policy strategy is complicated
column98: but very clear and we explain it day after day. In the two-pillar strategy
column100: we certainly come to a judgement about fiscal developments as we see them – it is one of the indicators we look at in determining our policy stance. And
column101: the current economic developments do not change in any way our long-term oriented reasoning nor our long-term oriented stance. Only as a side remark - I would like to remark that for this year for example the fiscal deficit of the euro area aggregated
column102: is expected to be1.4% of GDP. This is a Commission estimate. And the estimate the IMF made for the United States is a deficit of 0.5% of GDP. So there is still some way to go.   Mr Katiforis (PSE/EL)   But this is a rather static way of looking at things and in the United States it is clear that we have shifted very rapidly from a forecast and a policy indeed supporting fiscal surpluses to a changeover which is dramatic. So in dynamic terms
column103: and I thank you for those figures
column105: the United States has turned around very quickly whereas it seems to me that in a period of economic slowdown
column106: not recession because you won't accept the term
column107: some greater flexibility is of importance - not in order to frame a monetary policy but in the general climate you create by your advice to governments.   Mr Duisenberg   The general climate I create is to tell governments 1) we are not yet in a recession and we will not be in a recession as the United States is
column108: and 2) what we suffer most from is the lack of confidence of consumers and investors in their own future. And we have to do everything in our power to restore the confidence of the consumers and investors all around Europe. Our reasoning is that if the European Central Bank sticks to its forward-looking
column110: and if governments do the same
column111: if they convince the public that their medium-term oriented policy will not be disturbed by short-term developments
column112: then we think that both the European Central Bank and the governments will make a big contribution to the restoration of confidence amongst the people. In the same breath we say
column114: to the extent that you are adhering to the Stability and Growth Pact
column115: that is you have already sanitized your public finances so that there are surpluses or at least balanced budgets
column116: you can also let the automatic stabilisers in the fiscal sphere do their work fully. To the extent that you
column118: have not used the previous period
column119: when we had a boom in the economy
column120: to an adequate extent so that you are safely below the 3%
column121: you can also let the automatic stabilisers function but there are limits there. You can not let them function fully in all likelihood.   Mr Tannock (PPE-ED/UK)   Madame Chairman thank you. Mr President
column122: first of all I too would like to congratulate the sheer professionalism in handling the logistics of the launching of the euro notes and coins by the ECB
column123: Commission and national central banks. Frankly
column124: coming from a country which is out and a party which is opposed to joining
column125: I was expecting more glitches and popular resentment at the imposition of an unfamiliar currency. Nevertheless
column126: as an MEP I found it quite useful to be able to travel between Brussels and Strasbourg using the euro. (Laughter and applause) I'm still unconvinced
column128: that the 500 euro note will do anything other than serve the interests of tax evaders
column129: money launderers and other criminals
column130: and I found the one and two cent pieces an irritant in my pocket and I do hope they are phased out as soon as possible. But my question
column131: Mr President - In the event of an asymmetric shock to one country in euroland
column132: which may require a large bailout
column133: for which presumably the risk will become even greater after enlargement
column134: do you think that the existing EU budget
column136: will be large enough to fund this through transfer payments
column137: or will it require a much larger EU budget and therefore direct EU levy taxes? After all
column138: the USA federal budget is of the order of 20% of their GDP
column139: and there of course labour mobility is much larger.   Mr Duisenberg   One brief remark on the 500 euro note. I do want to recall (I've said it before in this parliament) that six out of the twelve countries for a long time had notes in circulation of a value of between 500 and 600 euro. If you were not to issue this note
column140: criminal elements undoubtedly would find other bearers of value in which to invest the proceeds of their criminal activities
column141: let alone that there always will be the 1000 Swiss franc note. On the transfer
column142: I believe that is a question to be asked to the European Commission and finance ministers. In principle
column143: for the effect you prescribe
column144: the requirement of a large bailout if there is an asymmetric shock
column145: the Treaty of Maastricht prevents such bailouts taking place. But the question basically is
column146: are the Structural Funds of the EU budget large enough
column147: and I believe that I have to indeed leave the answer to that question to the fiscal authorities together with the European Commission.   Mrs Van den Burg (PSE/NL)   Thank you Madame chairman. Mr Duisenberg
column148: you just mentioned something about the psychological effect of the introduction of the notes and coins
column149: which had quite an impact on people compared to the earlier introduction of the single currency. It struck me as well that public opinion has been affected greatly by that psychological effect and there is much greater awareness now of the link between the monetary project and the greater project of European integration
column150: that's the case anyway in the Netherlands and we've seen that being expressed in publications there. And this with the convention which will prepare for the future of the Union
column151: we are going to see a continuation of that political break and over the Christmas break I had the pleasure of reading a book written by one of your former colleagues
column152: André Szász who also said that in Maastricht the monetary union had been dissociated from the political union but clearly now we are seeing the two being associated and linked again and Mr Wellink also said that he felt monetary union to be a part of that greater political project. I'd like to know what you think about the fact that this discussion has been restarted.   Mr Duisenberg   Is monetary union possible without political union
column153: that basically is the question
column154: and will the introduction of notes and coins do something to bring political union closer? I always find it very difficult to define what does it mean - political union? Which field of politics are we talking about
column157: foreign policy
column159: law
column160: everything? I am of the opinion that the psychological impact of the cash changeover
column161: at least I have that impression
column162: has given a great boost to the feeling of sort of fraternalization ('Verbroedering') in Europe amongst the population. The public will start to exert pressure on their elected representatives to also come to further harmonisation of policies or even integration in some cases in various other fields
column163: because the public will not understand that policies can be so different in the various areas of a region
column164: and we are no more than a region in the euro area
column165: which uses one currency
column166: which daily goes through our hands. But then in practice
column167: it is my conviction that in certain policy areas
column169: the single currency will
column170: by making prices transparent and easily comparable in the various countries
column171: pressure will arise to come to a greater harmonisation e.g. of indirect taxes
column172: of excise taxes
column173: of income taxes. That pressure will undoubtedly be there. I also believe myself that it will happen without saying that in the end the systems will be equal everywhere. There can very well be differences and there is no attack on national sovereignty in all these areas. At the same time in
column174: for example
column175: the fiscal structure or the social benefits structure
column176: the gap is narrowing. But it will also be a long time before we can say: now really we have an integrated or harmonised policy in all areas. We may talk about decades rather than about years.   Mr Purvis (PPE-ED/UK)   Mr President
column177: it seems quite premature to me but there appears to be some disappointment among politicians and journalists at the relatively meagre take-up of the euro as a reserve currency around the world. Is the ECB actively promoting the euro's reserve role or intending to promote that role
column178: and if so
column179: why is it such a good thing to be a reserve currency. Would you like to see the euro as a major reserve currency and what
column180: if you do is
column181: the time frame? If not
column182: what will you do to discourage it? Would it be more relevant to work towards the use
column183: the denomination in euros of international trade of commodities such as oil
column185: major EU agricultural products and other commodities in euros and what do you feel is the potential here
column186: and can this be achieved separately from the role as a reserve currency or are they inevitably combined?   Mr Duisenberg   The ECB neither encourages or discourages the use of the euro as an international reserve currency. At the moment
column187: the euro represents roughly 13% of world reserves and the major reserve currency undoubtedly is the US dollar. But we are not in competition with the US dollar in that respect. So
column188: the answer to your question is no. We observe that the use of the euro as a reserve currency is increasing - we see that from the statistics that are being published by the BIS for example. It is increasing but it is a slow process and it is in all likelihood going to remain a slow process. I don't have to remind you that in the past big central banks have made quite some efforts to discourage the use of their currency by other authorities
column189: as they would be too far away for their monetary policy to reach. But in the end
column190: all central banks that have tried to discourage the use of their currency as a reserve currency
column191: the Bundesbank is one example
column192: have given up the discouragement because it was ultimately the market that determined the outcome
column193: and we expect the same for the euro. Now I often give the example that around the turn of the last century
column194: around 1900
column195: the United States already was by far the largest economic power in the world. But it took the dollar about 60 years to replace sterling as the world most important and the internationally most-used currency. The other part of the question
column196: our stance on invoicing
column197: we are also neither encouraging nor discouraging that. What we are encouraging people to do
column199: is to do as much as their invoicing as possible in euros so that they can avoid the exchange rate risks with third countries
column200: including the "outs"
column201: and they can thereby lower their costs by avoiding having to pay a risk premium in the price for the goods they deliver. It is likely that the habit of invoicing in euros will spread
column202: also in the light of the accession of at least ten new countries to the European Union and ultimately
column203: some time later
column205: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)   Thank you. That concludes our first monetary dialogue. President I hope that the introductory phase can be successfully completed and that this year will be characterised by price stability
column206: low interest rates
column207: better growth and more employment. That would be a very good first year for the euro for Europe and I hope that the euro will become the keyword for 2002. Thank you.

column3: Testimony before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament with the President of the European Central Bank
column7: which still seems to be continuing. The only thing that has changed is everything relating to inflation. So
column8: my question is as follows. Do you not think that in order to take account of these improved inflation conditions
column9: and because we do have price stability
column11: would it not be a good measure to lead to a recovery by a decrease in interest rates as soon as possible
column12: which I think would be the positive contribution of the European Central Bank to economic recovery?   Mr Duisenberg   First of all
column13: if there is a change in the monetary policy stance
column14: the effect of that will become visible or known in the economy one year
column15: or one and half years later
column16: which would in this particular case be at the moment that the economy
column18: is already growing at its potential growth rate; second
column19: the actual level of real short-term interest rates which we can influence are already at a level safely below
column20: and not higher than the level of real short-term rates experienced between 1999 and October 2001.. I would under no circumstances
column21: be prepared to jeopardise price stability. So
column22: the answer in short to your question is you have not convinced me.   Mr Schmidt (ELDR/SV)   Thank you very much Mr Duisenberg. Well
column23: we are sitting here and we are a little bit jealous because we are not going to be part of monetary union in a couple of weeks time
column24: and I hope that this disappointment is something that you can at least empathise with. I'd like Sweden to become a member as soon as possible and I think the economic criteria are very clear for my country
column25: but however
column26: Mr Duisenberg I think there is some doubt about the legal criteria. The most important lawyer in the Swedish Central Bank thinks that the constitution would have to be changed as far as the monopoly on the minting of coins is concerned
column27: and also on monetary policy. Now Mr Duisenberg
column28: the Swedish Minister of Finance has also expressed a certain amount of concern about the reduction in the independence of the Swedish Central Bank
column29: so what I would like to ask really is with all that as a background
column30: would Sweden already fulfil the legal requirements for participation in EMU? Has the ECB got any contacts with the Swedish government to check whether they could be any way of getting rid of the doubts about legislation in Sweden and whether or not that fits in with the fixed criteria for economic and monetary union? This Mr Duisenberg could mean that there may be some problems that should be traced and detected as quickly as possible. So Mr Duisenberg
column31: are there are any constitutional changes necessary? Should the Swedish Parliament take the necessary decisions to ensure that Sweden could become a member? We do need information on that
column32: and I would like to have some guarantee on that from you. Thank you very much.   Mr Duisenberg   If Sweden were to apply for membership of the euro area
column33: Sweden would have to conform with all the convergence criteria that have been applied to the other participating countries as well
column34: and that includes the legal requirements of full independence of the Central Bank. The Charter of the Swedish Central Bank would have to be made to conform with the requirements of the Treaty. So whether this is only a matter for the Constitution or the Bank Act
column35: I'm not in a position to judge
column36: but there would have to changes made. In the 2000 Convergence Report
column37: and in the other convergence reports of '98 and '97 of the EMI
column38: it has been pointed out that a range of amendments would have to be made
column39: and that has been made public
column42: Chapter 9
column43: Article 13 of the Constitution Act and in Chapter 9
column44: Article 11. All these changes are regarding the Central Bank's powers in the field of monetary policy
column45: regarding the exclusive rights to issue bank notes and coins and regarding the Central Bank's powers of exchange rate policy. The Swedish authorities are fully aware of this because I have confirmed this in a letter to Minister Ringholm on 19 July last.   Mr Schmidt (ELDR/SV)   But were you satisfied by the answer of Mr Ringholm in his letter to you in the autumn? You have got the letter
column46: were you satisfied by his answer?   Mr Duisenberg   The issue is not very acute at the moment
column47: so I think that it remains on the table; also the requirements remain there. I could still respond again to Mr Ringholm and that would indicate that I would not be totally satisfied with his answers.   Mr. Schmidt (ELDR/SV)   Mr Chairman
column48: on the other hand the issue is very acute if we have to change the constitution.   Mr Duisenberg   Yes
column49: that is true. We have taken note of that.   Mr Abitbol (EDD/F)   Thank you very much President. Mr Duisenberg
column50: one of the reproaches against you is that the ECB pursues a single target of price stability. But this reproach is only made against ECB because that's the role referred on the ECB by the Treaty. The Statutes give you that single objective. Mr Greenspan was saying that the ECB was
column51: all of the Central Banks in the world
column52: the only one with a single target
column54: and so there is a debate underway in France. You know that we are entering into an electoral campaign period now which is very important for France and one of the main candidates has said that he is in favour of a change in the way in which the ECB works and
column56: growth and employment would be added to the simple price stability criteria. So my question is straightforward: I would like to know whether that is a feasible idea for a central bank like yours
column57: not today because now you are applying the Maastricht treaty as it stands
column58: and you can of course discuss the way in which you apply this target
column60: or perhaps totally out of the question
column61: that the management criteria that have been conferred on you by the Maastricht treaty might be changed in the context of the Treaty review for 2004?   Mr Duisenberg   It is feasible
column62: but I do not regard it as desirable. Let me say that. One always has to remember that monetary policy in the longer term does not have an impact on the real performance of the economy but has an impact on inflation
column63: and that is the basic reason why in the Treaty this target is given so much preponderance. I would at the same time say that the Treaty also says: "without prejudice to price stability the ECB should support the goals of the European Community." That is
column65: the ECB should contribute to reach high levels of growth and low levels of unemployment. But we do believe that the best way to do that
column66: to achieve this secondary target of the ECB
column67: is to provide the European economy with a climate of price stability and predictable price stability
column68: so that investors and consumers can rely on the ECB to preserve the value of their money. And creating such a climate of stability over the medium term is
column70: indeed the best contribution that the Central Bank can make to achieve this target.   Chairman
column71: Mr Herzog (GUE/NGL/F)   Well I would just like to interject that what Mr Duisenberg is saying about the relationship between monetary policy growth and inflation
column72: that it has no impact on long term growth but an impact on inflation
column73: well it is 100% Milton Friedman. Allow me to say that
column74: as an academic it is 100% Milton Friedman's recipe.   Mr Abitbol (EDD/F)   I just wanted to know whether it was feasible or desirable. You say it is feasible but not desirable. I don't agree with you at all. But I think it is feasible and one would wonder why the other Central Banks have broader and different targets to those of the ECB. If it weren't feasible to achieve these targets they wouldn't have them. I'm sure that one of the most important political goals in the review of the treaties that are starting now should be to bring about this review of the ECB targets. Thank you.   Chairman
column75: Mr Herzog (GUE/NGL/F)   Thank you very much
column76: now I will give the floor to Mr Mann.   Mr Mann (EPP/D)   Thank you very much Mr Duisenberg
column78: well the night of Saturday to Sunday morning
column79: I was before the stock exchange in Frankfurt am Main together with the president of the Bundesbank
column80: and we said goodbye to the deutschmark and hello to the euro because we received our euro starter kits. Enthusiasm was great among the people
column81: but there was still a lot of concern about price increases of which you have said that these aren't so serious. You say consumers have to be attentive
column82: of course they can switch from one company to another
column83: but very often you have the same supplier behind both companies. And my second question: we keep saying that the exchange rate is not so important
column84: it's the actual internal value. Agreed
column85: but you can see for yourself that the differences are still vital. So how do you gauge the risk of a weakening of the euro if in Central and Eastern Europe they are placing a lot of emphasis at the moment on the Swiss franc and the dollar?   Mr Duisenberg   The main movement that we see
column86: both inside the euro area and in Central and Eastern Europe
column87: is that most of the currency in circulation will be exchanged into euro
column88: or is being dug out and being converted into euro bank deposits. There is some
column90: movement into Swiss francs and US dollars
column91: but we are not at all concerned about that. We also have to realise that the money in circulation in total is only a small part of the total of stock of liquidity. To be precise it is only 6% of M3
column92: which takes the forms of notes and coins in circulation. So changes of the type you and I just mentioned are changes in only that 6% part and they are minor. So their impact on the exchange rate
column95: Mr Herzog (GUE/NGL/F)   Thank you. Mr Bullmann now.   Mr. Bullmann (PES/D)   Thank you Mr Chairman. President Duisenberg
column96: I'm going to have to come back to a question related to the path towards growth that we want to try and define. Mr Von Wogau opened up the debate
column97: and unlike him I don't hear that many experts saying that we should dissolve the Stability and Growth Pact. I don't hear many people saying that. What I am hearing rather is the voice of the very experts we should be taking seriously. Admittedly
column98: many of them are those well-known radical left-wingers
column99: such as Norbert Walter of the Deutsche Bank
column100: or I could quote economists from the Bayerische Hypothekenbank. No doubt my Bavarian colleagues could confirm that these are also leading advocates of Socialism - Marxism even! (Laughter) But these are experts who are saying that we have a very serious problem. And they are saying that the European Central Bank is not discussing this
column101: to the benefit of the German government. But they are looking at this on the basis of figures from the Commission. And if you take a look at the autumn forecasts for the Commission for the year 2002
column102: their forecast said that the growth rate for the year 2002 would be below that for the year 2001. 1.4% for the year 2002
column103: rather than 1.6 in the year 2001. And the Commissioner responsible then further reduced this to 1.3% at the Laeken Summit. So 1.3% growth for the year 2002. If
column105: monetary policy is meeting its objectives
column106: shouldn't we be working towards a co-ordinated fiscal policy? Should we not be doing more to make sure that Europe acts in a more co-ordinated way if we do not want to depend on US growth rates? Is there not a need for action
column107: and what would your specific advice be?   Mr Duisenberg   My specific advice I have given. This is not a time
column108: which calls for fiscal activism. I have said there is always a need for more co-ordination amongst the finance ministers
column109: amongst governments and with the European Central Bank. As long as co-ordination means the full exchange of information I am in agreement. But that there never can be
column112: a co-ordination of monetary and fiscal policy
column113: because that could endanger the mandate of the ECB which is first and most of all to preserve price stability
column114: and excludes co-ordination if that co-ordination brought about changes in the monetary policy stance which were not inspired by the expected inflation performance of the economy
column115: that would I believe seriously undermine the credibility of the monetary institution. So there will not be. Otherwise
column116: there is the fullest co-operation of the ECB with the fiscal authorities
column118: in the form of a full and frank exchange of information
column119: where the fiscal authorities have the big advantage of knowing what the policy of the ECB is and will be at all times.   Chairman
column120: Mr Herzog (GUE/NGL/F)   Mrs Villiers is the last speaker on this topic of monetary policy.   Mrs. Villiers (EPP/ED/UK)   President Duisenberg
column121: I very much wanted to draw your attention to a topic
column122: which has been raised
column123: on a number of occasions in this committee
column124: and that is the ability of the markets to read the ECB. I would put it to you that the ECB does continue to have a communication problem in that the markets feel that they are able to read and predict the signals that come
column125: for example
column126: from the Fed or the Bank of England. But the persistent criticism of the ECB is that is very difficult to predict and its very difficult to read on the part of the markets. I would strongly urge you to address your communication strategy
column127: and to try to work out a way to give clearer signals to the market
column128: and to open up in ways that have been recommended by this committee on many occasions to make the ECB a more transparent operation. I am very interested in your views as to how you intend to review your communication strategy
column129: because of course your relationship with the market as we all know is absolutely crucial in determining the external value of the euro. So I am sure that this committee would very much appreciate your thoughts on your current communication strategy and whether you have any intentions of modifying it or updating it or changing it in any way in the year to come.   Mr Duisenberg   We are continuously scrutinising it. We also are continuously
column131: improving it. But we are faced with one major problem. We have to communicate to the public and markets at large in 11 official Community languages and in even more different cultures and we have to explain ourselves. So what we continuously are trying to do is to speak with one voice
column132: but through more than one mouth. But increasingly
column133: the tendency is to let the sound that is coming from those mouths
column134: basically be the sound that comes out of my mouth. That's the form of discipline that we are imposing on ourselves and we know that markets are continuously guessing or outguessing what the ECB thinks or does. It is
column136: one of the reasons why
column137: whereas we think there is a need to maintain our bi-weekly meeting schedule
column138: that we have publicly announced to the market that it is only during one of the two meetings per month that we will discuss monetary policy. Then
column139: in particular when changes in the monetary policy are apparent or dawning
column141: we have agreed amongst ourselves
column142: that it is primarily to me to whom the markets should listen. Those are all tiny improvements
column143: but I believe they are improvements and so is our experience also of the past two or three months
column144: after we have executed these measures and have come to this understanding amongst the members of the Governing Council.   Mrs. Villiers (EPP/ED/UK)   Can I ask a brief supplementary? Would you say
column145: Mr Duisenberg
column146: that some of the reasons why the euro hasn't recovered from the significant losses that it saw in the first few months is because the markets still find very difficult the coherence of the policy of the ECB
column147: that your communication difficulties mean that the markets really can't see or can't accept that the ECB is pursuing any long term or coherent strategy
column148: and that affects their confidence in the currency?   Mr Duisenberg   I can't understand that. And I also say openly that I also have difficulty in explaining why the euro stays where it is for such a long time. I still do believe that the euro has a strong potential to appreciate. But as for not having a strategy
column149: or a clear strategy
column150: I would say the ECB is the only central bank in the world that goes out of its way to explain its strategy
column151: or even has a strategy. Thank you.   Chairman
column152: Mr Herzog (GUE/NGL/F)   One additional question in the last 10 minutes on the euro. Mrs Thyssen   Mrs Thyssen (EPP/ED/B)   Thank you very much Mr Chairman. President of the Central Bank
column153: I have got a question which may not seem to be that important
column154: but I think it is something which is very important for the people out there who are very much concerned by the details of all this. We have heard discussions with Minister Reynders
column155: who has been presiding over the Eurogroup for the past year
column156: and I think it is a bit of a shame that we didn't get the two to overlap because Mr Reynders did say very clearly that
column157: even though it was on a personal basis and he did try to be very prudent in what he said
column158: that he actually would have liked to have seen a bit more frontloading of notes
column159: of euro notes to the consumer. He said that it is not excluded that here and there may be some ATM machines which may be tested and therefore will have to be loaded with euro notes before 1 January. I have seen here that the European Parliament is probably not the only institution which is in favour of frontloading of notes for consumers and I would like to ask you whether you are going to decide this week that since the coins and have now been distributed and it is going very well
column160: people are not now trying to use the coins they are just getting them to get their hands on them
column161: to learn what they look like
column162: to see how they will use them
column163: wouldn't you perhaps therefore give the green light to the banks and to the post offices
column164: just a few days before New Year
column165: to give perhaps small denominations of notes out to the public? The notes are there
column166: the banks have them
column168: its just a very small sign that you would have to give to make it possible and to allow people to get their hands on the notes. So I think it would it allay a lot of fears. And then an additional question. What are you going to do when you see that the notes are being distributed just before New Year anyway
column169: what would you do about that?   Mr. Duisenberg   I have to disappoint you and Mr Reynders. The main thing that we wanted to be sure of was that the introduction of the banknotes would take place simultaneously in all 12 participating Member States. That's the main thing. Once you have done that
column170: you have to pick a date
column172: and you have to pick one date and then not deviate from that. We have to take into account that at all costs we have to avoid confusion. I know in some countries the retail sector
column173: for example
column174: would appreciate some of the notes to be distributed earlier. I know also of countries
column175: and big ones
column176: where the retail sector thanks us for not distributing the notes
column177: even a few days before the fixed day. All the logistics of the various sectors is geared towards distributing the notes on 1 January
column178: and it would take a sizeable investment and create a lot of confusion if we deviated from that stated policy. But then we have only 12 days to go anyway. The problem will soon be all over.   Mrs Torres Marques (PES/P)   Thank you very much Mr Chairman. I wish to pick up on a point that the President of the ECB has insisted upon
column179: the euro starter kits. Apparently they have run out. In Portugal they have run out and in other countries as well. This is extremely successful and there is a desire on the part of our citizens to get their hands on the euros
column180: on the coins. And I think that this has been far more successful than anyone could have guessed. The Belgian minister when he first spoke to us said that we are facing something very new. There is a great degree of enthusiasm on the part of the people to have these coins and notes. Now as a lawyer I don't really know what the difference is between having coins or notes
column181: because all of them are euros. This was the point made by the Belgian Minister as well. But he was saying that we are going to have to test some
column182: one or two ATMs to see whether they do actually give us euros
column183: and as he said this is quite a new phenomenon - this enormous demand for euros
column184: and I think the ECB should have the right kind of capacity to cater for this kind of phenomenon.   Mr Duisenberg   As far as the testing of ATMs is concerned
column185: Mr Chairman
column186: we have already opened a facility a year ago where all the producers of automatic teller machines have been invited to test their machines and they have done so. They are compatible with giving you euros when asked. In addition we have established other test centres all over the European Union for the machines to be tested
column187: so what you are asking for is already being done and is in place for a long time already.   Chairman
column188: Mr Herzog (GUE/NGL/F)   I suggest we listen to the last two colleagues and take those two questions together. Mr Maaten.   Mr. Maaten (ELDR/NL)   Thank you. I would like to talk about the introduction so far of the euro. I think things are going very well
column189: apart from some problems that people had expected but which did not occur
column190: so I think things are going very well. But I do have a question. The enthusiasm for the euro kits
column191: the starter kits
column192: is a very good sign for the euro
column193: but it also means that the national central banks have been very surprised. People weren't actually expecting this. So is there going to be any adjustment made now for the distribution of notes on the 1st of January
column194: because I think you can also expect the same kind of enthusiasm on the 1st of January for the notes? Maybe the demand is going to be higher than availability? In connection with the coins
column195: which are already distributed
column196: I have heard that in some places there are shopkeepers who are already accepting the coins and that transactions are being carried out in euros. Is this going to lead to any problems?   Mr Radwan (EPP/ED/DE)   Well I'm always the last to get the floor so I must be doing something wrong. But I would like to make a brief comment and then ask a question. Your responses to Mr Marinos and Mr Mann were I felt a little bit disappointing. I think in the media at the moment this issue of hidden price increases with the introduction of the Euro rounding up is very important. People are talking about a third of the products being subject to this. This is what is being said on German television
column197: and I would be very happy if the ECB could say something about this. You do have a very calm serene position and perhaps you could put this discussion on a more factual footing. I had heard in the Commission that there were price increases and we are talking about 0.1% of the inflation rate there. I don't know where these Commission figures actually came from but I would be very grateful if the ECB could say something here. There is a discussion
column198: which is taking place across Europe about the hidden price increases; perhaps you could say something factual about that to allay people's fears? Finally
column199: in the European Parliament last week we decided on the regulation on cross-border transfers and you said explicitly that you did welcome the aim but you didn't like the means. Now more than a year ago
column200: we did ask the ECB to play a co-ordinating role within the European banking world and to try to ensure that there would be uniform standards which would then lead to self regulation. Now we have still got 18 months before the regulation
column201: will take effect and in the European Parliament we are always open to this kind of self regulation but I would still be interested in what kind of action the ECB is starting to ensure that the self regulation will kick in time and will allow the banking world to be a little better co-ordinated.   Mr Duisenberg   First
column202: if there are too few euro kits with coins
column203: will the same happen with notes? I don't think so. 15 billion bank notes are ready. They are available already. Our estimate is that to replace the current currency in circulation in the form of notes
column204: we will need about 10 billion notes
column205: so that the remaining 5 billion notes are a logistical stock
column206: which is available already. Then
column207: in addition we very much encourage banks
column208: and it is being done in particular in the Netherlands
column209: to concentrate the issuance on low denominations in the first days of next year. So the automatic teller machines in many banking systems
column210: including in the Netherlands
column211: will be filled almost exclusively with five and 10 euro bank notes. In those countries where social welfare payments are still made in cash
column213: the payments will be made in low denomination bank notes and the estimates have been made for that. So I don't think that that problems will arise. That there are too few kits available right now
column215: but I am also trying to push that responsibility where it belongs
column216: namely to the Ministers of Finance. Be a little bit clearer about hidden price increases? I say over and over again
column217: we try to monitor it as closely as possible together with the national central banks and the national statistical institutes. We honestly cannot find a significant effect on prices. Maybe some of it has already happened. Maybe that already last spring
column218: when we saw this jump in inflation in the euro area
column219: up to a figure of 3.4% in April. I don't exclude that part of that was already due to price increases
column220: which would no longer have to be made in order to reach nice round euro figures at the day of the conversion. But that is a thing of the past. At the moment we do not discern significant motives or developments pointing to the phenomenon of hidden price increases. We do however monitor it closely. We do welcome the announcement by the governments in July last that they would do the rounding in such a way that the outcome would be in favour of the customer
column222: as far as administered prices are concerned
column223: and we do call on the consumer organisations to remain vigilant. I know of some countries where they are very vigilant indeed in nailing down those enterprises whenever they see this movement developing and not without success. On the cross border retail payments: just let me say we share the aim
column224: namely to have basically in one monetary area also one tariff
column226: for domestic as well as cross border retail payments. We have given our opinion on the draft Regulation that was before the European Parliament. Many of the critical remarks
column227: which we had included in our opinion
column228: have been taken on board. Some have not
column229: and the main thing that has not been accepted is that we are of the opinion that one should have given the banks somewhat more time
column230: even a few years to change their software systems and to change their administrations because we simply think that they cannot cope with the substance of the Regulation in such a short time. We don't want to lose the very co-operative stance of the big banking associations
column232: who are very co-operative in helping us to achieve the ultimate aim
column236: Mr Herzog (GUE/NGL/F)   Thank you very much. Well
column237: we didn't follow that point of view when recently we adopted the Regulation on cross border payments
column238: but that's all part of the same debate. Anyway thank you very much
column240: and we wish you a merry Christmas
column241: but I hope that first of all we will meet you outside for the inauguration of the euro statue.
