column3: The ECB's monetary policy -  accountability
Testimony before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliamentwith the President of the European Central Bank
column7: and I think this is important in terms of the implications for public finances
column8: that there will be no recession but you didn't define your terms
column9: and if a period of rising unemployment is not to be defined as a recession
column10: presumably there were no recessions in Europe between 1945 and 1973
column11: but it would be useful to have your definition there. Secondly
column12: you said that some countries clearly are not in a position to allow the full operation of the automatic stabilisers. Could you specify please
column13: which of the euro area countries in your view are not in a position to allow the full operation of the automatic stabilisers? And thirdly
column14: you said in an answer earlier on that those which were not in a position to allow the full operation of the automatic stabilisers would have less room
column16: less room but not no room. So there is clearly in your mind
column18: continue pursuing the ultimate target of getting an abnormal cyclical position into a position where they are close to balance or in surplus. But they are allowed to have acceptance of the cyclical consequences. My question there is what should that compromise be? Clearly in the euro area
column19: when the stability programmes were set this time
column20: the overall projection for growth was about 3%. It's now if you look at the latest IMF forecast 1.9% so there's been a substantial reduction in the growth forecast for this year and that obviously has an impact on public finances. How much should the extra flexibility be for those countries which cannot fully allow the automatic stabilisers to work? So please specify the countries and how much flexibility they should have.    Mr Duisenberg    The countries which we most closely watch in this respect
column21: let me put it that way
column22: are quite specifically Germany
column24: Italy and Portugal. As to the extent to which they have a degree of flexibility
column25: I take the 3% ceiling as serious. So you can count for yourself
column26: to the extent that their budget deficits were to approach the 3%
column27: if it were purely for cyclical reasons I would make no problem. But to the extent that part of that approach is linked to a relaxation in the expenditure cutting plans or new expenditures being contemplated which have a long-term effect
column29: as they would had structural implications. As I said in my introduction
column30: in this context there seems to be no room for discretionary measures
column32: because expenditure measures have a long-term afterwave of being in existence
column33: even if at the moment they are taken
column34: it is thought that it is only a one-off thing.    Mr Huhne (ELDR/UK)    If I can just have a supplementary on that
column36: which is just to ask: would it be useful in that context
column37: in a year like this one
column38: where there's been a substantial deterioration in the growth outlook and therefore an increase in the projection for deficit
column39: would it be useful to have an operational target of say a primary cyclically adjusted balance rather than having this rather fudged solution?    Mr Duisenberg    I am aware of that discussion. For a variety of reasons
column40: but mainly for reasons of the credibility of the Pact which was agreed only 3 years ago
column41: to change it and to fudge the definitions
column42: would to my mind already undermine the credibility and with that the confidence in the Stability Pact.    Mrs Villiers (EPP/ED/UK)    Mr Duisenberg
column43: I completely agree with you that we all need to act calmly in this moment of crisis. I agree that structured reform is the key to a healthy economy and it's much more important than monetary and fiscal management. I am the last person to say that governments can spend their way out of a recession
column44: but I can't help looking back to 1998
column45: when the world stood at the edge of the precipice looking down at the prospect of recession
column46: and only Alan Greenspan with a combination of political acumen and rate cuts pulled us back from that precipice. Now we must now be standing a whole lot closer to that precipice
column47: not only with the appalling tragedy that we've just seen yesterday in the heart of Wall Street
column48: but also with the economic slowdown which you've just acknowledged is more serious than you expected. I mean
column50: isn't it worth at least thinking about viewing the Stability Pact with more flexibility
column51: even as a short-term measure just to try and head off recession? Can we really be sure that the Stability Pact holds all the answers in good times as well as bad? I really urge all of us in this room
column52: and you Mr Duisenberg
column53: to think about whether in these particular circumstances applying every single precise letter of the Stability Pact is what is going to be best in order to prevent the world economy from falling over that precipice
column54: which we all very much hope that it's not going to do.    Mr Duisenberg    First of all
column55: it is remarkable how short-lived the slow-down in 1998-99 was. Much more short-lived than everybody or anybody
column57: had anticipated. I am sure he would most gracefully accept your compliments without maybe entirely sharing it
column58: but he would certainly accept it. But in these particular circumstances
column59: to react to a disaster as has happened and which is still being absorbed and the ramifications of which we cannot at all be sure of
column60: I think it is of particular importance that we stick to our medium-term strategies and goals
column61: while fighting the consequences of the disaster in any appropriate way possible. But whether that would be a reason to change our structural polices is a question I'm inclined to say no to.    Chairman
column64: I would like to ask another question which is raised elsewhere in the economic and financial world: what is the role of monetary policy and what should its role be in future
column65: when one considers that the reductions in interest rates have not had the desired effects
column66: or at least the effects desired by the President of the US Federal Reserve? When one considers that the measures taken by the Bank of Japan have not had results enabling Japan to get out of its crisis
column67: one has to ask questions. We can wonder whether the central banks are all going in the right direction. I would like to talk about the future
column68: about the future role of the central bank
column69: and in particular of the European Central Bank. I ask this question because the very precise definition of the task of the European Central Bank has still not been clarified. When in your view will the time come for the European Union's employment policy and economic policy to be effectively supported by the European Central Bank?    Mr Duisenberg    That moment is already there and we will support it and we are supporting it by preserving price stability. Because it is our strong conviction
column70: and I know it's an almost ritual answer
column71: but preserving price stability and now bringing it back
column72: that is the best contribution that monetary policy can make to let all economic agents
column73: consumers and producers take their decisions on an expected environment of stable prices to take away uncertainty
column74: to convince them that prices will remain stable
column75: then they can make investment decisions
column76: spending decisions as far as consumers are concerned
column77: in a most responsible way. And so with that
column78: it remains the best contribution. The question is is this debate going on in the heart of the governing council? The answer is no
column79: because we are very happy and satisfied
column80: both on theoretical and empirical grounds
column81: with the mandate that we got. And the mandate being maintaining price stability and without prejudice to price stability
column82: fostering the goals set out for the European Union in Article 2 of the Treaty. We are very satisfied with that and in no way can you expect from this governing council an initiative to change the Treaty.    Chairman
column83: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    You have drawn our attention to the fact that in the United States there are no risks for price stability
column84: but the US has a very different definition of price stability. It is not as narrow as that used by the ECB. In light of this
column85: should the ECB not think again?    Mr Duisenberg    You can have many definitions of the average price developments. We chose and defended here in this building the concept of a harmonised index of consumer prices
column89: I would think it would be unwise to start trying to manipulate the definition in order to create more room for discretionary measures. And so I'm not very much inclined
column90: to say the least
column91: to start redefining our definitions or redefining our concepts of price movements at a stage when the economy is developing in a way that is less satisfactory than we had hoped for.    Chairman
column92: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Why is the ECB the only central bank in the world
column94: narrow definition of price stability?    Mr Duisenberg    I don't know whether the definition is so narrow and so much narrower than that of other central banks. I would have to look into that. But there are central banks
column95: which have a precise inflation target
column97: and they do that on the basis of one definition
column98: which they can use. I would have to look into that
column100: and to see whether your statement that we have the strictest or most narrow definition of price movements
column101: to what extent that statement holds water.    Chairman
column103: we would be delighted if you could give us an answer to that. Thank you. Mr Tannock.    Mr Tannock (EPP/ED/UK)    Madam Chairman
column105: I'm not sure how wise it was for you
column107: to publicly admit to Mr Huhne the fact that the ECB's emergency contingency plans are not yet operational. Is this not putting your bank in jeopardy during this period? On security matters
column108: it is also reassuring that the internet and e-mail communications throughout the period yesterday of disruption to landlines and mobiles remained fully operational
column109: and I think that's actually interesting as the Pentagon
column111: specifically designed it with redundancy in mind for this kind of event. I personally am particularly concerned on a specific question about the euro 500 note
column112: which I think will be a gift to organised crime
column113: tax avoiders and counterfeiters. Can you just reiterate again the justification for the production of such a high denomination note in euroland? On a monetary issue
column114: I note that the July figures have accelerated for annual broad money growth in euroland from 5.3% to 5.9%
column115: which is well above your target or your announced target of 4.5%. In view of your 25 basis point reduction on August 30
column116: does this mean that you are now abandoning money supply figures as an indication of future inflation in the euro zone? Thank you.    Mr Duisenberg    Madam Chairman
column117: we are creating a disaster standby facility for the ECB
column118: but then it's not the ECB alone that implements monetary policy. It's the Eurosystem. That's 13 central banks
column120: and many of which
column121: if not all
column122: already have their disaster standby facility operational for years. So for the Eurosystem as a whole
column123: which is implementing monetary policy measures and market operations every day
column124: that I would say have no fear. The thing is already there. Only our own is not yet operational and it costs time to build create a thing and money
column125: I must say. On the internet
column127: I don't know what to answer. I'm also very pleased; I was very pleased up until and including this morning that I could use those instruments to communicate with those with whom I wanted to communicate. Why the € 500 note? Don't forget that denominations of such a magnitude are freely floating and have been issued for years - in Germany
column128: the Netherlands
column129: Austria and one or two other countries. We have the 1
column131: 000 Guilder notes. We have the thousand shilling notes in Austria
column132: all equivalents to such a note. So it's nothing exceptional. And don't forget
column133: if you see it as a means of hoarding or of putting away money whether legally acquired or illegally acquired that if we wouldn't have such a note
column134: the money would be hoarded in other currencies. The Swiss have a 1
column136: which is worth a lot more than € 500. The M3 developments. As I indicated
column137: we have to adjust and we are increasingly in a position to adjust the M3 figures
column138: which contain money or assets held by non-euro area residents
column139: i.e. shares in money market funds and money market paper and debt securities with a maturity of up to two years. We have to correct for that and purely statistically it's - I can assure you - a hell of a job. We are increasingly in a position to eliminate those figures from the observed statistics and by the end of this year
column140: we will be in a position that we can fully publish new ranges of M3 figures which exclude all the elements that are held by residents outside the euro area. But already doing that preliminarily
column141: we come to a figure of the three months average M3 growth figure of
column142: I believe
column144: which is - let me put it that way - and now you permit me to correct you - not close to our target of 4.5% but close to our reference value of 4.5%. Monetary developments did not stand in the way the lowering our interest rates by a quarter per cent based on other considerations contained in the second pillar of our monetary policy. So in no way are we abandoning as an element of our monetary policy strategy the analysis of monetary developments? We continue to believe that ultimately inflation is a monetary phenomenon
column145: so that it remains worthwhile to analyse monetary developments as one of the main elements determining inflation over the longer-term
column146: and in no way are we abandoning the first pillar in our analytical strategy.    Chairman
column147: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Thank you. Mr Goebbels.    Mr Goebbels (PES/L)    Mr President
column148: at a recent press conference you said that the automatic stabilisers should only be allowed to come into play fully in the countries where the budgetary situation is close to balance or in surplus. We know that the logic of the stability pact is a long term one
column149: while the current slowdown calls for short-term measures. So for what reasons should some countries be condemned to lead restrictive budgetary policies? You seem to think that the markets are not capable of understanding that an anti-cyclical policy will in fact facilitate long-term stability through short-term measures. In other words: if the automatic stabilisers are able to produce results for some countries
column150: why not accept these for all countries?    Mr Duisenberg    The automatic stabilisers are something different from taking discretionary measures. Those countries that already have achieved this position of structurally having their budget in balance or surplus simply have more freedom to let the automatic stabilisers work. They also have the task that they should maintain their balanced budgetary position over the medium-term and over the cycle on average. And they have all the liberty they need and they want. They don't want anything more. Even to quote an example
column151: which I know best because it is my own country
column152: the largest deviation from a stated budgetary target that a recession has caused - and we have had many in the Netherlands in the 50 years since the war - was between 2% and 2.5% of GDP. It is for that reason that the 3% ceiling leaves
column153: in my opinion
column154: for that country - but I think it holds for all - ample room and adequate room for the automatic stabilisers to work. So for the inevitable rise in unemployment benefits
column156: for the inevitable disappointments in tax revenue which could coincide with a slowdown in economic developments. But not in those countries where the stated goals for the medium-term and the intermediate term have not yet been reached
column157: because all the countries have in their stabilisation programmes announced more or less the date or the year in which they will have achieved their position of having their budget in balance or if necessary
column158: in surplus. Now what we are
column159: what I am pleading for
column160: is to not make this date
column161: which for some countries is 2003
column162: for other countries its 2004
column163: a moving target but to stick to the plans as they are. And that implies that the possibility to let the automatic stabilisers work
column164: to let deficits for cyclical reasons deviate from their stated objectives
column165: are more limited in one country than in another.    Mr Von Wogau (EPP/ED/D)    Mr President
column166: can you confirm that the European single currency is the only currency in the world
column167: which is supported by a Stability Pact? This stability rests on two pillars: the Stability Pact and the independence of the Central Bank. And this Stability Pact has the aim of protecting the currency from national finance ministries. This is all very positive
column168: but today we hear that these two pillars should be extended. I am a little surprised by this situation
column169: especially by the question raised by our Chairman. I think it would be very dangerous
column170: because it would mean sending a signal to the markets
column171: and in the wrong direction. You have indicated that long term interest rates have stayed very low
column172: and I think that in this kind of debate this could be interpreted very differently. So to my question: when one speaks of recession there are different definitions
column173: which are used. Some say - recession means that growth falls. Others consider that there is a recession when growth is negative over two quarters. Growth is currently falling - so what is your definition of recession?    Mr Duisenberg    I believe the Euro is indeed the only currency in the world
column174: which is in its monetary policy backed up by a Stability and Growth Pact
column175: but then I would be inclined to state it a little bit differently. We are the only monetary authority in the world
column176: which does not have
column177: as a natural counterpart
column178: one fiscal authority. And basically
column179: the Stability and Growth Pact is a substitute for having one fiscal authority as a natural counterpart in the process of policy formulation. The Stability and Growth Pact admittedly ties the hands of 12 fiscal authorities in the euro area. I must admit
column180: Mr Von Wogau
column181: that as a Governing Council we haven't even discussed it
column182: but we do not have a very fixed definition of what is a recession. We are inclined to use the word recession indeed as you indicated
column183: which is two consecutive quarters of negative growth. But that's in our thinking
column185: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Thank you. Mr Radwan.    Mr Radwan (EPP/ED/D)    Mr President
column186: before the summer break the Commission made a proposal for a regulation concerning cross-border payments in euro
column187: and recently one of your Central Bank colleagues strongly criticised this proposal. At the beginning of this year a European Parliament report called on the Commission to play a co-ordinating role in the banking world so that progress would be made on cross-border payments. I have already raised this with you at a previous monetary dialogue. At the time
column188: you said that the Central Bank could not play this co-ordinating role. I do not think that you should criticise the position of the Commission on this issue
column189: but now that the Central Bank has made a certain number of criticisms
column190: do you intend to take certain measures to accelerate the process and to achieve standards which would render the proposal for a regulation superfluous?    Mr Duisenberg    The Commission has
column191: as you all know
column192: prepared a draft regulation on cross-border retail payments. Our inclination is to applaud and support the contents of this draft regulation
column193: basically with one proviso. We think that the ambition of the Commission to have this regulation implemented by the banking system already by the 1st of January 2002 may be too ambitious. So we would be inclined
column194: because major changes in software etc and in behaviour are necessary
column195: to grant the banking system somewhat more time
column196: a couple of years more
column197: to achieve both what the Commission wants and what we support. That's the only major difference in view.    Mr Radwan (EPP/ED/D)    Yes
column198: but there is this proposal to equalise the cost of domestic and cross-border payments. Do you support these proposals? I would like to know what is your objective for 1 January 2002
column199: and what are the chances of achieving this objective? I would like to know if we can achieve this objective. What objective could we achieve by 1 January 2002 to equalise the cost of cross-border and domestic payments in euro?    Mr Duisenberg    I want to emphasise; Madam Chairman that the pricing of services is left over to the market mechanism itself. The Commission proposal is already shoving the market mechanism
column200: to some extent
column201: aside
column202: which is a thing that any Central Bank in the world is very hesitant to do
column203: to prescribe the tariffs which banks have to adhere to in order to cover their costs and maybe to make a profit. So we do not have an objective in terms of prices of services
column204: but we recognise that in a single currency area
column205: with a single currency and no borders
column206: with no distinction of the currency used in one part of the region Europe as in another part of the region Europe
column207: it would be rather incomprehensible for the public and not very good for the popularity of the euro
column208: if it was more difficult to transfer a euro from A to B than from A to C. And it is for that reason that we ideologically support the goals that the Commission has set. On the other hand
column209: I do not deny that we are happy that the initiative on this point
column210: I know that the European Parliament would have liked it otherwise
column211: but that the initiative to propose such a regulation is with the European Commission whereas we support the goals. But we do not have a precise goal about what has to happen or will happen on the 1st January. On the 1st January
column212: our only goal is to have as smooth a changeover to the money embodied in this star as is humanly possible.    Chairman
column213: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    I think that the committee shares the view of Mr Radwan. There must be a change with regard to cross-border payments and transfers. In fact we are about to return to this issue to debate it. A supplementary question?    Mr Radwan (EPP/ED/D)    I am glad that you support the objective of the Commission
column214: I am just a little surprised that you criticise the means. But with regard to the objectives of the Central Bank
column215: you appear to have no proposals in this area. Could the Bank not play a role in co-ordinating and accelerating the creation of cross-border payment systems by the banks?    Mr Duisenberg    We are in a constant dialogue with the various elements of the banking system
column216: both with the savings banks
column217: with the Federation of European Banks
column220: the goals to be achieved which we have set out in our letter - I quote by heart - of
column223: what has to be achieved by 1st January 2002. And we exert peer pressure to the maximum extent possible and
column225: I must say the banking system has shown a remarkably co-operative attitude in this respect. Although I do admit that developments still are
column228: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Mrs Torres Marques.    Mrs Torres Marques (PES/P)    Thank you Madam President. Mr Duisenberg I would like to insist on a point which is vital for the credibility of the euro. The European Parliament has intervened several times on this issue. Each time
column229: the Central Bank has said that all these issues can be dealt with without legislation. But I can see for myself that prices instead of falling in the euro zone are going up
column230: which undermines the credibility of the euro. Now
column231: you say that you agree with the regulation
column232: which will be directly transposed into Member State laws on 1 January 2002. I think this is a fundamental step. We have tried to do it in the past and it didn't work
column233: but now it should work and I would like the Bank to strongly encourage this measure
column234: which is truly revolutionary for the euro zone. This will mean a real internal market with one currency for which there will be the same charges everywhere for payments
column235: transfers etc.  Mr Duisenberg: To the best of my knowledge
column236: the European Parliament is involved in the adoption of this proposal. What we do consider is that to impose equal charges for cross-border and domestic payments in order to achieve the objective of a single payment area is not the optimal solution. Firstly
column237: it would interfere with the price formation mechanism and it would contradict the principle of an open market economy. And as long as all the conditions for price equalisation are not there
column238: maybe that the same processing channels can be used for both domestic and cross-border payments
column239: the draft regulation will force the banks to adopt cross-subsidisation practices. And secondly
column240: from the micro-economic viewpoint and in contrast with the arguments put forward in the explanatory memorandum to the draft regulation
column241: the ECB takes the view that the proposed draft regulation may eventually trigger a counter-productive and undesirable reaction by decreasing the supply of cross-border payment services
column242: as banks would not find it appropriate to invest in that business. And then
column244: consumers would suffer from shrinking supply. In addition
column246: domestic credit transfers are free of charge
column251: an undesirable effect of this regulation could be that the current disparities between countries are frozen
column252: and that important price differences for cross-border payments would remain throughout the euro area
column253: because there are differences in domestic charges.    Mrs Torres Marques (PES/P)    Yes
column254: but that is precisely the situation that we wish to overcome
column255: Mr President. The Commission has had the courage to propose this regulation so that the euro finally becomes a single currency in a single market. If this proposal is applied in full
column257: which we must applaud. The banks will just have to adapt. If they do not
column258: the situation will remain as it is and we will not have a single currency.    Mr Duisenberg    In Germany when I make a payment
column259: I'm being charged for making a domestic payment
column260: at least by the bank I'm working with. So I see what costs I have to make. That's a domestic payment I'm talking about. In the Netherlands
column261: where I also make domestic payments
column262: I'm not being charged - I think - but I am being charged of course because processing the payment takes a long time. The interest covered by the bank in the period between the payment I make and the moment the money reaches the recipient that's basically the charge that the bank imposes on me. Now what this regulation does is to force the banks to equalise the practices and I'm not convinced whether this is really the appropriate way forward. I'm in principle for making real costs visible
column263: but were you to make visible the real costs of making transfers also domestically
column264: I know in my country you would cause an outcry. Because the people tend to think that the thing is "gratuite". But then we all know that it is not. To make it visible and therefore transparent has in principle its attractiveness
column265: but why interfere in market practices and market mechanisms if they are accepted so well by the various parts of the population in Europe?    Mr Marinos (EPP/ED/EL)    First of all I would like to say that Mr Duisenberg was right to react calmly to what happened yesterday in New York. If the President of the ECB starts to express his unease then the consequences could be catastrophic at world level. Its a fact that what happened yesterday will probably change the history of the world. It shows that the whole planet is exposed to terrorists
column266: including banks. I was surprised to hear that the German government wanted to give assurances
column267: guarantees to Mr Duisenberg. How can we be sure of anything in such a situation? Before the events of yesterday
column268: inflationary tendencies were already on the increase
column269: which was of course contributing to a slowdown in economic growth. It's clear that there is an inflationary tendency
column271: and it is also clear that some speculators are going to get rich. We are on the eve of the introduction of the euro on 1 January and before we reach that date
column272: Eurostat tells us that most Europeans are worried about the speculation that could be caused by the introduction of the currency. So my question is the following: after the introduction of the euro
column273: and given everything that has happened
column274: do you not think that those who are going to speculate in the framework of the introduction of the euro are going to get rich? Doesn't the ECB's goal of stability risk being compromised?    Mr Duisenberg    First part of the question - do I feel safe in my bank? Of course
column275: that's not just a feeling. That's a feeling that is supported by careful analysis by competent authorities about the physical security of our personnel and to what extent that might be endangered. That comes first and foremost before any other consideration. But that's not a judgement that I'm competent in making. One thing is sure. We will not let these barbaric attacks that have been executed yesterday destroy the functioning of our democratic institutions. But we have to make sure that the life and health and well being of those who man our institutions are guaranteed to the maximum extent
column276: which is humanly possible. Given that
column277: I feel safe in my bank. The second part of the question
column279: is based on the starting point that inflation is increasing. Well
column280: inflation is not increasing - inflation is declining and it will continue to decline – although
column282: there may be hiccups in the process. But that it will continue to decline is our firm belief and expectation and conviction
column283: so that we will have inflation under 2% in the course of the first half of next year. And certainly on average for the year as a whole. So that being given
column284: I cannot answer a question which
column286: is based on a false hypothesis.    Chairman
column287: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Concerning prices I would also like to ask a question. Lots of citizens are complaining about the fact that there are constant changes in the price of the housewife's basket of goods
column288: notably the price of a jar of jam as well as clothing
column291: yoghurt and other foodstuffs. And this is confirmed by information provided by consumer associations. I think that the problem needs to be taken into account when our citizens approach us. Statistical institutes have said that they have no indications of price increases. However
column292: if the man on the street
column295: asks the question and wonders why prices are different in euro
column296: people say it is the fault of the euro. And on a psychological level this is damaging for the acceptance of the euro. So would it not be wise to come back to this problem
column297: both at a political level and at the level of the central banks in co-operation with the European Central Bank
column298: so that we can send a different message on the euro to our citizens?    Mr Duisenberg    I'll do that immediately
column300: both the ECB and the national central banks and the national statistical offices
column301: the process very closely. So far
column302: we have observed little or no evidence of an upward move of prices ahead of
column304: the conversion into euro. We don't deny that the tendency may exist. We are very pleased with the results and the declaration of the Ministers of Finance of the eurogroup who have declared
column305: I believe on the 9th July last
column306: that the governments - the central governments - will round off the conversion of the national currencies into euro to the benefit of the consumer
column307: that is either neutral or to the down side. And we call on other parts of government
column310: to follow this example of the central governments. And we call on the consumer to be very vigilant in following
column313: signalling deviations from this principle. And I know that in some countries
column315: consumer organisations are extremely active in precisely monitoring the conversion process and they are publishing whenever they see a deviation which is significant enough to hit the consumer in a negative
column317: way. So I fully share your concerns and I herewith - may I repeat myself - I applaud what the Ministers of Finance have decided for the central governments. I call on local governments and other public bodies to follow this example. And I call on the consumers to remain vigilant and help them and us in containing this process wherever it were to enlarge.    Chairman
column318: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Mrs Villiers.    Mrs Villiers (EPP/ED/UK)    President Duisenberg
column319: I'd like to raise a point made by an UK citizen
column321: but I think relevant to all people in and outside the euro zone. Are there any arrangements being made to take account of the fact that people from their holidays may have small amounts of currencies which are not their own. Say
column323: may have a small amount of deutschmarks left over from a holiday. Will they be able to exchange those deutschmarks in a bank in France with the launch of the euro notes and coins as easily as they can exchange their French francs? Will they have to pay an extra charge if they are exchanging not their own local currency but someone else's? And on the same basis
column324: in the UK is there any arrangement made for UK citizens to be able to change say deutschmarks or French francs into euro when the changeover happens? And do you anticipate charges being made in the euro zone or indeed outside the euro zone for those types of small transfers?    Chairman
column325: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    The last question is for Mrs Thyssen. If you could be so kind?    Mrs Thyssen (EPP/ED/B)    Madam President
column326: I wanted to raise some questions about cross-border payments
column327: in view of the discussion on the Peijs report which will follow this point on the agenda
column328: I wanted to raise a number of questions in the presence of the President of the ECB. I won't raise them however because indirectly I have heard his answers in response to the questions of others.    Mr Duisenberg    Thank you very much then. I'm not aware of all the arrangements that have been made. We try
column330: to make the exchange of notes free of charge. In as far as it is in our power we ask the co-operation of the banks to make it free of charge. As far as the United Kingdom is concerned
column331: I believe - I'm not 100% sure - that the possibility to change Deutsche marks and French francs and Dutch guilders into sterling will remain for some time - not free of charge but then these changes are never free of charge - if it is into sterling. It was also a striking fact for me to learn that for one of the banknote printing works that are operating
column332: significant orders for euro banknotes did originate with UK clearing banks. So they are preparing for the event as well.    Chairman
column333: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Thank you Mr President. We thank you for the monetary dialogue which has just taken place and we hope that we will have answers to a number of other questions
column334: and I wish you every success for a smooth passage to the introduction of the euro
column335: which will shortly become a reality in the form of notes and coins.

column3: Testimony before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliamentwith the President of the European Central Bank
column6: which ended up in an attitude at that time of literally wait and see. We had to wait and we had to see further evidence and then finally you come up after some time with a new conclusion. Now on fiscal policy
column7: if you have a situation where the expected performance of the euro area economy is one that lets the output growth be at the top rate of what we see as the trend potential growth rate of the economy - we always have said that is about 2 to 2.5 percent
column8: I say now we expect it to be at the top of that range - then there seems to be no reason to cyclically (or periodically) deviate in your fiscal policies from your structural standards. There is no reason
column10: for automatic stabilisers to start working when the stabilisation itself is not in danger. Then there is every reason to keep calling on every single government
column11: but in particular those who still do not comply with their self imposed targets
column12: to over the medium term reach a situation of balance or even a small surplus. There is no reason to deviate from that endeavour.    Mr. Katiforis (PES/Gr):   But nevertheless as things stand now monetary policy and fiscal policy are not pointing in the same direction. Isn't that the case?    Mr Duisenberg:   If monetary policy
column13: of which we regard the stance as appropriate in the current circumstances and based on the current evidence
column14: is reflected in a short term interest rate level of 4.5 percent
column15: that is to my mind fully consistent with the fiscal policy stance that is required to lead to a movement of budgetary results in the direction of continued movement in the direction of balance or surplus. I see no need at the current moment in time for fiscal policy currently to deviate in a pro-cyclical sense or in an anti-cyclical sense to stimulate economies which are still operating euro area wide on
column17: what we call a robust base. So I really see no conflict between the two major policy areas.    Mr Langen (EPP/ED/D):   Mr President
column18: I have got a two-fold question on the present discussions on the subject of the euro
column19: and the declaration that the French Prime Minister
column20: Mr Jospin has made. One is the question of co-ordination of economic and financial policy. In the new proposal it is suggested that the old model of an economic monitoring body should be recreated. I would like to know how you feel about how the co-ordination of financial policy is being managed so far. Do you feel that there is a need to go beyond the present situation
column22: secondly
column23: there is a question of tax harmonisation within the European Union. We know that the proposals in the USA for a huge decrease in taxes would lead to an increase in purchasing power for every household
column24: but also a part of the growth prediction which has been revised downwards would occur in Europe. I would like to know what you think about a reduction in taxes across Europe or a harmonisation of taxes in the Euro zone.    Mr Duisenberg:   On policy co-ordination
column25: Madam Chairman
column26: I think a clearer awareness of the euro area dimension in the process of co-ordinating economic policy making between the Member States is certainly useful
column27: and the ideas that have been brought forward by the European Commission on this aspect are therefore welcome
column28: but I cannot emphasise strongly enough that the European Central Bank cannot be expected to enter into any co-ordination or any commitment which would compromise its primary responsibility
column29: given to it by the Treaty
column30: that is to maintain price stability. Our contribution to any process of economic policy co-ordination is already well known: monetary policy will always primarily be geared towards achieving price stability. That means that monetary policy decisions cannot be subject to any form of prior consultation or could not be subject or guided by predetermined rules of behaviour. On the proposal to hold regular meetings between the ECB President
column31: the euro Group President and the competent Commissioner that seems acceptable also in the light of the Commission's emphasis on what they call "respect for the independence of each party". The Commissioner and I can speak for
column32: respectively
column33: the Commission and the Eurosystem. It remains to be seen to what extent the euro group President of the time can always speak on behalf of his 11 colleagues in the euro group. But that is his problem not mine. On taxes
column35: I will not touch on the issue of tax harmonisation
column36: that goes beyond my area of competence; what I can do is re-emphasise what I also said in my introduction today; tax reforms are in some countries urgently called for
column37: mainly to enhance the structural reforms which are necessary for the functioning of a less rigid labour and product market infrastructure. But they always should be made in a responsible climate
column38: namely if tax reforms imply tax reductions
column39: they should not be without prejudice to the other goals that governments have
column40: namely to achieve the aims of the growth and stability pact
column41: that is to achieve the situation of a balanced budget or slightly in surplus of that. So if there are such tax measures to be taken they should be accompanied by adequate measures on the expenditure side of the budget.    Mrs Beres (PES/F):   Mr Duisenberg
column42: I am sorry but once again I am going to come back to the question of the introduction of euro bank notes. Other colleagues have already taken the floor on this
column43: but I do want to come back to this point because it is part of your responsibility to distribute the notes and it seems to us that above and beyond the technical arguments put forward by the Central Bank
column44: there are other more political or psychological arguments which would warrant our asking you to give fresh consideration to your decision. We feel that there is still a window of opportunity remaining with a meeting of the euro group on 4 June. I must say that hitherto none of the logistical or technical arguments you used really convince me. You talked about the risk of fraud
column45: but I am not honestly sure that the distribution of a paper document will allow people to acquire a sufficient level of awareness. We can see very well that a lot of people are waiting to the last moment to switch over. Psychologically speaking there is an ideal period between the Christmas holidays and New Year during which individuals could go along to their banks and get used to handling small bank notes. Another aspect of practical implementation of the euro comes from the principle of subsidiarity
column46: it is up to the Member States to organise that and you
column48: stressed how well things seem to be organised in a varied and broad way
column49: so on this issue of frontloading of small bank notes is it not conceivable that an option should be left open
column50: subject to the responsibility of commercial banks
column51: for small quantities to be frontloaded in this way? Could you elaborate on that?    Mr Duisenberg:   Before answering the question
column52: may I restate what was foremost in our minds about a year and a half ago when we decided and made public the decision not to frontload to the general public. What most of all seemed important to the entire Governing Council is that the banknotes would be issued at the same moment
column55: and not first in one Member State and then in another. So there was agreement
column56: and it seems to me still to be very important
column57: that we start with one big offensive
column59: of a changeover in all Member States at the same time. Now indeed
column60: the closer you get to the actual date of the lst of January
column61: the less convincing becomes the counterfeiting or fraud argument as you mentioned. I fully agree with you. Nevertheless
column62: we think there are adequate other measures
column63: and I mentioned already some of them
column64: to get the low denomination bank notes into circulation in a very speedy and efficient way
column65: which is also not without cost
column66: by loading the ATMs almost exclusively with 5 and 10 euro banknotes. Now not all countries do that
column68: but most countries will do that and have already agreed that with their national banking systems. I also want a little bit to counteract the notion that there is a general and widespread feeling amongst retail organisations that frontloading to the general public is a necessity. I know it is true in some countries
column69: but I can assure you that we at ECB are also being approached by large retail organisations from other countries who tell us that we should please not frontload. That is also an element
column70: and they say that for the same reasons that we say it. Make the introduction of banknotes uniform
column71: make the money as well known as possible
column72: make the people to the maximum extent familiar with the new banknotes; just don't cross this one border line: frontloading some banknotes. We say all banknotes should be put into circulation one day
column73: and that is lst January. But then we also say: banks play ball; be open on lst January. And most banks in most Member States have already decided to do just that.    Mr Goebbels (PES/L):   Mr Duisenberg
column74: you have just told us that 70% of the euros will be put into circulation by ATMs
column75: you said that during the course of your introduction. But now you have just said that the ATMs will have 5 and 10 euro notes put into them mainly and that is simply inconceivable. Ordinarily speaking
column76: cash machines tend only to have 2 boxes within them
column77: if you are going to fill them with 5 or 10 euro bank notes rather than bigger denominations
column78: you can't have 70% of the euros circulating.    Mr Duisenberg:   According to my information
column79: if I go country by country- this information comes from the monthly monitoring of the European Commission- how many ATMs will have been converted on the first day of circulation? In Belgium
column81: Luxembourg
column82: Austria it will be 100%. They all will have been converted. Then it is up to the individual bank to say which notes do I put in that ATM; now I have understood indeed
column84: some banks are using machines which can carry
column87: others are using machines which can carry three bank notes. That seems to me a minor problem. we are also talking about the first couple of weeks or even days of the changeover. Then in Greece
column90: the number of converted ATMs varies between 90% and 100%. It is only in France where the figure is significantly smaller at 62%. And ss far as things look now
column92: where the figure is significantly smaller. But if you look a few days further
column94: I talked about the first day
column95: when 62% of the ATMs will be converted
column96: the figure is already up to 85%
column97: after the end of the first week. So it is only a matter of days that we are talking about
column98: with respect to the full conversion of all ATMs.    Mrs. Villiers (EPP/ED/UK):   Mr Duisenberg
column99: I really would like to press you on this changeover issue. We have heard extensive things about what you are asking of small retailers
column101: of businesses with the changeover to the euro. What I would like to ask you is
column104: ever actually done an estimate of the total cost of this transfer
column105: because it seems to me really unfair to ask people to undertake this course if we haven't even made an estimation of it. I mean
column106: are there figures for the euro zone as a whole
column108: I know obviously you will be concentrating at the moment on the changeover
column109: but also we must not forget that enlargement of the euro zone is likely within the foreseeable future. What sort of preparations are you doing pending that enlargement process in terms of work and statistical analysis
column110: obviously you got Greece in fairly quickly but are you actually doing further sort of pre-preparations on administrative and statistical work pending possible applications to enlarge the euro zone?    Mr Duisenberg:   The available estimates of total costs of the changeover range between 0.3 and 0.8 percent of GDP. These are one off costs
column111: of course. But I would also in this context
column112: when we talk about the changeover and frontloading again
column113: like to point to one aspect which we should not enter into my consideration but at least
column115: should enter into your considerations
column116: and that is if you frontload to the general public
column118: it will cost the general public money. Assume that the general public would be able to get the banknotes
column119: but would not be permitted to use them
column120: that is a cost. They would then have to invest part of their monthly or weekly income
column121: at least in the sums available for them to spend
column122: in particular
column123: in the rather costly month of December to invest in an asset which they could not use
column124: and it would in general only be the more well to do people who could afford to be frontloaded. The others could not even afford to do that
column125: because they would have to use the money
column126: the hard won income from their labour
column127: for other means. Now on enlargement we are in close contact with all the accession countries and have almost permanent contact at various levels
column128: to prepare them for accession
column129: that is on the legislative level
column131: on financial infrastructure. Those are either multilateral contacts
column132: but there are also many bilateral contacts; mostly
column134: of course with the bentral banks of the particular countries
column135: to prepare them. But then you have also to bear in mind that there is a difference in timing between accession to the European Union
column136: accession to the exchange rate mechanism and accession to the euro area. But we are already now in very close contact and co-operation with all the accession countries on these various issues.    Mrs. Villiers (EPP/ED/UK):   A supplementary are those contacts being maintained with current members of the EU as well? I mean obviously we are very much aware of your work with the accession countries
column137: but enlargement of the euro zone doesn't just relate to those who are applying to join the EU
column138: it relates obviously to those current members of the EU who are not in the euro zone.    Mr Duisenberg:   Yes
column139: I almost tended to forget that there were those countries as well
column140: but I can confirm we are in close contact. Do not forget that in the case of the three countries of the European Union that are not yet members of the Monetary Union
column141: at least their central banks are members of the European System of Central Banks
column142: so the contacts are intense and extensive and indeed it is the case that we carry out most of our co-operation amongst the central banks of the European Union within a committee structure. We have
column143: all in all
column144: 12 ESCB Committees and the Budget Commitee
column145: and on some of those committees also the so-called 'out countries' are included already today in most of the practical work in the committees.    Mrs Torres Marques (PES/P):   Mr Duisenberg
column146: I would like to say that the replies you gave to Mrs Beres and Mrs Villiers would lead me to the exact opposite conclusions to what you said. All the arguments you gave to oppose people being able to get hold of euro coins and notes in their hands
column147: but at least it would be an option open to the people if they wanted actually to get hold of them and this will build confidence in the new currency. Anyway
column148: let's say something about the cross-border transfer costs. The banking authorities have just said
column149: despite what you have said
column150: that there is this commitment to ensure that all the costs will be the same as on the domestic market. But we've just been told that cross-border transfers charges would be somewhere between 10 and 12 euros
column151: the banks felt that that was a good price range. But if you look at 12 euros
column152: it is far from being the same figure which applies to domestic transfers
column153: it is a very high figure. Mr. President
column154: it seems to me that it is quite incredible that the credit institutions are behaving in this way. I also find unbelievable the outrageous percentage charged on credit card payments within the euro zone. There are measure that have to be taken if we are to make sure we have a real internal market.    Mr Duisenberg:   Chairman
column155: I must simply confess I am not familiar with the 12 euro figure. I thought that for the inter-bank transfers the figure was 3 euro. That does not mean yet that it will be the same figure for every client
column156: but at the moment I think it would also be unrealistic to expect completely equal costs within a few months after the changeover without cross-subsidisation between cross border and domestic payments. Cross border transfers are currently a hundred times more costly than domestic ones; the domestic ones of course being extremely cheap because of the full automation and very high volumes involved. But we do expect a significant reduction in prices
column157: but that will ultimately be assessed after some experience in the course of 2002. In the medium to longer term
column158: prices for domestic transfers and cross border
column159: be it intra-European or intra euro area
column160: transfers should be the same.    Mrs. Torres Marques (PES/P):   I am going to give you the figures because they are here
column161: and it says that is 10 to 12 euros everywhere in Europe. But you did not answer about credit cards - the cost of transactions with credit cards in Europe.    Mr Duisenberg:   May I then ask you to repeat your question. I did not get it.    Mrs. Torres Marques (PES/P):   I said it is very expensive to pay with credit cards. It is a percentage of the payment in the euro zone. There is no risk
column162: no exchange risk
column163: so what are you doing to do about it?    Mr Duisenberg:   Well
column164: I would have to look into that
column165: Madam Chairman
column166: because I do not have a precise answer at this point in time. Whether we would be in a position to do something about that
column167: whether that falls within our competence or into the competence of other authorities. We at the European Central Bank can act as a catalyst
column169: but what we cannot do is directly intervene in the market structures and market practices.    Mr Maaten (ELDR/Nl): T   hank you very much President Duisenberg. Your position on the frontloading of notes before l January
column170: I see that your position has not changed and your answer is still unsatisfactory for us. There are some new elements in your decision but it seems that some retail organisations
column172: consumers and even the Prime Minister of France have actually started to express their concerns about the question of frontloading and counterfeiting of notes as well. Concerning this argument about actually giving the notes too early
column173: before 1 January
column174: of course you would need somebody to accept this money before 1 January for there to be a problem. If there are no transactions
column175: I think there is a very limited risk compared to the problems that we are hearing from retailers about the safety of having all these coins and problems and calculation mistakes as well. I think would be possible to get for example 100 euros beforehand a couple of days before 1January and that would help a much bigger group of people. Now I quite agree with you that of course after a week or two everything will be fine. But our concern is that people are not going to be very knowledgeable about what the euro note actually look like
column176: and that is our concern. So the question is: is it so difficult to change your thinking
column177: your plan on this if you could get some effective solutions before the 1st of January
column178: because this answer is really not satisfactory in particular from a safety point of view.    Chairman
column179: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D):   Mr. Maaten is of course the rapporteur for the European Parliament's report on the preparation to the changeover to the euro.    Mr Duisenberg:   It would not be so difficult to change the thinking
column180: what is difficult is to change the policy and why. We have
column181: as ECB or as Governing Council
column182: announced our policy one and a half years ago. That gave certainty to market participants. They knew what to do and when to expect what. Do not underestimate
column183: I plead with you
column184: that if we were to change our position and make frontloading possible
column185: be it for part of the banknotes or for the entire bank notes
column186: say a week or two weeks before the date of introduction
column187: this would require a significant change of plans with our counterparts. It would also make them incur significant further costs. All their logistical plans are being based on the hypothesis that there will be no frontloading to the general public
column188: I repeat
column189: only to the general public. You mentioned the backing that in some quarters recently had risen to the idea of frontloading even for small amounts. You mentioned the name of Prime Minister Jospin and some others. May I counteract by also mentioning that at their informal ECOFIN in Versailles
column190: the Ministers of Finance of all Member States explicitly endorsed the decision not to frontload. That I do also regard as some political backing.    Mr. Abitbol (EDD/F):   Mr. President
column191: Mrs. Villiers asked about the cost of the changeover. You talked about 0.3 to 0.8 a percent of the GDP
column192: well that still amounts to an awful lot of money
column193: something like 40 million euros if I am not mistaken
column194: so who is actually going to pay that cost for the changeover?    Mr. Duisenberg:   In the end
column195: we all together.    Mrs. Peijs (EPP/ED/Nl):   If you listen to Mr Duisenberg
column196: it seems that we just started talking about frontloading yesterday
column197: but in fact there has almost been a 5 year war. We have been talking to you about this for about 5 years. There was a hearing and Mr Duisenberg of course you are not sitting in an ivory tower
column199: but you don't listen to us and you are not listening to what society is telling you. You are speaking
column200: but you have got two ears to listen to us as well. Well
column201: everyone who is sensible is actually talking about this problem of retail trade. Now
column202: have you ever tried to go to the supermarket on a Saturday
column203: think about the people at the cash tills
column204: and listen to us. In the Netherlands
column205: the president of the central bank said that he does not want to hear about this
column206: but I am actually thinking about the example of public transport. From the 1st of January
column207: public transport in the Netherlands is saying that we will only be able to pay with euros
column208: so why are you not taking on board the concerns of the private sector? Do listen to people that know what is going on. I know that you've got a video which talks about the problems in the cities
column209: so listen to us because it is going to be a real disaster. I am in the opposition
column210: Mr. Zalm finds himself in a very sticky situation because a few weeks later there are going to be the elections
column211: I would not worry about this but this is a real concern for everyone. We do not want the euro to get a bad reputation
column212: so do mull this one over. Could I please add some comments not about the frontloading but about the payment system? You've got a very clear role here and this was a clear task laid down for you in the Treaty
column213: where it said that you have to make sure there are flexible payment systems. Everybody is talking about what the banks have to do
column214: but there is a very clear task for you as well. In 1997 there was a Directive that was adopted and this Directive applies up to 50
column216: and it is my conviction that the statistical reporting requirements for the national accounts need to have a similar exception up to 50
column218: because otherwise we are never going to get the prices for small value cross-border credit transfers down in time. Apparently this is not going to be accepted because this will mean that the prices will actually go up.    Mr Duisenberg:   I can assure Mrs Peijs that I can listen and I do listen
column219: but I am also claiming the right to come together with my colleagues in the Governing Council to come to a judgement which may be different from what you plead for
column220: but I can assure you that we all listen carefully and we keep on doing that. Now as for your first specific question
column221: when was the last time I was in a supermarket on a busy Saturday
column222: the answer is 2 days ago. As to the reference that Mrs Peijs made to public transport in the Netherlands
column223: who have publicly announced that they will only accept euros as from the lst January and no longer guilders
column224: I share the question with Mrs Peijs
column227: I must confess. I am not condoning that situation either
column228: but as long as the guilder or any other national currency remains legal tender in the sense of the law
column229: I think the receiving party is obliged to accept the legal tender; I think it is for one month in the Netherlands. I am sure that you in the Netherlands will be able to solve that problem. Now finally
column230: I know that the plea to increase the reporting threshold from 12
column233: so as to further reduce the costs involved for banks
column234: is not new. The exemption threshold of 12
column235: 500 euro for balance of payments reporting was only agreed upon recently and it will take effect as from 1st January 2002. In addition
column236: statistical authorities have harmonised the list of economic codes for balance of payments reporting. This already should considerably reduce the administrative burden for the large majority of cross border retail payments without greatly diminishing the meaningfulness of balance of payments statistics. Naturally
column237: there is trade-off between a loss of statistical information for the authorities and low reporting costs for the banks. We have the feeling that the current trade-off seems to be well balanced and we do not want to re-open the issue at this stage. Let us first analyse the impact of the new threshold on both the quality of the statistics and the level of retail cross border prices and once we have a clearer picture
column238: that is also once we have some experience
column239: we might be in a position that we could reconsider the level of this threshold.    Mr Radwan (EPP/ED/UK):   Unfortunately my question earlier on was not answered. I do not share you optimism Mr Duisenberg that for cross-border payments it is going to be easier to reduce the costs. I would like to go back to the question of the regional banks in Germany
column240: which already today have clients that can make cross-border transfers because they have small limits of 0.80 euro. Who is going to be able to allow the clients in Germany to continue to make these transfers abroad from Germany? Are the regional banks going to be able to this? I would really like to know what the situation is. You said that the ECB has not got the possibility of intervening in matters of this type
column241: but I think that you could
column242: because you could co-ordinate things. I do not share your optimism when we hear about all the figures for the future
column243: and I am not sure that the ECB is really reacting properly. I think we saw what happened in Germany after the war
column244: the way in which the central bank in Germany intervened then to stabilise markets
column245: I think the ECB could do that in Europe now.    Mr Duisenberg:   I think we can try to persuade
column246: I think we can try to catalyse
column247: it is a matter of whether there is the competence for certain measures. In this instance
column249: it is certainly not with the ECB
column250: and for the rest of that matter I must confess Madam Chairman
column251: I am less familiar with the structure of the German banking system than with German supermarkets.    Chairman
column252: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D):   That was a convincing answer
column253: but I think that we will come back to this question again. Now the final speaker
column254: Mr Tannock.    Mr Tannock (EPP/ED/UK):   President Duisenberg
column255: can you re-confirm that in the unlikely event of a UK Labour Government victory
column256: and if the British people were to endorse the euro at the promised referendum in 2 years time
column258: as you seemed to suggest also applied to the candidate countries after joining the Union
column259: would have to spend two years in ERM II as suggested by the Treaties
column260: which in our case will take the joining date right up to the campaign period before the next general election of the next parliament
column261: and secondly what is it the exact mechanism to ensure that if we were to enter the euro
column262: that the right exchange rate will be achieved. We all remember the ERM débacle under John Major back in 1992. Currently the pound-deutsche mark rate of 3.22 is very high
column263: Jaguar motor cars suggest that 2.7 DM to the pound is the right for them. Can you spell out to us whether the UK Government has an absolute autonomous right to determine this rate or is it the ECB
column264: or is it the Council of Ministers who are the correct authority for this matter? As the British Government will clearly want a low rate to remain competitive but the 12 others will not want to be disadvantaged by cheap British exports. Can you clarify where the exact authority lies for determining a future UK pound-euro rate were we ever to join? Thank you.    Mr Duisenberg:   For the European Central Bank
column265: and I am speaking only for the European Central Bank
column266: if the request is there to enter into the Monetary Union
column267: what the European Central Bank has to do is to apply the convergence criteria as spelled out in the Maastricht Treaty
column268: to the UK as well as to any other entrant into Monetary Union. There will be equal treatment. So we will write a convergence report based on the criteria as laid down in the Treaty. Subsequently
column269: I want to emphasise that whatever convergence report the ECB may write
column270: it is not the ECB who decides upon eventual membership of the UK or any other country. That is a purely political decision
column271: and that is a decision which ultimately has to be taken by the Heads of State and Prime Ministers in the European Council
column272: and not the ECB. As material to underpin the decision
column273: they will have amongst others the convergence report of the ECB in which
column274: in so far as membership of the European Exchange Rate Mechanism is concerned
column275: the ECB can do no other thing than state
column277: that it appears that in the period between X and Y the United Kingdom has been a member or has not been a member of the Exchange Rate Mechanism without devaluing its currency. That is a statement of fact. To what extent the political authorities will subsequently use that fact to say either 'yes' or 'no'
column278: I have no idea.    Mr Tannock (EPP/ED/UK):    That doesn't actually answer my question
column279: Mr President. Who actually determines the exchange rate - the Council of Ministers or the UK government?    Mr Duisenberg:   The UK Government in the run up to membership
column280: if they were to want it
column281: will itself form an idea of what the appropriate exchange rate for the UK economy is likely to be. They will
column283: formulate their economic and financial policies
column285: in such a way that the pound sterling will approach the rate which is likely to be the desired rate for the UK economy and which could be sustainable for eternity
column286: once they became a member.    Mr Karas (EPP/ED/D):   I just wanted to ask one question
column287: more and more often the different policies between the FED and the ECB are being given as a reason for the different economic developments in America and in the European Union. This is superficial
column288: so I am asking you really because even you have a number of answers
column289: you have actually pointed out the different situation in these two groups of countries and used this as your argument between the USA and the European Union. So do you think that the different foundations of the European Union are a reason for the weaknesses in the ECB or in the European Union
column290: or do you think that there should be a reform of the Treaties to strengthen your position?    Mr Duisenberg:   From me you will hear no urge to reform the Treaties. I work with the Treaties as they stand
column291: as they have been ratified by all the Parliaments in Europe
column292: that is our constitution for the ECB. That Treaty gives us the single mandate
column293: the primary mandate of maintaining price stability
column294: and we take our decisions based exclusively on an analysis of euro area wide developments
column295: and not in a comparison with whatever national central bank elsewhere in the world
column298: my final question looks at the instability and volatility of the financial markets and your monetary policy. If we look at the international financial markets we can see that they are moving further away from the goods and services market
column299: and I wonder whether the financial policy can really influence growth and employment
column300: or is the dominance of the financial markets really what sets the tone? I think we should also say that the American interest rate policy seems to look more at the assets market than the growth and employment levels in the country
column301: so is there a danger in that for monetary policy
column302: and should we perhaps rethink the store that we put by monetary policy?    Mr Duisenberg:   It is true Madam Chairman
column303: that it is simply a fact of life that developments on financial markets are increasingly having an impact on exchange rate development
column304: much more than was the case say
column305: 20 or 30 years ago. But we have to take that in our stride
column307: and that is how their impact develops. As far as assets prices are concerned
column308: I can only comment on what we do with it
column310: and not on what other monetary authorities do with them or the degree to which they are influenced by them. For us
column313: are one of the range of indicators we take into account under our second pillar of the monetary policy strategy. Only one
column315: but there are many more that we look at simultaneously.    Chairman
column317: let me thank you most sincerely for today's monetary dialogue
column318: and we wish the European Central Bank not only to have the wherewithal to fulfil its monetary policy
column319: but we also wish you good luck on this path
column320: and we are looking forward to our debate on the annual report from the European Central Bank. Thank you very much.
