column4: Keynote address given by Mr. Tommaso Padoa-Schioppa during the International Payment Systems Week 2001 London

column3: Europa y la nueva economía
column4: Eugenio Domingo Solans Miembro del Consejo de Gobierno y del Comité Ejecutivo del Banco Central Europeo Conferencia inaugural del curso "Comunicación y empresa en la era digital"

column3: First experiences with the euro
La inflación
the EURO. OUR money
column4: Speech by Dr. Willem F. Duisenberg

column3: Hearing before the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament
column6: and that mainly is small and medium-sized businesses
column7: to sooner rather than later effectuate the changeover process in their administration. On the whole
column8: I have no complaints on the role that banks are playing in this changeover process.    Chairman
column9: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Thank you. Mr Lipietz.    Mr Lipietz (Verts/ALE/F)    Mr Duisenberg
column10: if I have understood correctly you think the potential growth rate for Europe is going to remain at 2.5 for a period of time and the real growth rate will until the end of 2002 and beyond be 3%. In order words
column11: today you are announcing sustainable high interest rate policies and high financial yields. And of course this is in line with your original statement where you said that among the factors that contribute to prices - there are many - but you are just talking about stability for wages. Why are you insisting on stability only for wages and not for the other components that influence prices
column12: such as profits and financial yields? Today we have the first numbers for 2000. It would appear that in France
column13: shareholder profits and the like have increased far more than wages. Do you think that this way of sharing out benefits and profits is favourable and fair for Europe?    Mr Duisenberg    I am not only talking about wages. I am talking to both social partners
column14: employers and unions. I am talking to governments when I talk about budget deficits. So they receive advice as well. I am talking about achieving price stability - that is effectively saying to entrepreneurs "do not increase your profits by increasing your prices". So there is a message. I do not think in any way that my advice is lopsided to any part of society.    Chairman
column15: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Thank you. Mr Tannock.    Mr Tannock    Madame President
column17: thank you. I'm extremely worried about the statement from Mr Noble
column18: the new American head of Interpol
column20: France. He has expressed formal concern that Europol
column21: which I understand is charged with overseeing the co-operation and co-ordination of measures by national police forces against counterfeiting of the Euro
column22: has no formal right or duty to disclose information or work with Interpol. Interpol will have to deal with euros being forged outside of the European Union
column23: which in many ways is the most likely place for this to event take place because of ridiculously strict data protection laws. This is in my opinion severely and gravely remiss. What will the Union and the European Central Bank do to redress this obvious breach of security? Otherwise
column24: not only might we see notes being hijacked in transit to the national central banks
column25: but also counterfeiters flourishing in third world countries
column26: flooding euroland with absurdly high denomination bills
column27: such as 300 euro denomination bills
column28: which perhaps should be withdrawn anyway. This would cause further lack of confidence and weakening of the currency
column29: as well as damage to euroland's economy
column30: and therefore also
column32: to the UK's trade patterns and its own economy. What will be done about that Mr President?    Mr Duisenberg    I was not aware of that problem
column33: Madam President. I'm only aware of some very useful contacts the ECB has with both Europol and Interpol and with the European Commission. On the issue of potential counterfeiting
column34: we have had no complaints about co-operation on whatever side of the balance sheet.    Chairman
column36: Mr Huhne.    Mr Huhne (ELDR/UK)    Thank you very much President. I wonder if I could ask you to speculate on some rather longer term issues within the euro area. Obviously the introduction of the single currency has been widely expected to lead to increased competitive pressure downwards on prices
column37: and therefore perhaps some change in the normal relationship between price expectations and inflation and domestic demand growth. I wonder if you can discuss if there is any evidence yet of that sort of emerging competitive pressure actually happening. Secondly
column38: the other aspect is the easing of capital flows within the euro area. I noticed that last year Portugal had a current account deficit on the old terms of 10% of GDP. Is there any reason why that should be a source of worry
column39: or is this the normal development one should expect within a monetary union?    Mr Duisenberg    As to the last question
column40: I think it is normal. One should expect it within a monetary union such as the euro area
column41: and one can measure it. For example in the United States
column42: there are also huge differences in the current account deficit
column43: in other words in the capital flows from one part of the country to the other. The same is happening in Europe
column44: and that is in itself normal. I would speculate that a country like Portugal
column45: given the state of its development in relation to the rest of the euro area
column46: is almost entitled to have a current account deficit. It should have one.    Mr Huhne (ELDR/UK)    And the first part of the question on inflation?    Mr Duisenberg    Yes. On that we think that we have some signs
column47: although it is too early to judge
column49: by increasing the transparency across the euro area
column50: has contributed to keeping inflation down. It is a factor which does increase competition across Europe
column51: and in that way it contributes to keeping inflation within permitted limits. But it is too early to come to a more specific judgement for this young currency. Let me say that we think we see some signs that it is indeed happening.    Chairman
column52: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Thank you. Mr Herzog.    Mr Herzog (GUE-NGL/F)    I'm accepting your assumption for growth for the next two years
column53: and I would like to ask you whether you're worried about expenditure structures for this growth rate you predict and the way the money is spent. What about that? You've expressed concern about public debt. You want to see a decrease. But you have also said that private debt is currently increasing. Is there not then a risk that private debt leads to a lot of speculation and thereby growing inflation? Take telecommunications
column54: is what is happening in the telecommunications sector of little importance to you
column55: or are you going to be able to act? Because this is the kind of problem that can't be solved simply by tweaking the interest rates.    Mr Duisenberg    The particular composition of national expenditure over consumption and investment
column56: or public consumption and public investment
column57: is a matter which
column58: I am afraid to say falls outside the competence of the Central Bank
column59: and the Central Bank cannot influence that. We can say something about it if we think that certain movements point in the wrong direction We can give warnings
column61: the problem of the ageing of the population brings with it costs that have to be borne
column62: whether you like it or not'. Let me speak only from my experience. In the Netherlands it has once been calculated that 15 years from now
column63: the extra costs of the phenomenon of an ageing population through increased pension payments and the rising costs of health care simply because an older man or woman has to go to the doctor more often than a younger person
column64: would be equivalent to 5 percent of GDP. That has to be borne at that time by someone
column65: and we think it is very likely that it is the government that has to bear the bulk of those costs. Well
column66: if you see that coming
column67: then it is very wise to already create the room in your budget to be able to bear those costs at the future date. One example of that is
column68: I'm again speaking about the Netherlands
column69: the Dutch government pays in interest payments on the public debt roughly the equivalent of 5% of GDP. So
column70: if you were to eliminate the public debt in time
column71: you would already have created the room that is required to bear the burden of the ageing of the population. On private debt and the example of telecommunications
column72: that is a matter for the banks to judge. I do admit that there have been some auctions of licences in the telecommunications sphere that - well to put it prudently - were rather extraordinary. And I also see a development in that sector because of these enormous debts that have been built up that point in the direction of a great deal of consolidation and concentration. But those developments do not by themselves endanger the ECB in its endeavours to fulfil its mandate.    Chairman
column74: Mrs Villers.    Mrs Villiers (EPP-ED/UK)    I'd like to turn very briefly to one of the points that Mr Abitbol made on the euro information campaign. I hope that you won't emulate the French government which published a rather misleading leaflet which actually said that transaction costs for travellers would be completely eliminated with the launch of the euro. As you and this committee know
column75: that's not the case. I'd like to ask you if you have an estimate within the ECB as to the launch cost of the euro to those participating in it - the cost to business and the cost to government
column76: regardless of how you divide it between government and business? It would be interesting to know if you have a figure as to how much the logistics will actually cost. And lastly
column77: to return to a subject which I raised with you before on Ireland and tax. It's always going to be the case
column79: that smaller economies on the periphery of the euro zone won't necessarily have an interest rate which suits their economy. Isn't it important for them to retain a lot of flexibility over their fiscal strategy in order to offset the possible damaging effects of having the wrong interest rate for their particular circumstances?    Mr Duisenberg    I don't have an estimate of the total costs of the transition to the euro notes and coins. I know that there are some estimates in some countries. We don't have an overall estimate. It's something that's going to happen
column80: and the basic principle is that every single sector will have to bear the burden of its own costs
column81: and every single sector will also gain the fruits and have the benefits of the introduction of the single currency. On Ireland
column82: I don't know whether it is necessarily true that it is for small countries only that the single monetary policy may not always yield the results that would be the most appropriate for that single area. That can happen to any economy. I do think that having a single monetary policy and no regional differences is simply not possible. Having a single monetary policy does place an extra burden on other areas
column84: on wages
column85: to show the necessary flexibility in order to achieve goals that in the past were
column87: also contributed to by monetary policy. So
column89: but what is also necessary is that if you have certain rules of the game for these other policies in a European context
column90: that you adhere to these rules of the game.    Mrs Villiers (EPP-ED/UK)    A short supplementary - Mr Duisenberg
column91: what do you think of the Nobel Prize winning economist
column93: that the criticism of Ireland had nothing to do with macro economic policy and everything to do with the agenda to harmonise taxes across the European Union?    Mr Duisenberg    Well I disagree with him whether he has won a Nobel Prize or not.    Chairman
column94: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Thank you. Mrs Beres.    Mrs Beres (PES/F)    Now clearly in all the capital cities of euroland
column95: your optimism about the possibility for the euro zone to maintain its level of growth is not necessarily shared
column96: and one wonders how the Central Bank understands its twin role. That is essentially the question that the chairman of the committee asked you
column97: and obviously it has an effect on individual countries of the euro zone. The Ecofin Council recently adopted a decision which at least theoretically means co-ordinating economic policies
column98: and that is of course something one can only support as it is only applying measures outlined in the Treaty. However
column99: this decision is based on a definition of what is a tolerable inflation rate as set by the Central Bank. Doesn't that mean that we have to reopen the debate on defining the inflation rate which is to be targeted by the Central Bank? My second question relates on how the governing board going to be organised following enlargement. The central bank is a young institution so we didn't really ask this before. Nice has been and gone
column100: it will be ratified. The way things have gone for the Commission following on from Nice doesn't make us terribly optimistic. One wonders if the same sort of solution might be used for you as the Commission. Would you accept a possibility of some kind of rotation in the same way as for the European Commission?    Mr Duisenberg    First question - is there a necessity to redefine the concept of price stability - I wouldn't think so. The Treaty does not define price stability
column101: it only says that the ECB should ensure that price stability prevails
column102: but it has not defined what is to be understood by price stability. We did that ourselves you might say. We said we regard price stability as a situation where the rate of increase of prices is below 2%. Thereby taking into account that there will always be a measurement bias in the price indexes which we do not know precisely. We did want to make clear that we are as opposed to deflation as we are to inflation. By talking about the rate of increase
column103: we did want to emphasise that we did want to have the movement in prices always to be positive
column104: and not negative. I don't think there is a need to redefine price stability. The ECB has three decision-making bodies - the executive board
column105: the governing council and the general council. For the first and last
column106: there is no need to change anything in the composition
column107: however big the euro area might become. The governing council currently consists of eighteen members who all sit there in a personal capacity. They do not represent their countries
column108: they are forbidden to seek or accept instructions from any private or public body. They have to be completely independent and that independence has to be respected by the European Community. For the governing council there might be a problem
column109: that it could become too unwieldy to take effectively decisions were it to consist of say
column111: or it might even reach 30 members in the longer but foreseeable future. We are currently thinking about various models which could be used. You could use rotation
column112: which is the most likely outcome
column113: but then immediately the question arises - would it be for any country acceptable not to take part in the decision making on monetary policy for some time? Or do you treat countries differently? These are questions which are very sensitive
column114: but still they are sensible questions to ask. So we are thinking about that. I think that the rotation model
column115: but now I am speculating
column116: will be the most likely outcome of that discussion. Another model would be for example to form constituencies to group countries together
column117: but then you would violate the principle of total independence of the individual participants
column118: because a representative of a constituency would have to defend the interests of his constituency in the governing council. That would run counter to the total personal independence as it is presently formulated and experienced. Fortunately
column119: we still have some time to go before we come to a decision
column120: or until the heads of state come to a decision on this.    Chairman
column121: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Mr Purvis.    Mr Purvis (EPP-ED/UK)    Mr Duisenberg
column122: in your introductory statement you mentioned the continuing need for structural reform
column123: including removing barriers to investment in the new technologies. As you know
column124: the Lisbon summit committed the Member States to making the European Union the most dynamic and competitive knowledge-based economy in the world. Are you satisfied that the structure of Europe's capital markets
column125: its stock exchanges
column128: is adequate or at least heading in the right direction of being adequate and competitive with other economies within an acceptable timeframe? Or would you have some suggestions for the European Council about to meet in Stockholm
column129: which is to be concerned with following up Lisbon
column130: as to where it should place its priorities in this area?    Mr Duisenberg    We see capital markets developing. We see that it is making progress but it goes very slowly
column131: because in most cases it also requires changes in national legislation on the form of contracts which are being traded on the capital markets. That is by necessity
column133: a cumbersome and slowly-developing process. We do what we can by having contacts with the players
column134: that includes the stock exchanges to promote the process of coming to one deep and liquid capital market in the euro area. But actively participating in that is something that we cannot do. But we give it as much peer pressure as we possibly can. As for the upcoming summit in Stockholm in June
column135: at the moment I am not aware that we have any particular subject that we would ask to be placed on their agenda.    Mr Purvis (EPP-ED/UK)    Would it be worth your while
column136: because they are going to be discussing the follow up to Lisbon
column137: to get the point across to them that it is a high priority? Also
column138: is the downturn in the American stock exchanges
column140: is that going to be detrimental to peoples' attitudes in Europe to investing in equities and so forth?    Mr Duisenberg    I shall try my best to answer that question
column141: because thinking about it
column142: it would be sheer speculation if I did so. I do believe that the developments of the stock exchanges
column143: both in the Nasdaq and in the broader Dow Jones
column144: are having some impact on the appetite in Europe to invest in equities. Looking at the development of the exchanges in Europe you can see that it reflects
column145: but only to a limited extent
column146: what is happening elsewhere. But on the macro economic impact one has to realise that a huge difference between the euro area and the United States is that European enterprises to a much lesser extent than in the US are dependent on equity financing. On top of that
column147: the distribution of equity
column149: is very much smaller in Europe than in the US. So the macro economic impact of movements in the stock exchanges is much more limited indeed than in the United States.    Chairman
column150: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Thank you. Mr Ettl.    Mr Ettl (PES/D)    President
column151: let me try once again to link price stability and full employment. I do understand your ambition to combat inflation
column152: but I'm more concerned at the moment about the point of view of the employees and the possible cooling down of the economy
column153: and the policy of the ECB that's linked to that. And if I put that in the context of European price developments and core inflation
column154: and if I take out external factors
column155: then we're still looking at ECB growth rates of 1.8 - 2.8 or 2.2 and 3.8% for 2002. It seems here that real interest rates are being kept above European growth potential. And in the short term
column156: that would curb investments in Europe to a massive extent. So the ECB response to this seems unsatisfactory. Do we really have to lag behind the US
column157: new economy and old economy? Could we not come up with something more original
column158: something that would not curb growth to such an extent?    Mr Duisenberg    Allow me to remark
column159: Madam chairman
column160: that interest rates in Europe are lower than in the US. Interest rates are lower
column161: and growth is now finally higher in Europe than in the US. Monetary conditions cannot by any means be regarded as a hindrance to further growth of investment and output in general. Monetary policy is not hindering economic growth. We do expect economic growth
column162: I repeat
column163: to be close to 3% both this year and next
column164: and I added we see no reason why it should be different even in the year thereafter. Therefore
column165: although I do understand the concerns that you have about employment
column166: I do agree that the process of getting unemployment down is very slow indeed
column167: there's nothing monetary policy can do to change the speed of that process. We have to remind ourselves
column169: that when the euro started
column170: the unemployment figure for the euro area as a whole was over 10%
column172: and we expect that within the next year and a half
column173: the unemployment figure will begin with a 7. The movement is continuing
column174: admittedly very slowly
column175: but there is nothing that monetary policy can do to accelerate that.    Chairman
column176: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Mr Langen.    Mr Langen (EPP-ED/D)    Thank you very much chairman. I think that the ECB has done very good work despite adverse circumstances. You said the rate of inflation
column177: stable growth rates have a good impact on the labour market
column178: but as Mrs Kauppi has said
column179: the confidence of our citizens is falling
column180: and that causes me great misgivings in particular with regard to the process of transition to the euro. Several mentions have been made of counterfeiting
column181: I think in this transitional phase everything that can be done should be done
column182: not just under national responsibility
column183: so that national agreements or government agreements can be reached also with the national banks of Eastern European countries
column184: as well as with the ECB
column185: so as to ensure that we prevent as far as possible counterfeit notes and coins coming into circulation. I know how sensitive this area is. Do you think that enough has been done about this in the banking sector
column186: or will further measures be necessary? Because this could become an issue of confidence amongst our citizens. On the stability and growth pact
column187: Ireland got a rather nasty letter about this
column188: and there is also the point about the expected inflation rate in Ireland and its potential impact. Is Ireland being made an example of as a small state
column189: or was it really necessary to send them this letter.    Mr Duisenberg    On counterfeiting
column190: it is my firm conviction that enough has been done and that we are doing enough on all sides
column191: both as the Central Bank and the producers of the bank notes. So the public should be convinced that they will have in a few months time the most sophisticated and counterfeit-proof money in their pockets which is imaginable. There is always the fight
column193: between the speed with which producers can produce even safer banknotes and the counterfeiters' ability to copy them. However
column194: I think the European public will have the most sophisticated and well-protected banknotes in the world. Ireland has been reprimanded by the Council of Ministers
column195: I'm keen to say
column196: and not by the ECB as is sometimes thought in Ireland. It is not for being a small country. I believe first and foremost that if Ireland had not been reprimanded
column197: that it would have created a pretext in the future not to reprimand potential
column199: sinners as well. Therefore I do believe that this a precedent which is good rather than bad.    Chairman
column200: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Mrs Torres Marques.    Mrs Torres Marques (PES/P)    Mr Duisenberg
column201: I'd like to talk about a few practical issues relative to the euro. In the past we discussed the question of the euro having a different value from country to country and the question of banking transfer costs. We were told that competition would help the banks solve this problem. That hasn't happened. For example
column202: if you go into a bank here in the European Parliament it pays MEPs with 15 different cheque books. I'm Portuguese
column203: sometimes I'm given a Portuguese cheque
column206: all in euros. But we all know that costs are different. This much is clear from my experience. I wonder if in 2002 when our single currency will be in existence as such
column207: we will continue to need 15 different cheque books
column208: or will there be completely free bank transfers within the euro zone?    Mr Duisenberg    We do believe that progress is being made
column209: also in the banking sector
column210: but also there it is rather slow. We closely monitor the practices in particular
column211: as far as cross-border retail transactions are concerned
column212: and as you know we have recommended that the banks should strive towards a payments system which makes cross-border retail payments as easy as domestic retail payments within the borders of any single country. The banks have assured us that they are endeavouring to reach that stage by 1 January 2002. Whether they make it or not I don't know
column213: but it is something we are concerned about. We do believe that progress is being made.    Chairman
column214: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Mr Karas.    Mr Karas (EPP-ED/A)    First of all I'd like to welcome the fact that the ECB council has made the decision as regards what will happen in the non-euro countries. One questions is open which we are faced with all the time - is there a possibility that notes will be distributed before the end of the year
column215: for example on 15 December - this is the wish of the economic affairs committees of the national parliaments. The Ecofin council continually says to us "we could do that if the ECB were to give the green light". Is there a possibility to distribute notes therefore in advance? Secondly
column216: we've spoken about growth a lot. You've told us about that. A few weeks ago there was a hearing with representatives from five economic research institutes. In this hearing there was a reason why the growth forecast in Europe had been reduced
column217: which was the economic situation in the US and the related strengthening of the external valuing of the euro. That's slightly in conflict with the explanation that you've given i.e. the independence of this development for our situation
column218: so how do you see this conflict? Third point
column219: I also think that the ECB at the moment is conducting a most compact information campaign. I have two questions in terms of policy. In the campaign of the ECB
column220: is the success of the euro up to the present day important and do you think that the national parliaments and the public could be confronted with the success of the euro to-date?    Mr Duisenberg    There is the possibility inside the euro area to make the banknotes available to banks
column221: from 1 September. The same applies to certain professional clients of the banks
column223: on the same date provided they can assure the authorities that they will not distribute the banknotes to the public. Outside the euro area
column224: this possibility is being created 3 months later
column225: as from 1 December. There should be no uncertainty about that. On the different outcomes for the forecast exercises of various institutions
column226: I cannot comment on any particular institution. I could comment on another international organisation
column228: and its forecasts for economic growth for the euro area are almost precisely identical to our internal assessment. They vary from one year to the other by no more than 1 decimal point. They are virtually identical
column229: and that of course gives me great satisfaction. On the balance of the euro so far
column230: yes I believe that it is very positive. When we make a total account we see that the introduction went as smoothly as one could wish. The money market developed into one euro area wide money market in a matter of three days. The payments systems after about three weeks functioned flawlessly
column231: and I now refer in particular to the payments system that has been developed by the ECB under the name TARGET. I believe its daily turnover is the largest in the world. In the United States
column232: there are two payments systems functioning and the sum of those two would be larger than the European one
column233: but singly TARGET is probably the largest payments system in the world. But the most important success in my mind of the euro is that the participating countries - now 12 - have enjoyed for two years for roughly four fifths of their "old" foreign trade
column235: namely no exchange rate fluctuations or exchange rate risks. That is of course not something the public at large realises everyday
column238: the explosion of oil prices in the course of last year has not caused any ripples in the European pond thanks to the fact we have eliminated exchange rate risk
column239: is to my mind the greatest benefit because it creates a high degree of stability for the European citizens. That is an accomplishment of the euro.    Chairman
column240: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Mr Goebbels.    Mr Goebbels (PES/L)    Mr Duisenberg
column241: according to a European Commission document
column242: cash machines in the EU can't be reprogrammed to distribute certain euro notes
column243: of 5 and 10 euro. Won't this put the small scale retail trade in a very difficult situation
column244: because as of the 1st of January they will be confronted by large denomination notes but they won't be able to give change to customers? So would you be able to frontload the small retail trade
column246: so as to avoid that kind of situation?    Mr Duisenberg    I am not a technician
column247: but I am not aware that the ATMs would not be able to handle small denomination notes. We have provided the vendors of cash machines with a facility already nearly a year ago to test their machines on the real banknotes. They are the only ones who handled the banknotes. We have used that extensively. They have used that facility extensively and currently it is being spread. First we did it in one place
column249: now we are preparing to do it across Europe and so far our experience has not been that they could not handle the smaller denominations. It even is the case in some countries for example that banks intend to supply their automatic teller machines with very small denominations in the beginning
column250: the 5 euro and the 10 euro notes
column251: so as to spread these notes as quickly as possible across the public at large
column252: and we have been assured that these machines work.    Mr Goebbels (PES/L)    Please check that information because I saw it in a document from the European Commission.    Mr Duisenberg    I will.    Chairman
column253: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Mr Marinos.    Mr Marinos (EPP-ED/Gr)    Before I ask a question
column254: I'd like to thank President Duisenberg because he comes to our committees very regularly and listens to our questions very patiently and gives us detailed answers
column255: and mixed with humour which makes the whole thing a pleasure. I'm a representative of the last Member State to join the euro. I'd like to say something about Greece. I'm not sure if you know
column256: if the President of the Greek central bank has informed you of some worrying developments
column257: for example there is a doubling of the trade deficit
column258: and there is a collapse of the stock exchange in Athens. There have been enormous losses and people are looking for guilty parties. Therefore there is a decrease in state incomes because of the collapse in the stock market
column259: but also because companies are seeing reduced earnings according to nominal conversions. The structural reforms were not necessarily carried out in the manner we were told by the Central Bank
column260: so what do you say about all these events? Have you got any comments or advice perhaps? And what would you recommend to us to do about our problems? Perhaps you could speak about other problems too
column261: such as the insurance area or public administration. And that leads me into a second question. What about the economic crisis in Turkey? Will that have after-effects for the European Union?    Mr Duisenberg    On the first question regarding Greece
column262: I can assure you that I have listened carefully. I have also listened carefully to my colleague Lucas Papademos when I met him three days ago. I can assure you that he has not mentioned in that conversation those problems that you set out. Had he done so
column263: I would still not comment on any individual Member State in this context in this room. If I had advice I would give it to him. On Turkey
column264: our impression is that the after-effects of the financial crisis some weeks ago in Turkey that made the Turkish currency depreciate in a matter of days by about 30%
column265: has had and will have virtually no effects on the euro area economy. There may have been some fallout to Latin American economies temporarily
column266: which is over. We carefully checked what is the exposure of the euro area private banks to Turkey and we found that although it is not insignificant
column267: it is insignificant in relation to the balance sheet total of the credit institutions concerned. So we do not fear any contagion or spill-over effects from the Turkish economic developments to the euro area.    Chairman
column268: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    We have come to the end of our first monetary dialogue of 2001
column269: and I think once again it has become clear how important transparency is. Despite the criticism of the information policy of the ECB
column270: this monetary dialogue should be seen as a part
column271: an element which can lead to clarity about the backgrounds to monetary policy. We won't tire of seeking the arguments for monetary policy decisions. We won't tire of asking for the publishing of minutes in the long term
column272: and we'll try to conduct this monetary dialogue and give it its full weight
column273: because monetary policy is more and more important for the confidence of the public and markets
column274: especially when you look at the knock on effects that can result from stock market collapses in terms of jobs and peoples' plans for the future. Therefore it is good that the ECB is entering into economic co-operation and co-ordination
column275: even if it doesn't have any formal position as such in this area
column276: but it will be important that your policy can be reckoned with and we can understand it. Thank you Mr Duisenberg
column277: and we wish you every success with the concrete preparation work for the introduction of the euro notes and coins. Although we haven't so far experienced a successful changeover in 1999 or in 2000
column278: the changeover in 2002 will be extremely important because the introduction of notes and coins is a very important expression of monetary union in real life. Thank you very much.

column3: The euro and the Eurosystem -  some issues of interest for the Swedish public
column4: Speech delivered by Eugenio Domingo Solans

column6: an explanation for the relative exchange rate development that we have seen ever since. However
column7: I do say 'in part'. It is very difficult to explain the remaining part
column8: even though I do not know how big that remaining part is. We do believe that markets have overshot in a direction
column9: which we don't like. We also do firmly believe that that overshooting will be reversed at some point. That is at least our expectation
column10: not the projection. That is the basic reason why we continue to say
column11: although you may by now almost consider it a platitude that the euro has a strong potential to appreciate. That is our belief and we will continue to believe it. It does
column12: as you indicate
column13: underline how necessary it is to have as correct a forecast as we can possibly have
column14: but we live in a world which is full of uncertainties. That is one of the basic reasons why in our projections to be published
column15: we use ranges rather than point estimates for the future: that is to reflect the uncertainties with which we are inevitably faced. Publishing point estimates would
column17: give a false impression that we know more than we do actually know
column18: but it is a disadvantage that we have to accept.    Mr Marinos (EPP/ED/Gr)    Thank you very much Chairman. Mr Duisenberg. Let me read something out: "Mr Massimo Ponsellini said at the weekend
column19: the European Union's planned enlargement towards Central and Eastern Europe could further damage the struggling euro. The euro will weaken further when these countries join the European Union. " That would therefore lead to a further weakening and I have two questions. How would you react to that text
column20: and has the ECB looked at the potential effects of the enlargement of the European Union in terms of currency stability and the exchange rate in particular?    Mr Duisenberg    There are 12 accession countries currently recognised as negotiating partners to enter into the European Union. The negotiations will take some time to come. That is about entry into membership of the European Union. The second step after that will be for these countries to become a member of the exchange rate mechanism. The third step is that ultimately - I'm talking about a process many years from now - when they have complied with all the Maastricht criteria on a sustainable basis
column21: these countries will come into a position where they can also adopt the euro as their currency
column22: so that they can become a member of the monetary union in addition to being a member of the European Union. In the meantime
column23: these countries are making great efforts to transform themselves into market-oriented economies and let me say
column24: from what I already now see
column25: that on average these efforts result in remarkable progress in catching up with the rest or the core of Europe. They are expected to have
column26: on average
column27: over the next couple of years higher growth rates than the euro area. That is how the 'catching up' process is proceeding. Talking about a time which is still considerably some way off from today or even from the moment of entry into membership of the European Union
column28: we are talking about entirely different economies which will then be fully fledged partners in the European Union
column29: also in the sense of monetary union. Therefore
column30: I disagree when it is said that the accession of those countries in the future
column31: when they are different economies would pose any danger to the stability or the strength of the euro. We have examples in the present also. As from 1 January 2001
column32: we will have Greece as the twelfth partner in monetary union
column33: coming in later than the others for good reasons but in the meantime having shown an economic
column34: fiscal and political performance which is laudable and to be greatly appreciated and which
column35: in no way endangers the euro or its strength or stability. Here also
column36: we have an economy
column37: which has managed to catch up with the rest of Europe
column38: in both a qualitatively and quantitatively respectable way.    Mr Agag Longo (EPP/ED/E)    Thank you very much. Mr Duisenberg. The initial evaluation by Mr Goebbels and Mr Von Wogau - the positive evaluation of the management of the European Central Bank is something that I would endorse
column39: in particular in terms of price stability. Alongside that global positive evaluation
column40: I do have one or two comments I would like to make. In the course of the meetings we have had together
column41: you have put emphasis on two things. Firstly
column42: the value of the euro does not reflect properly the fundamentals of the economies that make it up and secondly
column43: the process of internationalisation of a currency is a gradual one. In the case of the euro
column44: it depends on the health and credibility of the policies followed by the countries in the euro zone and therefore patience is the watchword. We agreed that patience was required
column45: but there is one question where it seems to be the ECB that has failed to show patience. I'm talking in particular about the interventions that we have seen recently - unilateral interventions carried out by the ECB have been interpreted by markets as a sign of concern or even desperation on the part of the European Central Bank
column46: trying to break the lack of sensitivity in the market. Experts talk about the risk
column47: whereby if the market anticipates the interventions by the Central Bank
column48: that would seriously undermine the credibility of the Bank itself. So I have three questions in this regard: first of all
column50: do you think that the transient and limited effect of these interventions could really help this price stability in the longer term - if that is the purpose of the European Central Bank? Don't you think the absence of a response to the breaking of the inflation ceiling could lead to a loss of credibility in the ECB and ambiguity over what objectives you are following? And finally
column52: which are still low in my view
column53: don't you think that's more a question of the fear of the impact it would have on German and French economies
column54: and don't you think that political will of the governments to actually introduce the necessary reforms is being damaged by this? Thank you very much.    Mr Duisenberg    To demonstrate that I have learned my lesson about speaking about interventions
column57: it is far too early to be able to make a judgement about the effect of the series of interventions that we have had. I know that media are sometimes inclined to already come with their final judgement the day after the interventions have taken place. We strongly believe that one needs more time. If I may
column61: of a few years ago. We have had also in 1995
column62: a series of interventions. There were in fact several rounds of interventions during the year 1995. They were undertaken respectively by the G2 - that is United States and Germany - by the G3 - that is United States
column63: Germany and Japan - by the G10
column64: by an even larger group of central banks
column65: and unilaterally. They were all aspects of an episode where it was thought necessary to intervene. Therefore it is too early to judge the effect of the recent interventions. I do want to underline that we do not have an exchange target. We have a price stability objective so interventions are not supposed to achieve a certain exchange rate. They are mainly used so as to break a prevailing thinking pattern
column66: or philosophy
column67: prevalent in markets those market participants only have a one-way risk or a one-way street
column68: which they can safely walk on. No
column70: a two-way risk and that is what we hope to achieve to instil that feeling on markets without having the aim of reaching a particular exchange rate. So I don't believe in judging the impact of interventions immediately
column71: but rather some time after they have worked their effects through
column72: and that may be a considerable period of time. I witnessed the experience of 1995 and I also witnessed other experiences last year and I think you would be inclined to come to a different judgement if you put them in the right perspective
column73: namely what can and is being achieved by interventions and taking into account that you need some time to let it sink in.    Chairman
column74: Mrs Randzio-Plath (PES/D)    Thank you Mr President. I would like to ask whether perhaps there is some change in monetary policy
column75: when I hear you saying that you are sticking to your definition of price stability. If you take the current inflation rate and simultaneously look at what you have said today
column76: that external factors ought to be left aside in terms of determining an assessment of inflation
column77: does that not mean that the ECB
column78: as two members of the Governing Council have already suggested
column79: should come to a core inflation rate? Is that intentional or is that a substitute definition because of the impact of oil price changes on the inflation rate? We have also heard assertions that the euro
column81: was affected by that ECB intervention which was intended to keep the inflation rate down?    Mr Duisenberg    Why the ECB intervened
column82: I just explained Madam Chairman
column83: but I think it is of the greatest importance to emphasise that there is no change in our monetary policy strategy
column84: nor in the aim that we try to achieve with our monetary policy: that is containing overall
column85: or some would call it headline
column87: inflation. There have been certain misinterpretations in the past
column89: of our aim in putting more emphasis on only part of inflation
column90: namely to explain that one should not underrate the significance of
column92: temporary or one-off changes in certain variables
column93: such as oil prices or the exchange rate and that one should abstain from taking them into account. No! At every press conference I give after a Governing Council meeting
column94: I do explain to the audience - that is basically the public at large - that inflation does this and that
column95: but you have to take into account that the underlying causes for inflation doing this and that
column98: such as the oil price or the development
column100: of the very volatile element of unprocessed food. That is not to say that we ignore those factors
column101: it is to say that they are only temporary or very volatile anyway. We should not forget that the future tendency for inflation is what counts most
column102: because of the lag in the monetary transmission mechanism
column103: which can be put at between approximately one-and-a half and two years. We have to have a forward-looking assessment of the likely price development. We expect
column105: for example the oil prices remain where they are
column106: then over time the effect of the increase in the past will disappear from the impact it has on the actual inflation figures. Then we will be back
column108: so ceteris paribus we will be back at our measurement of headline inflation without disturbing short-term factors such as I just mentioned. But again
column110: there is no change in neither the aim we intend to achieve
column111: nor the strategy with which we intend to achieve our ultimate aim and our ultimate responsibility where we ultimately will be judged on
column112: and held accountable for by the public
column115: Christa Randzio-Plath MEP (PES/D)    Thank you. Just a further point
column116: the oil crisis was the first external shock for the euro zone. Do you believe that the existence of the euro will alleviate shocks on the economies in the Member States?    Mr Duisenberg    The prolonged period of high and increasing oil prices will inevitably have
column118: a so called terms of trade effect
column119: which will take away some of our immediate growth potential. Nevertheless
column120: as I said in my introduction
column121: the European economy has
column122: over the years
column123: become significantly less oil-dependent than it was
column124: say 20 years ago when we also had oil price shocks. Nevertheless
column125: we do expect robust growth to be maintained over the years 2001 and 2002
column126: and that includes the effect of the increased oil prices working their way through. If the oil prices are to come down again
column127: the outlook for our economy would be even rosier than I just indicated.    Mr Skinner (PES/UK)    Thank you. May I welcome the move towards greater transparency? It is quite clear that the great European public is very interested in how you make your decisions and on what basis you gather your information. But
column128: it is quite clear also from your answer to Mr. Huhne that certain things will not be made available and I am just wondering about some of the reasons why. Whether or not there is anything you mentioned or did not mention to Mr. Huhne
column129: perhaps for example
column130: acknowledging a trigger floor for the exchange rate of the euro and the reasons therefore for the ECB intervention. Because although you said
column131: just now and before
column132: that the number one target is inflation
column133: the stability and of course the international role of the euro and its effects on bringing about inflationary pressure inside the euro-zone is an objective partner of that
column134: so I am just wondering whether you have an answer to some of those questions?    Mr Duisenberg    I believe
column136: that I have already answered those questions. Again
column137: we are not a forecasting institution
column138: we are an institution which carries policy responsibility and it is the areas most relevant for the determination of our policy stance that we are going to publish
column139: and then not all of them
column140: simply because we can't. We can't publish all the elements
column141: all the inputs in actual Governing Council decisions because we don't even know them. Yet
column142: I should add here: there are always developments in between the moments that we publish projections
column143: twice a year. Developments can happen
column144: both domestically and externally
column145: which may stimulate the Governing Council to come to a judgement to change the monetary policy stance
column146: in whatever direction. Whether it is at one of the bi-weekly meetings or even in between
column147: we have the liberty to do it at any time that we think it is justified to take such measures. Again
column149: contrary to most forecasting institutions
column150: the responsibility for a major part of economic policy
column152: that imposes certain limitations on our actions
column153: and it also imposes some limitations on our audience
column154: how to interpret
column155: how and what we are doing.    Mrs Riis-Jørgensen (ELDR/DK)    Thank you very much. Mr. Duisenberg
column157: you said how important it was for Member States to limit their public expenditures and Members States
column159: at the same time
column160: establish a strategy for limiting public expenditure growth. You have also said that in Europe
column161: we benefit from the advantages of the new economy. In the light of these statements
column162: do you think that European tax levels of around 50%
column163: because in Sweden it is over 50% and in Denmark
column164: we are talking about roughly 50% tax
column165: do you think that such tax levels prevent us from benefiting from the gains in the new economy which would allow for economic growth and investment coming in
column166: which we have seen going into the United States
column167: and the United States has much lower tax levels than we do in Europe? Thank you.    Mr Duisenberg    As I indicated
column169: I highly applaud the movement towards a reduction in the tax burden that we see in almost all countries in Europe. What I did raise my warning finger for is that these reductions have to be put in a responsible context
column172: endanger one other major objective of all European governments
column173: namely to comply with the standards set for themselves in the stability and growth pact. Whilst reducing taxes
column174: governments should at the same time continue to strive to achieve the aims of the Stability and Growth Pact
column175: of achieving
column176: over the medium term
column177: over the conjunctural cycle
column178: a budget which is in balance or even is in surplus. And that implies that over time
column179: over the medium term and over the cycle
column180: tax cuts have to be matched by cuts in the growth of expenditure. That is all I said
column181: but it is quite a lot.    Mrs Villiers (EPP/ED/UK)    Mr. Duisenberg
column182: I want to ask you firstly
column183: a very simple technical question on the Blair Government's policy on the euro. Their view is that there are five economic tests and the answer to those
column185: will determine whether it is appropriate for the UK to join the euro zone. I would very much like your expert opinion on whether you think that those five economic tests would be an accurate guide for someone in the UK
column186: deciding whether the euro would be good for them or not? But secondly
column187: I really must press you on the topic
column188: which has been brought up by a number of colleagues
column190: and that is the exchange rate intervention. I mean
column191: you have very frankly admitted that it is impossible for you to defend a particular level of the exchange rate
column192: and I think that frankness is refreshing
column193: certainly
column194: but it does give considerable anxieties in effect that the intervention has failed and you have set yourself a new goal
column195: which is changing the psychology effect in the psychology of the market. We do tend to think that selling the euro is a sure thing
column196: a guaranteed profit and that is what you are trying to change now
column197: you say
column199: I think they must be seen as a failure and damaging to the credibility of the ECB
column200: because it makes the ECB look increasingly beleaguered and really
column201: to a large extent
column202: I think desperate
column203: so I would urge you to re-think your exchange rate intervention policy.    Mr. Duisenberg    If I may
column205: I urge Parliament and I beg Parliament not to put words in my mouth which I did not use. And I did not talk about defending a particular exchange rate
column206: I explicitly said
column207: we don't have an exchange rate target. Now on the first question
column208: the self-imposed five tests that the UK Government handles are somewhat different from the tests that any new country
column209: new Member country of monetary union has to comply with. Those are the criteria as enumerated in the Treaty of Maastricht. All I can say about that is that it is only those criteria
column210: the Maastricht criteria
column211: which I regard as relevant for eventual entry of the UK into monetary union. Why? Because when the time is ripe
column212: it is on those criteria that the European Central Bank will write a convergence report as help for the ultimate judgement to be made by the political authorities.    Mr Mann (EPP/ED/D)    Thanks Chairman. The euro was presented as an alternative currency; a kind of way of facing up to the US dollar
column213: but for the moment the muscle seems to be lacking. How are we supposed to interpret that? On the one hand
column214: we have a kind of confrontation and on the other
column215: it seems that by intervening in support of the euro
column216: we can only succeed if the ECB acts in concert with the US bank and the Bank of Japan. Then second
column219: is intended to bring about price stability. But we need to remember the external value of the common currency as well. You say that the aim and the strategy remain unchanged. I understand that. But perhaps we can balance the two. Maybe there was an insufficient level of support? I think it is worth recalling that with regard to the yen
column220: there were 17 interventions before any form of stability was achieved. Finally
column221: when we visited Frankfurt at the beginning of the last but one Strasbourg session
column223: there were displays of large sculptures of euro coins
column224: most of which have since disappeared. In answer to many colleagues who have asked me
column225: I can say that this is not because people don't want the euro
column226: but rather that the proceeds from their sale went towards helping children who were sick with cancer. We are looking forward to the euro
column227: the sooner the better and we are proud to have this institution
column228: and are not about to let it go.    Mr Duisenberg    I never presented the euro as an alternative currency
column229: Madam Chairman. I always emphasised that there is no confrontation and there is no confrontational policy. I only present the euro as the single currency; the single currency and the only one for the participating eleven
column230: and soon the twelve Member States. An international role for the euro will
column231: given the power and the size of this economic area of soon more than 300 million people
column232: will come by itself and from itself
column233: and that's all I would like to say on that. On interventions
column234: they have to be seen in the context of our fight against inflation in this sense
column235: that we had witnessed a continuous walking down a one-way street
column238: namely in a downward direction. That had lasted for so long that
column240: had an impact on internal price stability
column241: on inflation. We have explicitly mentioned
column242: in our last two-interest rate increases
column244: the development or the protracted development of the exchange rate over the past few months. To break that psychology
column245: the euro could move only in one direction and that was downward
column246: that was one of the major causes or justifications for our intervention action. Not to reach
column248: a certain or uncertain exchange rate target
column249: but to break the back of a one-way psychology.    Mrs van den Burg (PES/NL)    Thank you Madam Chairman. First
column250: I'd like to make a comment following on from what others have said about the positive reception given by the European Parliament to the decision to publish these projections. We have to see this in the context of the developments since the Lisbon Summit and social economic policy in general
column251: and having structural indicators which go beyond the economic area
column253: in the area of education for example. I think that what the bank is now doing is a good contribution to all of this. I have a question again
column254: about interventions. I wondered why the national central banks weren't involved? For example
column255: what are they going to do with their monetary reserves in dollars? Surely they don't need them now
column256: and couldn't it have been more effective to have used these rather than the temporary interventions by the ECB? Couldn't this have helped to strengthen the exchange rate of the euro against the dollar
column257: and couldn't the national authorities have made this extra money available to put into funds
column258: to resolve the problem of the ageing of the population? Don't they have money available for that? But is what I am saying exaggerated
column259: what do you think?    Mr Duisenberg    On the first remark
column261: that I appreciate the appreciation such as I
column263: appreciate any appreciation. On the so-called excess reserves
column264: I would say the following. I don't know to what extent the reserves can be termed excess reserves. I would warn against one thing. The reserves that the euro system has are ample
column265: there is no doubt about that
column266: but they are not lying still there. They do earn their money also in whatever currency
column267: whether they are denominated in dollars or in yen or in anything except the major part of gold holdings
column268: which have their own value as you know
column269: just as when the capital of the central banks were to be denominated exclusively in euro. And so
column271: in whatever denomination the assets of the central banks are expressed. What I do object to
column272: is the suggestion implied in the question that the assets of the Central Bank
column273: whether they are denominated in dollars or in euro
column274: would be turned over to Treasuries. That would amount to monetary financing of government deficits
column278: explicitly forbidden. That profits are being turned over to Treasuries
column280: but turning over the capital itself
column284: and to put it in an unfriendly but not less valid way
column286: and that is something I would oppose.    Mr. Tannock (EPP/ED/UK)    Madam Chairman
column287: President Duisenberg. I believe the Wall Street Journal stated "silence is golden" regarding the ECB's public comments on euro intervention. And I believe also that this rule has proven to be a wise one generally. But
column289: I would like to congratulate you on your decision to start publishing twice-yearly economic forecasts
column290: although I take the point that the responsibility of the Governing Council is only limited in this area. This is a good start
column291: but do you not think that the time has now come for the bank to go much further by following the example of say the Bank of England in my country
column292: by publishing the minutes of the Governing Council
column293: as already mentioned by Mr. Huhne
column296: when interest rate decisions are taken. Mmany of us on this Committee are unhappy with the constant allegations of incoherent policy making
column297: poor presentation and lack of understanding by the markets of how you reach your decisions. I am interested
column300: although I realise you won't want to make any specific or direct comments on future currency interventions
column301: whether you now consider that finally the capital account exodus of funds from euroland is shrinking sufficiently
column302: particularly as the bullish growth prospects in the USA are beginning to diminish
column303: to make support and stabilisation of the euro a more realistic prospect for Central Banks and no longer make it possible for this so called "one-way bet" for currency speculators to make their fortunes? Thank you.    Mr. Duisenberg    To take the last question first
column305: as far as the capital account is concerned
column306: we have figures for the first eight months of this year in which figures we see that in as far as foreign direct investment is concerned
column307: there has been a net inflow into Europe which was almost of the same magnitude as the net outflow in the same months of 1999. In portfolio investment there has been an increase in the net outflow
column310: portfolio streams are much more quickly reversible than direct investment streams. In total
column311: foreign direct investment and portfolio investment taken together
column312: the net outflow in the first eight months of the year 2000
column313: was about half of the net outflow in the first eight months of 1999. So that there is something going on that there is something changing
column315: but it is too early to draw definite conclusions from these developments at this moment in time. Then on the other question regarding the minutes
column316: I don't think I have to repeat myself. Regarding the votes
column317: that is to my mind the same as for the minutes. In particular
column318: it rarely occurs that we vote in the Governing Council. We are usually able to reach a consensus
column319: which may take time. Votes are not excluded
column322: so you wouldn't be helped very much by that. For the rest
column323: I do concur with the statement that on some subjects
column326: and this reminds me of the founder of the nation I am a citizen of
column327: who was called William the Silent.    Chairman
column329: President. I hope nevertheless that your responses in future will not be too silent or taciturn. Thank you very much indeed for your presentation and statements today on the economic projections we will be receiving. We will be reading them in the December Bulletin very carefully
column330: and we will be looking at how they do help us to understand monetary policy decisions. We hope that the ECB continues to work successfully and not just internally but also outside the euro area. Thank you very much.
