column6: it is too early to come to a judgement. We will have to come to some sort of judgement already in December when we have our annual exercise of setting again the reference value for monetary growth
column7: which is in part itself based on an estimate of what the potential growth rate of the euro area is. But all indications
column8: as far as we can read them until now
column9: give us insufficient evidence that we can already speak of a higher potential growth rate than has been observed over the past 25 years. We need more time to come to such a judgement. Your third question
column10: I have forgotten.   Mr Lipietz (Greens-EFA/F)   Why should only pensioners and wage earners pay for the increase in oil prices? Why should not the holders of capital pay
column11: and what is your reaction to the French Government's decision to artificially reduce the price of petroleum by reducing excise duties?   Mr Duisenberg   I believe that the burden of the worsening of the terms of trade
column12: to say it in rather abstract and technical terms
column13: is being borne by all sectors of the economy - wage earners and companies. It is undeniable that the oil companies as such at the moment receive some benefit from the higher oil prices
column14: and in a way in as far as excise taxes on gasoline are on an "ad valorum basis" linked to the oil price
column15: governments also receive some benefit. At the same time
column16: I think one should not forget that if a government decides to forego this benefit by lowering taxes in another field
column17: the burden has to be borne somewhere and the government will then be compelled either to increase other taxes or to reduce expenditure if it wants to stay within the limits self-imposed by its fiscal policy.   Mr Schmid (EUL-NGL/S)   Thank you Mr President. Mr Duisenberg
column18: each time you have been in this Committee over the past 6 months
column19: you have assured us that the euro is strong and that the market is mistaken. I think that is a pretty strong statement
column20: to keep saying that the market is mistaken every time and the euro falls and falls. There is another theory or hypothesis
column21: that there are structural problems relating to the EU construction as a whole
column22: that the ECB cannot be independent of Germany
column24: Britain and maybe other Member States
column25: and that political interests necessarily interfere with economic judgement. What is your comment to that theory?   Mr Duisenberg   Well the political interests do not and cannot interfere with the judgements made by the European Central Bank. We are completely independent in that respect from all these political judgements you refer to. To the extent that the thinking and actions of the European Central Bank have an impact on the exchange rate
column26: it is completely independent from whatever political judgement might be given or ventured from whatever part of the euro area or outside it. Then
column27: are the markets mistaken? Some say that markets are always right. I say that the current exchange rate as it has developed over the last few months
column28: is clearly out of line with the fundamentals
column29: with the fundamental relationships between at least the two great economic areas
column30: that is the euro area and the United States
column31: as witnessed by a range of economic indicators. That is the same as saying: markets
column32: you do not have it right
column33: because ultimately exchange rates should and will reflect the fundamental relationships between economic areas
column34: but of course the outcome can from day to day and from week to week differ from this underlying fundamental relationship. It may take some time and it apparently does take some time before this
column36: overshooting has been corrected to an adequate extent.   Mr Schmid (EUL-NGL/S)   Just a comment. It seems to be Mr Duisenberg versus the market. I am not sure that Mr Duisenberg really could have responded otherwise
column37: because being a President of the Bank is kind of a political position. You have to talk up the euro and I suppose that is why you have to say this and why you have to say that the market is necessarily in this case mistaken.   Mr Abitbol (UEN/F)   Thank you Madam Chairman. Mr President
column39: following on from what Mr Schmid has said
column42: the politicians are wrong and you are right. Unfortunately
column43: you are wrong. It is not entirely your fault but I'll explain. The failure of the euro is getting worse every day. We have a so-called European currency; it is failing every day. Now you have spoken with frankness. You said you could do nothing about the American deficit. We all know that we pay for oil in dollars
column45: things are quoted in dollars on the world markets and the stock exchanges are also in dollars. This virtual currency has not found reality
column46: outside of the very talented comments which you make. The only thing you have any control over is interest rates. The only thing you have control over are interest rates. You have already increased interest rates. Growth is slowing down in France and we have managed to reduce unemployment to some extent. But markets and people are asking one question now. What is wrong
column47: is it the pilot or is it the aeroplane? Is the aeroplane badly designed or is the pilot not properly skilled? I would call for the resignation of the pilot. Would you offer your resignation in order to support this cause so that we can see who is wrong
column50: the people or yourself?   Mr Duisenberg   Madam Chairman
column51: the statement that the euro fails every day
column52: I do not accept. The euro to my mind is the success that we had hoped it would be. Since its inception we have been able to achieve our main objective
column53: that is to create a climate of price stability which is conducive to economic growth. We have created a climate which makes it now possible for the euro area as a whole to confidently expect a period of economic growth of more than 3% for at least 3 years. We have achieved that for a market of 300 million people
column54: the exchange rate is no longer a factor for the majority of their trade relations with third parties. The exchange rate has been removed from the considerations for about two-thirds of all previously international trade of the euro area countries. That is an achievement
column56: which was the main aim of creating monetary union in the first place
column57: and that has been achieved. And therefore that gives me a reason to say that the statement that the euro fails every day is totally beside reality and beside the mark.   Chairman (Christa Randzio-Plath
column58: PES/D)   I think the committee agrees with that assessment of the situation    Mr Blokland (EDD/NL)   Thank you Madam Chairman. I would like to get back to monetary strategy and economic development which is what we are talking about. We have heard from Mr Duisenberg that he thinks that in order to have sustainable development and sustainable balance in the Member States' budgets
column59: it is necessary to have wage restraint and a low level of public debt. It seems though that the Member States' governments have not yet carried out their reforms and that is perhaps an explanation why the exchange rate of the euro is not doing so well. We see that the economy is improving now and debt is beginning to be paid off
column60: but in some countries public debt is increasing and the effect of the future ageing of the population will mean increased pension costs for governments
column61: and we have not found a solution to that either. Some people say that in some Member States employers and wages will have to pay for 40% of this. Now
column62: three questions. How should the Member States approach this
column63: by which deadline should public debt decrease
column64: in absolute terms I mean? Should we get public debt down to zero in the next 25 years as some experts in the Netherlands have said? The Netherlands is not doing too badly there
column65: or in your view Mr Duisenberg
column66: should there be a less radical approach
column67: and would that be enough? In the July monthly report from the ECB we have an analysis of this situation. Thank you.   Mr Duisenberg   The fiscal developments in the euro area as a whole still point in the direction of gradually lowering the deficit and not
column68: as is suggested in the question
column69: that they are increasing again. It is a slow process
column70: that is true. The ECB is of the opinion that many governments should and could use the very favourable economic circumstances which they are going through to a greater extent in trying to achieve the goals set in the stability and growth pact. But the movement is in the right direction. I also think it is gratifying to see that currently in those countries where these huge auctions on UMTS technology are being held
column71: that it is intended to use the proceeds of those auctions for either a further reduction of the public debt or for an improvement in the funding of pension systems. Those are things that are going in the right direction. It is not to be forgotten that already
column73: in five or six out of the eleven participating Member States
column74: the goals set in the stability and growth pact
column75: that is to achieve over the medium-term a balanced budget or even a small surplus
column76: that in five or six countries this goal has already been met. Helped by the favourable economic conditions that is true
column77: but nevertheless the fact is there. That does not make me complacent about this. On the contrary
column79: we keep urging governments to use the favourable economic circumstances to a greater extent to achieve the goals set. In how many years the public debt should be entirely eliminated
column80: I cannot answer that. I cannot even answer the question whether it should be or should not. I have great understanding for those governments who make that an explicit aim
column81: to eliminate the public debt altogether
column82: in view of the fact that the room thus created in the budget will be badly needed to meet what is entailed by the ageing of the population over the medium-term. Because within 10 years
column83: you will see those costs increasing in budgets
column84: both in the form of pensions and in the form
column86: of health care costs. To create the room in the budget already now is to be applauded
column87: and I regard that as a wise policy
column88: without being able to indicate in how many years one should or could achieve that total elimination of public debt altogether.   Mr Della Vedova (TDI/It)   Thank you Madam Chairman. Mr President
column89: Chancellor Schr öder welcomed the weakness of the euro. He said that it helps economic growth in Europe. I think it would be suicidal to think about the weakness of the euro as a good thing for economic growth
column90: especially at a time when European citizens are fed up with the fall in the euro and the reduction in their purchasing power. My first question is this. How do you respond to those analysts who said that some people are throwing in the sponge when it comes to the stability of the euro and only a 25 basic point interest rate increase. My second question is about debt. I appreciate very much what you said about fiscal policy
column94: which still has a public debt which was almost twice the Maastricht criteria. Today the government is deciding to give a fiscal bonus
column96: back rather than reducing public debt. They are going to spend this on family allowances
column97: or on investment. I do not think that respects budgetary rigour. Surely budgetary rigour would be a better contribution to the stability of the euro rather than spending and redistributing this tax surplus?   Mr Duisenberg   I think the statement that one should be satisfied with the current position of the euro has been adequately answered by the joint statement issued by the Ministers of Finance and the European Central Bank last weekend. That is
column99: I cannot but repeat it again
column100: we have only one primary aim and that is to maintain internal price stability. We do not have an exchange rate target and therefore the exchange rate developments only become a concern for the European Central Bank in as far as they have a noticeable impact on the rate of inflation
column101: which is our main concern. The second concern is that all this talk about the position of the exchange rate tends to undermine
column103: the confidence and the credibility of the new currency
column104: the confidence it should enjoy with its own electorate
column105: that is the 300 million people in Europe. But that is a psychological cause for concern
column108: the impact that exchange rate developments may have on domestic inflation. That is then maybe a reason to take monetary policy actions as we have
column109: based in part on that consideration
column110: done on 31 August. I am not aware yet of today's plans for the Italian budget
column112: even today I would not comment on it. I recall the discussion we had in this Parliament when last year
column113: the Italians asked for some relief in achieving their goal of reducing the budget deficit to 2.1% of GDP. They asked for relief and they got it. I do want to point out that with the benefit of hindsight
column114: they need not even have asked for it
column115: because they achieved what they originally stated they were going to. And
column117: that seems to me to be a good sign for the future as well.   Mr Pérez Royo (PES/E)   Thank you
column118: Madam Chairman. I want to talk about the real economy. Two questions come in here. In the Round Table meeting in Calgary
column119: you presented a speech on the international role of the euro and in your speech
column120: it was a ten page long speech
column121: you only devoted 9 lines to the exchange rate of the euro
column122: reaffirming the doctrine you explained and which I agree with. But the tone and the content of these statements
column123: and the statements you have made this afternoon
column124: seem to me to contrast sharply with the more dramatic views expressed by the Finance Ministers this last week-end
column125: both in the ECOFIN meeting and in their press conferences. So I have a question
column126: does this mean that when it comes to the real economy and those who are responsible for the real economy
column128: are there more causes for concern than you might have
column129: focusing on purely monetary issues? Secondly
column130: you said there was a good prospect of growth for next year as well
column132: you said robust growth would continue. I believe you said that inflation prospects for the year 2001 would remain below the reference value of 2%. Is there also a prospect then of a strong recovery of the euro exchange rate? Is that consistent with your forecast of growth and low inflation? Is a strong recovery of the euro consistent with that?   Mr Duisenberg   In a ten page long speech I devoted only nine lines to the exchange rate
column133: and that was deliberate because with regard to the exchange rate
column134: one cannot escape mentioning it sometimes. But in general
column135: I agree with the statement made here earlier on the exchange rate; I think for responsible authorities
column136: silence is golden
column137: and I say as little as possible. I must confess I wish that others would have the same attitude on that. Is a strong robust rate of growth with inflation under control
column138: non-inflationary growth
column139: compatible with the strengthening of the exchange rate? The simple answer is
column140: yes. When you make a forecast or an assessment of future developments on certain variables you can only make an assumption
column141: and the assumption which is normally made for interest rates and for exchange ratesis that in the future
column142: the levels observed over the recent past will also prevail in the future. Then you can make variations around that
column143: and assume that things will change
column144: for example the exchange rate or interest rates
column145: and you can try to calculate or make an assessment of what impact that will have on your central forecast. We are doing that of course
column146: and the result of that is that the growth forecasts
column147: which are being made by various international institutions which we have carefully investigated and assessed
column148: are compatible with the strengthening of the exchange rate
column149: just as they are compatible with an unchanged level for the exchange rate.   Mr Goebbels (PES/L)   Mr. President
column150: before Mr. Evans had said that the euro is continuing to decline because Europe has not carried out structural reforms. You seem to partly share that view. I would like to know what structural reforms have taken place in Japan recently
column151: which have led to an appreciation of the yen against the euro and the dollar.    Mr Duisenberg   I know a book
column152: which is called the Japanese enigma
column153: and it is always an enigma for me
column154: so I cannot answer that question. I know Japan is struggling for years already to get out of an atmosphere of total lack of confidence on the part of consumers and investors in their future
column155: and of a great restructuring of the financial and pension sector and of the real estate sector. Those efforts are underway and have led in the meantime to the Japanese government deficit reaching the order of 6% of GDP. They have led to a public debt emerging far in excess of 100% of GDP and there is as yet no end in sight.   Chairman (Christa Randzio-Plath
column156: PES/D)   Could I just put a further question
column157: Mr. President? Would it not be a good thing for the ECB to sometimes remind us of the past
column158: and to remind us that the euro might help us to overcome external shocks? If you compare the impact of the oil price crisis in the 1970's with the oil price crisis now
column159: and if you remember that the Dutch and the Germans had to spend a lot more a few years ago to buy the dollar
column160: and yet at that time nobody spoke about there being a weak guilder or deutschmark.   Mr Duisenberg   Yes
column161: Madam Chairman
column162: I could not agree more
column163: and the question is whether the ECB should continuously point that out as we do
column164: or whether it would not be enough that you have done that already!   Chairman (Christa Randzio-Plath
column165: PES/D)   Well
column166: I can see it is a shared task and a shared challenge. Mr. Von Wogau has the floor.   Mr Von Wogau (EPP-ED/D)   Thank you. Mr. President
column167: I would like to come back to the question that I asked earlier about exchange rates from a procedural point of view now. If I see this correctly the Maastricht Treaty lays down that the question of exchange rates
column169: an exchange rate policy
column170: is a policy that has to be determined by finance ministers at the end of the day. It is not so much the task of the ECB. Exchange rate policy is determined and defined by finance ministers although
column172: intervention would be carried out by the Central Banks. I have a hypothetical question. If there were to be a decision to intervene
column173: what would the procedure be
column174: who would have the final say
column175: who in other words decides the policy and how is policy decided in this field?   Mr Duisenberg   The exchange rate policy is determined by the finance ministers
column176: that is correct. They can also decide not to define an exchange rate policy
column177: as is the current situation. In that case the management of the exchange rate is up to the Central Bank. In this case
column178: then the Treaty adds that the finance ministers could issue so-called general orientations for the exchange rate and thus for exchange rate policy. They could do so in consultation with the ECB.. At the Luxembourg Summit
column179: the finance ministers have decided that they would use that possibility only in very exceptional circumstances
column180: and so far they have seen no reason to do so and we have not consulted each other about that. The ECB also sees no reason to issue such general orientations. Now
column181: what is the procedure on interventions? The procedure is that
column182: were there to be interventions
column183: that would be the initiative of the Central Bank to consult the other big players in the market
column184: in this case that would of course be the American authorities and the Japanese authorities
column185: and the Central Bank would of course keep the ministers of finance informed of any such intentions and/or actions.   Mr Huhne (ELDR/UK)   Can I just follow that up by asking about the procedure again? Is it therefore the case that the ECB
column186: in the circumstances where the finance ministers have not actually set guidelines for the exchange rate
column187: the ECB can effectively decide on intervention itself
column188: obviously with the courtesy of consulting the finance ministers?   Mr Duisenberg   That is correct.   Mr Huhne (ELDR/UK)   The question that I would like to ask you concerns the fashionable topic of the output gap. I wondered whether you could give us your current estimate of the output gap in the euro area
column189: and whether you will be publishing estimates of the output gap when you publish your forecasts
column191: hopefully before the end of the year.   Mr Duisenberg   I cannot give you an estimate of the euro area wide output gap. I do see that there are parts of the euro area where one can clearly speak of the non-existence any longer of an output gap and of an overheated situation almost. There are other parts
column192: and they are the larger parts
column193: where there certainly still is some slack in the economy which could be used but I cannot give you an estimate of a euro area wide output gap. Regarding the second part of the question
column194: we have still to decide what to publish precisely. We are discussing that at the moment
column195: both internally and in the context of the governing council actively
column196: and it is likely that we will publish a small range of estimates for some variables. I think that the concept "output gap" will not be one of them.   Mr Lipietz (Greens-EFA/F)   Thank you. I am rather worried because until now you were more committed to making the model you base your policy on public. In the plenary session of Parliament you said that
column197: but if such an important factor as the output gap is not to be published
column199: do you think that the new economy will allow us to move from 2.5% to 3.5% potential growth
column200: and do you think that this increase in potential growth would be compatible with Europe's commitments on climate change? We have the Kyoto Conference commitments and this is happening in The Hague now. How can we achieve this without reforming our transport systems and investing massively in energy policy? How can the ECB or the EIB help to make this massive investment necessary
column201: which would then increase potential growth?   Mr Duisenberg   We have carefully analysed current and recent economic developments in order to investigate whether we could speak indeed about an New Economy. Has the New Economy arrived in Europe
column202: New Economy being defined as an economic development characterised by a persistently higher rate of growth of productivity than has been observed in the past? Our conclusion is that we do not find convincing evidence of the New Economy
column203: which in turn is being helped by the application of new technologies
column204: in particular in the information and communications technologies sphere and by a greater flexibility of markets. In particular in labour markets
column205: we have not been able to conclude that the New Economy is already here. Not even in those parts of the euro area which have observed over a number of years a considerably higher rate of growth of output than was traditionally the case.   Chairman (Christa Randzio-Plath
column206: PES/D)   That is the end of the second round. We will start with the Socialists on economic developments and in particular the question of the influence of the new economy on economic growth and the effect on monetary policy
column207: and other colleagues will also be asking questions. I give the floor to Mr Trentin.   Mr Trentin (PES/It)   Thank you
column208: Madam Chairman. I do not know whether President Duisenberg agrees with the widespread view that the members of the EMU would benefit from a devaluation of the euro
column209: because this would mean growth and more exports. I think
column210: and this is based on a lot of experience from my country
column211: that so called inflation and competitive devaluation
column212: apart from in the long term leading to a high risk of inflation
column213: leads to a form of drugged economic growth. It promotes traditional and uncompetitive growth and it slows down innovation and real enterprise. People do not invest in new technologies
column214: in research and continuous training under those circumstances. If I am right
column215: do not you think that the euro group's delay in adopting a transparent and clear policy hasnot been partly to blame for the problems of the euro? Also we need a common energy policy which we have not got and there is the crucial question we have already mentioned of co-ordinated government control of American debt vis-à-vis foreign investors.    Mr Duisenberg   If I am right in thinking and stating
column216: together with ministers
column217: that the exchange rate is clearly out of line with the fundamentals
column218: then the implication is that at some point it will correct itself. I am certainly
column220: not at all in favour of so-called competitive devaluations
column221: because it would mean one jumping over another and nobody would be any better off in the end. But also I do want to repeat that a strong euro is in the interest of the euro area and it will come. But the danger is
column225: a serious under- valuation of the euro in the markets may lead to decisions for example
column227: to invest on the basis of information which is only temporary and which is fundamentally wrong. It may lead to the postponement of other measures which will have to be taken in the structural sphere because of this temporary boost to the economy
column228: which is being derived from a weaker than justified exchange rate
column229: and that is in itself an undesirable effect.   Mr Bullmann (PES/D)   President Duisenberg
column231: in particular in information and communication
column232: should mean a leap in productivity
column233: which if there are moderate wage developments should increase the leeway for non-inflationary growth potential. If the leeway for non-inflationary growth is there
column234: we can let things have freer reign. But you say you cannot see this point yet
column235: as you cannot see the new economy
column236: and my question is: why are we not at that point yet? Are there other reasons why we haven't seen this injection of new technology yet to the extent that it is possible and visible in the U.S? Couldn't it be that the political recommendations that you expressed will have to be extended? You spoke about consolidation of budgets and the labour markets
column237: that's what we always talk about. Why don't you speak about a stronger pro-active technology policy or a stronger pro-active education policy which is required for the Member States to make us more innovation friendly as Europeans? Is this also part of the communication with Member States? Please do not tell me that you are not responsible for education policy
column239: but you are not directly responsible for pensions or education. Please tell me if you think what I am saying is possible. If it is
column240: all the better.   Mr Duisenberg   Well
column241: what you are saying is not only possible
column242: but I think desirable. But it would be wrong to ascribe the phenomenal developments in the United States exclusively to the development of new information and communication technology. It is a range of factors
column243: not the least being that in the United States they can operate much more than in Europe in a very flexible labour market. It is labour market flexibility which to a very large extent makes possible the phenomenal adjustment process that the United States has gone through
column245: also in terms of the application throughout the economy of new information technology. But then I don't say that it cannot come. I only said that as far as the New Economy is concerned we cannot see it coming yet
column246: even in regions which are performing outstandingly. Even in the field of application of information technology like in Finland or Ireland or even The Netherlands
column247: we cannot analytically observe yet that we have a higher growth rate of productivity than was observed over the past 25 years. But I happen to believe that it is coming
column248: but I cannot prove it.   Mr Katiforis (PES/Gr)   Mr. President
column249: following on from your last remark on the flexibility of the labour market in Europe
column250: can you tell us what were the measures that the United States used to increase the flexibility of its labour market
column251: which may be more flexible than the European one? How is it that in the Reagan era
column252: the United States was suffering from unemployment
column253: and now the United States is not suffering from unemployment? What is the great change in the flexibility in the American labour market that has changed the fortunes of the American economy? If we talk about flexibility
column254: should we not discuss the flexibility of the financial markets and comment on our scandalous inability to form a unified stock exchange?   Mr Duisenberg   I cannot point to a particular measure in the United States which increased labour market flexibility. What I did say is that they can operate their economy in a situation
column255: a climate where the labour market is much more flexible than in any part of the European Union. That is the situation there
column257: labour markets are stifled by rules and regulations and contracts which have grown over the years and had the effect that the mobility of labour and the flexibility in the labour market is weaker than it is in the United States. We have to do something about that if we want to perform in a similar way. As far as the financial markets and the stock exchanges are concerned
column258: I think that the coming of the euro is acting as a catalyst to achieving more efficient markets and market instruments also in that area. That is a process we are going through
column259: and I would not call it scandalous if that process went with some ups and downs. But for example in the area of clearing and settlement
column260: we still have in Europemany different systems. The process is clearly on the way to consolidation
column261: and the industry itself tells me that 5 years from now it would be reasonable to expect that there would not be more than 5 or 6 operative in the euro area. But it takes time to achieve that
column262: just as it takes time for stock exchanges to co-operate
column263: to merge and sometimes to disappear.   Mr Langen (EPP-ED/D)   President
column264: I would like to continue with what my previous colleague asked. You said here that amongst other things
column265: the taxation of labour is too high and reforms are required. First of all
column266: if billions of euros disappear into the dollar area
column267: there must be a possibility to retain this capital in the euro area. How could you describe the conditions for cross border pension funds in Europe to operate? Second part of the question
column268: how do you see the ramifications of the decision of taxation of interest in the European Union? You say that the burden must be taken off labour. We have burdens on oil. What is your view of taxation of interest income
column269: how do you see the proposed taxation of internet services proposed by the European Commission
column270: and as I understand it the French Presidency declined to do this yesterday?   Mr Duisenberg   The billions of euros that are going from Europe to the United States
column271: we cannot stop and we do not want to stop them in completely free markets. All we have to do is to make Europe more attractive as a place to invest than currently is the case. If we manage to do that
column272: for example by making labour markets more flexible
column273: by making hiring and firing easier - these are measures that may be painful
column274: but in the end they are to the benefit to the people and also to the workers
column275: as has been proven in the United States - if we manage to make those structural reforms amongst a range of others
column276: then Europe will become a more attractive place to invest in than it currently is. But we have to get the conditions right. On cross border pension funds we now have no borders for the euro
column277: so there are no exchange rate restrictions on where to invest for pension funds
column278: at least inside the euro area. Everything is done in euros so there the liberalisation is already there
column279: but I don't know precisely what the upshot of your question is. Taxation of interest and taxation of Internet services
column280: I know that it is a hotly debated subject amongst the competent authorities
column282: and I prefer the Central Bank - which has no competence - to stay out of this debate
column283: even in this room.   Mr Tannock (EPP-ED/UK)   Thank you. First of all
column284: a brief comment on your reference to the persistently high US balance of payments deficit which you hinted at as being fundamentally incompatible with a strong dollar. Surely and in reality
column285: and perhaps unwisely in my view
column286: the US government actively encourages a strong dollar to ensure indefinite financing by foreign investors of this deficit? If the perception were ever to change that the dollar would soon weaken
column287: then this would cause a massive flight out of the dollar to avoid foreign exchange losses and generate a balance of payments crisis in the US
column288: which is currently the driving force behind global economic growth. If the US goes into recession
column289: this would drag us all down with it
column290: with no hope of a soft landing anywhere
column291: no matter how skilled the pilot or well designed the aeroplane. The rest of my question regarding America is: given the exceptional 10 year period of growth in the US with the renowned skills of Alan Greenspan as Chairman of the Fed
column292: what useful lessons and conclusions can the ECB draw from the US model
column293: both in terms of the much championed information technology and telecom generated new economic paradigm
column294: but more particularly the special relationship between the Federal Reserve Bank and the other organs of US government? In particular
column295: the policy of openness and transparency which contrasts rather markedly with the European Central Bank's.   Mr Duisenberg   I can be rather brief on this question about what can we learn in the area of transparency. I do not think we can learn very much from the United States
column296: because to my mind the ECB is more open and more transparent than any other central bank in the world
column297: the Fed. included.   Mrs Villiers (EPP-ED/UK)   President Duisenberg
column298: I would like to ask you why a Danish voter
column299: contemplating whether to tick the "yes" or "no" box on 28 September
column300: perhaps concerned about the new economy
column302: because it seems to me that you have admitted today and it is clear that the new economy is not happening in the European Union. It is clear that the United States is setting the pace in terms of the new economy and economic reform
column303: and attempts in the European Union at structural reform seem to have been derisory so far. You come back to our Committee regularly and every time you bring the same message that we need structural reform and I myself cannot really point to any strides that have been made in that direction. The trend is in the opposite direction
column304: whether it is directives on pregnant workers or directives on how your employees climb a ladder
column305: the trend in the European Union is to make it more difficult to employ people
column306: to impose more costs on employers. Until there is a radical change in that I cannot see that the euro zone is going to become a better place to do business in. That surely is the fundamental reason why the exchange rate is going down
column307: because the euro zone is not perceived as a good place in which to do business. And so
column308: if I was a Danish voter on September 28
column309: I suspect that I would be ticking the "no" box and not the "yes" box.   Mr Duisenberg   I also said in my introduction and later in the debate that one by no means should think or perceive that in the area of structural reforms nothing is done altogether. A lot is being done not enough and in particular maybe in the larger countries not enough
column310: but a lot is being done and we have to appreciate that as well. So I am not as pessimistic as apparently you are that things might even go in the wrong direction. I have a different perception of that. As far as the Danish Referendum is concerned
column311: I think that it is wise for me to stay out of that debate.   Chairman (Christa Randzio-Plath
column312: PES/D)   That is also the reason why the European Parliament is not involving itself in the Danish debate. Now Mr. Huhne for the Liberals.   Mr Huhne (ELDR/UK)   Mr. President
column313: you said earlier on that you believed that the new economy was coming to Europe but that you could not prove it. I noticed that the Bundesbank's monthly report actually comes to the conclusion
column314: based on some quite clear evidence
column315: that investing in information technology is actually running at a higher level in Germany than people had previously thought
column316: so maybe that is a piece of evidence. But I wanted to ask you whether you thought that since Alan Greenspan had clearly begun to factor this process of productivity improvement
column318: into his thinking and decision-making before clear evidence became available
column319: whether you thought that that was appropriate for the ECB
column320: or whether you actually have to wait until the evidence is really cut and dried after the event before you begin to factor it into your decisions.   Mr Duisenberg   In our decision-making process I think we have to wait until the evidence is clear
column321: but the first moment that such a decision has to be taken is already coming next December. It may sound very technical
column322: but if we have to determine the reference value for monetary growth
column323: then the potential rate of growth of output is one of the factors which in turn determines the reference value we have to adopt. So it will come pretty soon that we will have to make up our minds
column324: and we are by no means ignoring it. But I would also like to point out that when Mr. Greenspan in his latest speeches finally
column326: recognised the existence of a totally new situation
column327: he also asked himself why it was happening in the United States and not in Europe. His explanation is that it is the major difference in flexibility in the labour market which is the main explanatory factor for the difference. I agree with you
column328: I have seen the study by the Bundesbank and other studies that the application of new information and communication technologies is proceeding at a very rapid pace also in Europe
column329: and in some European countries even faster than in the United States.    Mr Huhne (ELDR/UK)   Surely
column330: that is inconsistent with Mr. Greenspan's view. Why would business people invest in information technology if they were not able to get a good return form it? If the inflexibility that you are talking about actually prevented them from getting a good return
column331: surely the very fact that the investment is actually happening in Europe is evidence that on the ground
column332: people make the judgement that they can get the returns and that Alan Greenspan's view that inflexibility is an obstacle is wrong.   Mr Duisenberg   Well
column333: I would have to think about that one
column334: but I may have to go to another conference in Jackson Hole this time!   Mr Lipietz (Greens-EFA/F)   Thank you. I myself am rather sceptical that flexibility in the labour market explains investment in new technology. Finland is not the most flexible country in the world in terms of the labour market
column335: and yet in Europe it is at the head of the technological revolution. On the other hand
column336: what is true is that investment in the United States has been much stronger than in Europe throughout the 1990's. If you take the economy as a whole and not sociological studies
column337: it seems that investment is easier for companies if interest rates are low. I repeat a question I have already asked
column339: what measures do you intend to take in terms of monetary policy in order to promote investment in Europe
column340: be it in new technology or energy technology?   Mr Duisenberg   In terms of monetary policy the only measures that we will take
column341: are taking and are going to take are those which help us to achieve price stability in Europe
column342: and not those directed primarily at promoting investment or hindering investment. There
column343: monetary policy has no role to play.   Mr Theonas (UEL-NGL/Gr)   Thank you. Firstly a comment which does not concern you
column345: but it does concern us as Members of the European Parliament. If in this 21st Century we wish to copy the United States
column346: where I think the social situation is not very good
column348: and in the next elections we hope that more than 30% of the electorate will turn out. That is what we are striving for. Today
column350: the price of oil and the value of the euro effects economic development in Europe and if I followed your presentation and your answers to questions properly
column351: I reached the conclusion that you are trying to get a message across today. You are saying that in the context of monetary policy and exchange rate policy
column352: the ECB can do no more in combating the negative effects that we see in the European economy. So you are trying to get a message across to Ministers. You are calling on Ministers to carry out structural reforms. Three simple questions. On wages
column353: are we entering a new period of wage restraint and austerity? Secondly
column354: will this structural change be a response to oil prices and the uncontrollable situation arising from the value of the currency
column355: and what do you think about countries that have already carried out structural reform? How are they going to deal with the increase in oil prices and the devaluation of the euro?   Mr Duisenberg   I believe
column357: that I have answered most of those questions already at an earlier stage. I only do hope that for the immediate future
column358: we can continue to live in a climate where wage moderation is being exercised
column360: luckily so and to the benefit of the people
column361: over the past 2 to 3 years. I do hope that the shortages which are already appearing in the labour market will not translate themselves into wage demands which would exceed the rate of growth of productivity in the various areas. May I add that I mean the rate of growth of productivity corrected for the change in the terms of trade?In other words
column362: wage increases are not the appropriate response to the increase in oil prices.    Mr Blokland (EDD/NL)   We have just heard about the Danish Referendum and Mr. Duisenberg rightly said that he does not wish to comment on that. On the other hand I have understood from people who want to keep the krone in Denmark that the European Union and the European Parliament has done everything to support them because of the external value of the euro. They say that because of the external value of the euro we have got an excellent chance of winning the referendum in favour of the krone. Our perception of what we do
column364: is often very different to reality.    Mr Della Vedova (TDI/It)   Thank you. Mr. President
column365: I think you have already been very clear about flexibility in the labour market. But some time ago
column367: and it may have been a joke
column368: that he wanted to avoid raising interest rates if the American government had given 1
column369: 000 green cards for people who specialise in the new economy even though they have almost full employment. We don't in Europe
column370: but as far as the new technology sector is concerned
column371: there are job opportunities. Don't you think that as far as flexibility on the labour market we should open our doors to immigration
column372: especially highly skilled workers? Don't you think that that would help to develop the new economy in Europe much better than anything we can do with interest rates?   Mr Duisenberg   Well
column373: it is happening here and there and I think it is up to the governments to make decisions on that and not the ECB
column374: but it is happening. It is happening in Germany
column376: in The Netherlands. That is an achievement. When I think of Ireland
column377: I cannot help thinking how historically unique it is that a country which for 150 years has been a net emigration country
column378: has now turned into a net immigration country. That is a historic fact of enormous proportions to my mind and it is the European Union which has made that possible.    Mrs Torres Marques (PES/P)   Mr. Duisenberg
column380: the costs of cross border transactions
column381: bank transfers or credit card payments are still a major percentage of the amount transferred. There is always a certain percentage that is charged and seeing that there is no risk in the euro zone
column382: isn't the ECB of the opinion that this practice should be banned by means of a regulation or a directive? That is my first question. My second question is whether you think there should be some frontloading for public authorities
column384: local and regional government in the year 2001 so that these authorities can be functioning properly at the beginning of 2002.   Mr Duisenberg   On the transactions that are still being charged
column387: we are in close contact with the sector but we are not finally competent to dictate the sector how they will bring down the costs of the transfers
column389: and what they can charge their customers. As I have already indicated in my introduction
column390: we have issued a range of recommendations to the sector concerning cross-border retail payments in September 1999 and we will
column392: publish a report on an assessment of the situation as it develops and on the progress that is being made and on the lack of progress being made in other areas. Concerning frontloading to particular parties
column394: there can be frontloading to banks and to other organisations prior to 1st January 2002 but not to the general public. But to other organisations
column395: and I wouldn't exclude public authorities from that
column396: if they can guarantee that these frontloaded notes will not be brought into general circulation before 1st January 2002
column397: then it can take place according to our decision already as from 1st September 2001.    Chairman (Christa Randzio-Plath
column399: why does the ECB want to be involved in the negotiations on enlargement
column400: because surely the Treaties are clear in saying that ECOFIN and the ECB only come into play when a request is made for participation in the euro zone? The second question concerns staff of the ECB; do officials working for the ECB have the same working conditions as other European officials?   Mr Duisenberg   The ECB is not directly involved in the negotiations with the accession countries
column401: but we are always in close contact with the European Commission and also with the accession countries themselves to help and inform them and give them assistance in preparing for the eventual accession
column402: especially in our field of competence which is central and private banking and the financial sector as a whole. The consequences of the accession for quite a number of countries for the functioning of the ECB itself are not very clear. The question is being raised as to whether the decision-making bodies can properly function if the number of participants is greatly increased. Our answer to that is that of the three decision-making bodies
column404: nor the General Council in which all EU central bank governors participate
column405: seemed to be a problem given the nature of the decisions which the General Council has to take. There could be a problem with the Governing Council
column407: if that number were to be greatly increased
column408: but that is still a long way off. Then we might have to address that problem
column409: to reach a more efficient decision-making process. But in our view
column410: the time is not yet right after a year and a half in existence to start thinking about or discussing changes in the composition or nature of the decision-making bodies of the ECB
column411: and we have ample time to do that at a later stage. What we are talking about here is not accession to the European Union but basically accession to monetary union
column412: which will come years after actual accession to the European Union. With regard to our personnel
column413: I believe that working conditions are comparable to those prevailing in other European institutions.   Mrs Peijs (EPP-ED/NL)   Mr. President
column414: you spoke about a new threshold for balance of payment reports to the ECB. I am pleased about that but disappointed about the level of the threshold. I am the rapporteur on this and I had thought of the amount in the directive
column416: 000 euros. What do you think about this? I am sure the Parliament will be calling for a threshold of 50
column417: 000 euros in line with the directive. I know how you got 12
column419: that is the guarantee level in the directive
column420: but we want it increased to 50
column421: 000 euros because there will be a lot of reporting between the 12
column424: I would like to ask your opinion about the Western Union moneygram transfer system. Money can be transferred immediately
column425: but it is a system which is fine for people who do not have bank accounts but the problem is that according to the second banking directive
column426: these companies are seen as banks and this prevents them from growing and developing. I think some competition for banks is not a bad thing
column427: so what is your opinion about this sort of money transfer system?   Mr Duisenberg   I am afraid I will have to answer these questions at a later stage as I am not enough of an expert on either subject
column428: so I will answer them in writing.   Mr Gasoliba I B öhm (ELDR/E)   President
column429: I want to express a concern I have about this last item on the agenda
column430: the practical aspects of introducing the euro. Well
column431: we are just a year and a few months away from the introduction of the euro now and my experience has been that there has still been no significant campaign undertaken to raise awareness about the introduction of coins and notes. It is quite right as you said that what you do is nothing compared with what Member States have to do to raise awareness
column432: but I think that it is important for you to bear in mind the need for this campaign to really take off on a decentralised basis. At the moment all the decisions are being taken at the level of national central banks
column433: but this is not being spread to local authorities
column434: and the level of dialogue between the sectors concerned
column436: representatives of SME's. People's awareness is very limited.   Mr Duisenberg   The preparation of the campaign is on schedule and is well underway as has been explained by Mr. Domingo Solans in May of this year to this Committee. The campaign is intensifying over time and it will reach its most intense phase only in the last quarter of 2001. We believe that if we were to have an intensive campaign at an earlier stage
column437: it would be money thrown away because the effects of such a campaign would wear off long before the actual banknotes had been introduced. We do see the need and we share the concern of the European Parliament
column439: for close co-ordination of all the campaigns that will be executed both by the ECB
column440: or by the Eurosystem I should say
column441: and national authorities and the European Commission. The preparations as I said are well underway but the effects will only be seen very clearly in the period briefly preceding the actual introduction of the notes on 1st January 2002. But in the last quarter of 2001 you will be bombarded with information on the notes to come
column442: and our efforts will be directed at various categories of people such as the public at large and special categories such as blind and partially sighted people
column443: people with learning disabilities and elderly people to make them familiar with their new notes. I also would have liked to have the notes earlier
column444: but it simply cannot be done
column445: so we will have to wait another year and a half because we cannot print them earlier. We have already 11 secured printing works across the European Union which are currently operating 24 hours a day
column446: 7 days a week printing the new banknotes
column447: and it will still be a great effort to have everything ready on time by 1st September 2001.   Mr Gasoliba I B öhm (ELDR/E)   I am not only talking about the physical availability of notes in order to be familiar with them but also in some Member States the information campaign is limited to the central bank level
column448: to big firms etc. and it is not penetrating to other areas. Some regional and local authorities are not involved enough
column449: this worries me. I think it will be important to involve any sector at social
column450: economic and administrative level and in the discussions that you have I am asking to try to ensure the involvement of the different sectors.   Mr Duisenberg   I take serious note of what you are saying and I would appreciate it if there are certain concerns for certain regions of the euro area
column451: if you would relate that to us.   Mr Lipietz (Greens-EFA/F)   If I have understood the plan
column453: cheques in euros will become widespread and consumers are going to ask: will they have the same value regardless of where they are issued? You acted on small cross-border transfers and this will play a decisive role in the credibility of the euro
column455: throughout Europe. If a 100 euro cheque is worth a different amount depending on where you cash it because some banks might charge 40 euros for cashing the cheque
column456: then people will not believe in the euro.   Mr Duisenberg   Well
column457: to be able to write a cheque in euro is entirely up to the private sector and it is not up to the ECB. We will issue ourpromissory notes as from 1st January 2002
column459: whether or not it is in the form of cheques
column460: and make payments in euro already now in many areas but not everywhere. But it is up to the people themselves
column461: to the banking sector and the public to accept that.   Chairman (Christa Randzio-Plath
column463: I would like to thank you very much for this comprehensive monetary dialogue with a few new messages. Finally
column466: I would like to congratulate you on your 65th birthday
column467: as this is our first opportunity to do so.
