Hearing before the  Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs of the European Parliament
column4: Introductory statement delivered by Dr. Willem F. Duisenberg
column6: which in the end always hits those people most who can least defend themselves against the results of it.   Mr Theonas:  Thank you very much
column8: I have a comment to make. Since November of last year we have seen interest rates rise on a constant basis and I think that we have seen five or six interest rate rises on the part of the ECB. This leads to a number of questions. What are we supposed to assume; that ECB policy before November 1999 was not sufficiently considered. Now
column9: we have just heard that growth rates had a negative effect on stability policy. Is that the reason? If we were to have a global assessment today of economic developments then perhaps we should also have a political and monetary assessment
column10: so that members would be better placed to make the proper decisions on unemployment. I think that there is a question mark now with regard to political control of monetary policy in this context.   Mr Duisenberg:  I think
column12: you have this opportunity for an assessment every month after you have seen our monthly bulletin in which we give all the considerations for and against moving interest rates or leaving interest rates unchanged. You are in the position to form yourself a well-informed judgement about our policy.  Now
column13: as to the change of heart in the monetary policy stance in the course of 1999. In the beginning of 1999 I want to remind you that we saw the danger- and we shared the thoughts about this with the European Parliament - of recessionary tendencies developing in Europe. We saw inflation approaching the lower level which we also do not like
column15: zero. In some areas we already thought that if you took account of the measurement bias included in inflation figures
column16: that deflation had already arrived. That led us to decrease interest rates in the course of April last year. In the course of 1999 things changed and the outlook became brighter
column17: but that does not happen overnight. So
column18: to the extent that data became available
column20: we ultimately in November decided to reverse our monetary policy stance and with more and more data becoming available
column22: we followed upon that first measure by adopting a more tightening
column25: a less loose
column26: monetary policy stance. Appropriate
column27: we think
column28: and I hope I can share that with you
column29: for the monetary situation and the economic situation of the time. Take into account a money supply growth month after month
column30: or three months after 3 months
column32: whatever you may think of the reference value
column33: but the excess is very significant and certainly larger than any revision of the reference value which might be undertaken in December. I do not know yet. Add to that credit to the private sector developing at more than 10% on an annual basis It leads us to the conclusion that still today monetary developments are in no way a hindrance for the further development of economic activity in the euro area
column34: and liquidity conditions are still being regarded by the business community
column36: as being ample and generous.   Mr Della Vedova:  Thank you
column38: I think that the most recent policy decisions on interest rates are very good for the Euro economy
column39: not only in combating inflation but also because they stimulate virtuous behaviour and this is what is necessary at a time of growth. There is a structural change going on in the employment market. We want to encourage improvements in public finances. I am thinking of the debt. This encourages a prudential reform which gives you long-term sustainability and if this increases the level of the Euro as it seems to have done
column40: it will improve European companies' competitiveness through investment in technology. So
column41: this brings me to my question. How do you
column42: Mr President
column43: assess the proposal for a political body with real powers in economic policy for the Euro 11? Do you think that this extra body would be useful and necessary for obtaining European growth based on structural reform
column44: or do you think that this would be a political body which
column45: at the end of the day
column46: would simply increase ambiguity and pressure on the ECB for a policy which is not based on containing inflation
column47: but which is based on stimulating growth? Thank you.   Mr Duisenberg:  The independent policy stance and the independence as such of the ECB is
column49: extremely well-guarded in the Treaty. Any move amongst the European 15 or the Euro 11 to create an institutionalised political body
column50: if it enhances the co-operation and co-ordination amongst Ministers of Finance in fields other than monetary policy
column51: can only be applauded. If it is meant to exert influence on the European Central Bank
column52: it will not succeed. That is
column57: the position also politically of the European Central Bank is one in which the European Central Bank is fully independent
column58: but also fully accountable to Parliament
column59: Ministers and the public.   Chair:  Thank you very much.  Now we move on to the second part of the first round on monetary policy. Mrs Villiers.   Mrs Villiers:  Irish inflation
column60: hitting its highest level for 15 years this month
column63: not least of which the unfortunate fact that this most hospitable of nations now has the most expensive pubs and bars in Europe according to the European Commission
column64: leading some trade unions recently to demand an immediate freeze on the price of Guinness. Now
column65: important as this issue is to many of my colleagues
column66: what I want you to address us on is another consequence of this unfortunate fact
column67: and that is the spiralling asset price inflation and the very real inflationary boom in house prices and the prospect of a forthcoming bust. Is there anything that the EU and the ECB can do about this
column68: given that Ireland is always going to form a relatively small part of the total economy of the Euro zone?   Mr Duisenberg:  There is nothing that the ECB can do about it except from trying to convince the national authorities in Ireland that these developments
column70: are to be dealt with by them. Monetary policy as such can do nothing in this respect. I will not deny that our series of interest rate increases will help
column71: but they were not taken with a view to Irish developments only. They are helpful and certainly work in the right direction also for the Irish situation.  Now
column72: the spiralling asset prices. A Central Bank and also the European Central Bank cannot
column74: form a judgement on what precisely the appropriate level of asset prices is
column75: be it real estate or be it stocks and equity. We do recognise that the rise in asset prices which is occurring here and there
column78: on the one hand creates wealth effects which may be only temporary. On the other hand
column79: they do carry the danger that the balloon will burst and that might have consequences
column80: although we think as I said in my introduction
column81: that the consequences for the banking system can be overcome. The banking system as a whole is not very vulnerable in these areas
column82: so there is little likelihood that it will spread across the financial system. We are faced here with a dilemma
column83: especially the national authorities. I always say that in the old days before the Euro whenever such a development happened in a country
column84: there was one policeman who very soon reacted and forced a country to take counter measures. That was the balance of payments. When a country competed itself out of the market it was the balance of payments which reacted and showed very quickly a deficit which was unsustainable
column85: and which forced a country to exert a policy of belt-tightening so that these forces could be kept under control. Now
column87: Ireland does not have a balance of payments any longer. The euro area as a whole has a balance of payments
column88: so that policeman is on vacation you might say. Ultimately
column90: the same effects of losing competitiveness will work their way through also in relations between Ireland and the rest of Europe. It may take a very long time. We are
column92: faced with a dilemma. We see the long-term disadvantages - and I know that the Irish Government sees that also - but here you have a country which has a healthy surplus on the budget
column93: which has no longer a balance of payments
column94: but which does have an inflation rate well in excess of 5%. It is a very difficult situation to handle. On the other hand
column95: I am always struck looking at it historically. Ireland has been a net emigration country for two centuries. Now Ireland is a net immigration country
column96: which is a historical achievement of proportions not to be underestimated.   Mr Tannock:  Madam Chairman
column98: The weak Euro has clearly benefited Euroland's exporters recently
column99: although the currency came dangerously close to going into freefall last month as the markets lost confidence in the ability of the socialist governments of France
column101: to address the Euro's sclerotic labour market rigidities
column102: and the obvious need for structural reforms
column103: including de-regulation and less red tape. Recently
column105: under your stewardship
column106: was blamed for the single currency's weakness and calls were made for more political oversight and direction of the bank by the Euro 11. However
column107: is it not the case that you have been unable to give growth a chance by further interest rate cuts
column108: as Euroland's NAIRU is higher than it should be
column109: compared to the U.S.A. with its incredible ten-year unsurpassed record of growth and low unemployment
column110: precisely because of the lack of the political will on this continent for further structural reforms?   Mr Duisenberg:  No
column111: I don't think so. The Central Bank has great powers
column112: but don't over-estimate powers that the Central Bank has. In your analysis
column113: I think if I am permitted to say too
column114: you mentioned some socialist governments: I would also like to point to the socialist government in the Netherlands
column115: which has seen a growth performance - at least the socialists are the largest party there in the coalition - which is not very much below that of the United States
column116: both in terms of rates of growth
column117: in terms of unemployment figures which are now under 3%
column118: in terms of reform of the labour market and all that with a unified monetary policy. I can say the same for Portugal. I think the generalisation that I just heard was just a little bit too much
column119: and I do think that political interference with the policies of the ECB ought not to occur
column120: as is clear from the Maastricht Treaty. The Maastricht Treaty gives strong guarantees to the Central Monetary Authority that such political interference will not occur. It is even forbidden. I think that works well and it will work well in the future.   Mr Katiforis:  Mr President
column121: Chair
column122: You have said time and again today that you consider inflation a monetary phenomenon
column124: of course
column125: money comes with a velocity and velocities are usually changeable
column126: so one wonders where that leaves your first pillar? But that is by the way.  The main question is
column127: even you will not insist that raising interest rates leads to an acceleration of the rate of growth. We are advised by our experts that the weakness of the Euro is explainable by the persistent growth differential in favour of the United States
column128: which your interest rates rise does not seem to do anything to diminish. If so
column129: and if it is indeed true that the weakness of the Euro is due to a differential growth effect
column130: by your raising of the interest rates you are prolonging
column131: one would say
column133: the improvement of which has not been spectacular in the markets
column134: lets face it. Therefore
column135: by trying to fight inflation you are exacerbating one of the tendencies to inflation which is the low Euro
column136: you admit. I wonder how you would comment on that.   Mr Duisenberg:  I forget about the velocity point?   Mr Katiforis:  The velocity point is that velocity is changeable and where does that leave your first pillar?   Mr Duisenberg:  Well
column137: it leaves our first pillar where we established it
column138: namely we observed a trend decline in the velocity of circulation of between 1/2% and 1% per year over 25 years and our indications are that nothing much has changed. We still have
column140: an unusually stable demand for money function
column141: more stable than in the Anglo-Saxon countries
column142: on both sides of the ocean. The main thing is the difference in performance on both sides of the Atlantic. They in part explain the exchange rate relationships and the weakening tendency which has been prevalent
column143: and I emphasised fortunately the words "has been prevalent". That growth differential is diminishing but it has not yet disappeared. Still the United States is growing faster than Europe. It will not take long
column144: I hope
column145: before those positions are reversed
column146: but it is still the case
column147: and then it is not the only reason for the persistent weakness. The interest rate differential as such should also be mentioned. Of course it is more attractive to invest in a country where you can make a rate of return which is significantly higher than was the case in Europe. So
column148: interest rate differentials have their effect. They may not have an immediate impact on decisions to change a position
column149: but it cannot be denied that they have an effect. There are more explanations for the development of the exchange rate relationships
column150: also some which I cannot quantify. I have a feeling that confidence and credibility play a role. You cannot forget that the European Central Bank - although the Federal Reserve Bank is not that old
column151: but it is about 100 years old
column152: has been conducting monetary policy for only 1 1/2 years. We still have to build up our track record of credibility and confidence
column153: and that will take time. It may take many years to solidly establish a high degree of confidence and credibility amongst the people at large. I would like to say - we will come to talk about that later - I do feel that one major handicap which we have in communicating with the people at large in Europe
column154: is that they often have the feeling that the Euro still has to come because the notes and the coins are not there yet. I regret that very much
column155: but I cannot do anything about it. The people do not realise that the Euro has already been there for 1 1/2 years
column156: but it is a major handicap in the public perception that they cannot feel the money in their hands yet. It instils a measure of uncertainty amongst the people
column157: which I have to accept
column159: because we cannot bring the date forward for introducing euro banknotes and coins
column160: but I wish we could.   Chair:  The Parliament shares your view and we asked for that when we prepared for the Madrid summit
column161: but of course the Madrid summit was long ago.   Mr Bullman:  President Duisenberg
column162: A very brief supplementary to Mr Katiforis' question and then an independent question.  You talked about confidence. Are you not afraid that your decision on interest rates will be taken as a measure of lack of confidence in the European economy i.e. that we are not confident in inflation-free growth of between 3.5% and 4%? We are not confident in achieving that
column163: even though wage trends are so moderate. That is the supplementary.  My own question is on the necessity of international cooperation in stabilising the exchange rates. How do you assess quality and the requirements for co-operation between the main central banks. There are very different models which are up for discussion: corridors
column164: sterilised intervention to stabilise exchange rates. What is your personal view on quality requirements and the feasibility of international exchange rate policy?   Mr Duisenberg:  First of all
column165: as far as confidence after our latest interest rate decisions is concerned
column166: Madam Chairman
column167: if there was lack of confidence after our interest rates had been increased
column168: inflationary expectations for the medium-term future and long-term interest rates would have risen dramatically. They did not. That is an indication - and we also read that from commentators in the market - that there is no doubt that our intention to create a climate where a period of economic growth well in excess of 3% can be sustained over a longer period is helpful. We do not have the impression that confidence has been undermined. Rather from anecdotal evidence we conclude that confidence has been strengthened
column169: and I might say
column170: so it should be.  As far as international cooperation to stabilise exchange rates is concerned
column171: also through the use of interventions
column172: the following:  First of all
column173: as I have said repeatedly
column174: I will only comment on interventions ex post facto. I will never do so before they have occurred. The instrument is available. If and when we intervene
column175: I will tell you immediately but not before that. I would like to say that what basically is important is the euro-dollar relationship. I would again and again like to point out the impact of exchange rate variations between the Euro and the dollar. For the euro area
column176: total imports represent close to 15% of GDP; for the United States
column177: it is close to 12% of GDP : relatively comparable figures and second
column178: relatively small. The impact of exchange rate movements on the European economy is significantly smaller than what we in Europe used to perceive. In my country the import ratio was 60%. In Germany it was 30%. Something of that order. Now it is significantly smaller. What people tend to overlook is what I said earlier
column179: that about three-quarters of their foreign trade was intra-European trade
column180: where there is no exchange rate risk any longer - none whatsoever. That is the big advantage of being part of the euro area. Don't over-estimate the impact of exchange rate variations on the real economy. If they are large and persistent they may have an impact on domestic inflation. Then they become relevant also for monetary policy decisions
column181: but still the impact is only limited. And then something one should never forget: we do not have an exchange rate target. We have a mandate to maintain internal price stability. External movements can have an impact on the achievement of that primary objective. We are not neglecting that.   Mr Huhne:  Thank you
column182: Madam President
column183: Those of us in favour of British participation in the Euro zone
column185: were very encouraged recently by the OECD country survey
column186: which suggested that the process of convergence was proceeding and that within a couple of years the output gaps in both Britain and the Euro zone would be very similar. I wonder whether you share the view that the UK would be able to have a window of opportunity in which it could join the Euro within the next couple of years
column187: without the sort of problems which appear to have arisen due to the rather hasty convergence efforts in Ireland.   Mr Duisenberg:  It seems to me that the window of opportunity is becoming increasingly open. It is there but there are certain obstacles to be overcome to my feeling
column188: mainly of a psycho-political nature. The economic conditions in terms of inflation
column191: more and more point to the direction that the UK is
column193: joining forces with the euro area. The economic conditions are increasingly there. The exchange rate developments are
column194: to my mind
column195: not yet optimal for the United Kingdom to be a full participant at this rate. As long as it is true that the Euro has overshot
column196: certainly the same can be said
column197: but in the other direction also
column198: for sterling.   Chair:  And now we move onto the second round on co-ordination and the role of the European Central Bank in the process of co-ordination of policies
column199: and the role it plays in the macro-economic dialogue
column200: and Mr Radwan is the first speaker in this round.   Mr Radwan:  Mr Duisenberg
column201: at the moment we are in a phase of enlargement eastwards and I have a question on that. With Greece we have our first accession candidate to the Euro area
column202: and here we have talked about public debt in Greece and so on. Now
column203: do you think that we should still be considering these criteria in accession to the Euro zone and the Euro
column204: or do you think that there should be new rules for interpretation and new criteria in some cases. Secondly
column205: for the candidate countries in the Euro area we need a minimum degree of economic convergence. Where do you think that minimum should lie? Thank you.   Mr Duisenberg:  The ECB is not part of the negotiating team with the accession countries
column206: although we do keep a close contact with the European Commission for all issues that are relevant for the ECB and we have reached full agreement with the European Commission to be involved
column207: or at least in close touch
column208: as soon as we touch upon areas of shared competence or even exclusive competence of the ECB. One of the statements I believe that was formulated in Copenhagen
column209: at the summit in Copenhagen
column210: was that also for the accession countries there should be the willingness to accept the acquis communautaire and there can be
column211: and should be
column212: equal treatment for old as well as new members. That implies also that the criteria - if you are talking about convergence criteria
column213: but they are not yet relevant at this point in time - will to our mind have to be respected to the same extent and with no other interpretation than they have been respected for the founding fathers of the euro or for new entrants like Greece yesterday evening. That is as far as the position of the ECB is concerned but
column215: the ECB is not the ultimate decision-maker. Let me put it that way. But then also in this context I think it is wise to again call to mind that I
column216: at least
column217: see the process of accession as a process in three stages: first
column218: there is the accession to the European Union; second
column220: some years later there is the step to become a member of the European Exchange Rate Mechanism II
column221: and then maybe again after a few years there is the obligatory step to become a part of the Euro area. Only for that last step do the Maastricht criteria become relevant to form a judgement about the accession to monetary union
column222: just as it has been for Greece in the past three months.   Mr Langen:  We expect a minimum degree of real economic convergence before entry into the Euro. Now
column223: where do you think that minimum should be in order not to endanger the EMU?   Mr Duisenberg:  Well for EMU
column227: but that is years from now. There has to be a much greater degree
column228: to my mind as an economist
column229: of convergence of the real economy of these accession countries
column230: much greater than it is at the present day. That is not even so much in the interest of Europe as it exists today. It is much more in the interest of the accession countries themselves. They are still very much in the process of transforming from a centrally-planned economy into a market-oriented economy. Even with in some areas prolonged transitional arrangements as have been used in the past with new entrants
column231: these young market economies could not stand the full force of competition in totally liberalised markets and they would be swamped
column232: and it would not be in their own interest to speed up their entry. I know that political impatience is very large
column233: but lets not forget the economic pre-conditions which have to be fulfilled
column234: so that the people in the street also see that they benefit from and do not suffer from participation in the European Union.   Mr Langen:  Well
column237: we are talking here not only about co-ordination of financial and economic policies of member states
column238: and a certain amount of consistency with decisions of the ECB
column240: here we are talking about three levels of discussion. First of all
column242: with institutions like ECOFIN and the European Parliament and thirdly
column243: with our citizens. The European Central Bank is actually independent. Now
column244: how do you assess the view that is always being expressed that the ECB is very reserved and has not got involved in this dialogue to such a great extent or
column247: you can always say that you can justify this later on and
column249: exchange rate changes should not be over-estimated
column250: but what about the discussion on Ireland
column251: of the European Union perhaps stopping the cohesion fund and thereby preventing greater inflation. That would be one thing that could be done
column252: or the issue of massive harmonisation with regard to savings taxation
column253: or an active participation in an information campaign about the reason for the fluctuation and the external value of the Euro. I do not really think that we should necessarily tell our citizens that there are great problems. I do not think there are
column254: but all this affects public confidence
column255: and what view does the European Central Bank take of its role? Should it not be more active in this simply because of its independence?   Mr Duisenberg:  The establishment of a macro-economic dialogue was concluded finally in Köln. We see it as a forum in the preparation of which the ECB has been fully involved. It is a forum for an exchange of views amongst the main economic actors in society
column258: and the monetary authorities. A very useful exchange of views is possible
column261: an opportunity to express our views about what the others should do
column263: whether they do it or not. It gives the others an opportunity to say what they think we should do
column264: whether we do it or not. Our independence is fully preserved
column265: and even in the Köln statement it is repeatedly underlined that this macro-economic dialogue
column267: in no way interferes with or undermines the independent authority of the actors concerned and the ECB is even specifically mentioned
column268: that the independence of the ECB is fully respected. Given all that
column269: we regard the macro-economic dialogue as a useful opportunity for an exchange of views. But one thing is certain
column270: the ECB will never participate or take part in an ex-ante co-ordination of policies. We will not take part in an ex-ante co-ordination of policies
column271: which could jeopardise our primary objective
column273: to preserve price stability.   Mr Trentin:  Thank you Madam Chairman.  Mr Duisenberg
column274: there has been a limited increase in inflation. This seems to be mainly because of the price of energy products
column275: and that is determined outside of the Union. It does not seem to be of medium-term effect though
column276: and this could be part of the macro-economic dialogue respecting the independence of the ECB. With a view to a certain cooling
column277: what is the bank's possible assessment of the length of time interest rate increases will last? Some countries have had a lower growth rate. Others have had a higher growth rate than public debt. You have to realise that in some of these countries the recent decisions of the European Central Bank have encouraged national banks to increase interest rates even more
column278: and this is a burden particularly on small and medium companies. It also means an increase in treasury bond revenue which is 5% in Italy
column279: and that means an increased cost for a policy of reducing public debt. Thank you.   Mr Duisenberg:  Yes
column282: and in particular the Italian budget
column283: has greatly benefited from the decline in interest rates which was associated with the entrance into monetary union because a large part of the Italian debt was financed in a very short-term way. We do not believe that our recent interest rate increases will have the impact of cooling down the economy. We still think
column285: that we are busy creating the conditions for a sustained period of economic growth in excess of 3%. What we do believe is that with our interest rate decisions
column286: we safeguard the expectation that over the medium-term inflation will remain below
column288: the ceiling of 2% which we have set for ourselves. Then there is no denying that if interest rates by the Central Banks are increased
column289: that those costs will be passed on to their customers by private banks. But still the interest elasticity of investment has proven to be limited. Then I would like to point out
column290: and I am thinking of Italy
column293: that we are still talking about levels of interest rates which five years ago were unheard of. Everything I say
column295: is relative and remains relative.   Mr Katiforis:  Thank you
column298: if indeed that is a part of the macro-economic dialogue
column299: you are going back to the governments time and again recommending that they use any surpluses which are being created right now
column300: from windfall gains like from the sale of those third generation telephone licences
column301: that they use all that to consolidate the budget situation. Now
column302: alternatively that money could be directed to investment and
column304: to public investment for which we are rather short in Europe. Take
column307: why this insistence on budget consolidation
column308: and would it not be more correct to take the net position of a country: debts
column310: and increasing assets then would show up favourably and we could have some additional investment which we need now
column311: because we are totally exhausting the excess capacity. Now is the moment to have some additional investment cash
column312: not insist on cutting down budget deficits all the time.   Mr Duisenberg:  It is not for nothing.   Mr Katiforis:  Why not the net position
column313: isn't it the main thing?   Mr Duisenberg:  That's mainly a matter of statistical measurement
column315: the definition of what is investment
column316: what is consumption. I remember vividly the many discussions I had when I was a Minister of Finance
column318: who always asked : what is a better investment in our future than educating our children better? That is mainly a matter of statistics. That's not that important
column322: well the following. First of all
column323: whatever you may think of the Stability and Growth Pact
column324: the main thrust behind it and the thinking behind it is the solemn declaration of the participating countries to
column326: strive for a budget that is either in balance or shows a small surplus. Why? That is in terms of when the economic wind is against you
column327: to create a buffer which allows the automatic stabilisers to work
column328: and it is thought that a 3% buffer is adequate . Then in times when there is an economic downturn
column329: and inevitably at some time in future maybe there will be another economic downturn
column331: then we should not be worried that we approach the 3% level. But in order not to be worried we first have to create the situation that structurally we are at an average level of just about balance. Secondly
column332: there are more fundamental reasons for this endeavour. There is still a far too much under-estimated problem of the ageing of the population which inevitably requires savings and investments to be made within a decade from now
column333: which are of a sizeable nature. The awareness is awakening
column336: still very much under-estimated is the enormous impact the ageing of the population will have on public budgets in terms of costs of pensions and health care. That means savings will be necessary for pension funds. Investment will be necessary for health care. In order to be able to do that in a responsible way you have to create the conditions in the budget for that. Another reason why I am somewhat concerned about the present tendency
column337: when there are economic windfalls because of stronger than expected economic growth
column338: to spend or to lower taxes - which in itself I have nothing against
column339: on the contrary - but to do that in the pro-cyclical environment we have now. We are entering a situation where all our economies are performing better than we anticipated and better than the trend they have demonstrated in the past. In this situation then to add an additional pro-cyclical stimulus to that development is rather dangerous.   Mr Schmidt:  Thank you very much
column341: you just answered a question from Mr Katiforis on the need for structural reforms and you said in your address that in Europe we do need structural reforms
column342: and I would like you to go into a bit more detail and I would like you to tell us which member states in the EU you think are in greatest need of reform. I would like to have a comment from you on the possible role of the ECB in this context
column343: to bring forward these reforms.  My second question is linked to what Mr Radwan said and your view of the applicant countries. Now
column345: you said that if we assume that some of the candidate countries become members in 2004 and 2005
column346: then they will become members of the EMU in about 2009 and 2010. Now
column347: you said that would be compulsory and my question to you is self-evident
column348: because today there is only one country of the 15 that does not have an opt-out which is outside the EMU and that is Sweden. What is your view on Sweden? Can Sweden permanently remain outside EMU? That is my question to you with a view to what you said about the candidate countries. Thank you.   Mr Duisenberg:  Just yesterday evening in Portugal
column349: I witnessed the adoption of the new broad economic guidelines in which specifically country by country recommendations were given for the structural reforms that have to be performed or executed in the individual 15 member states of the European Union. In the context of the Economic and Financial Committee
column350: the ECB co-operated in that context
column351: but we were only one of those who provided an input
column352: but I would like to refer to it. They will have been published by now and I think I can refer to that by now. On accession countries I did not mention the time-frame as you just put in my mouth
column353: but you can infer from it that I would not be inclined to disagree very much from your time-frame. But then I would also like to emphasise that we in the continuous dialogue we have
column354: at least with the Central Banks of the accession countries
column355: emphasised the fact that circumstances in the various countries are very different from one another. Exchange rate regimes are very different. The state of affairs of the banking industry or the financial industry in the various countries is very different indeed
column356: and therefore I would be very much fearful if all
column358: of these countries we are talking about were endeavouring to all come in at the same time. I think one has to allow for the fact that the developments in the countries are very different
column359: that the state of affairs may differ very much and that it is individual judgement which should be applied. Now I am not one of the ultimate decision-makers. I realise that
column360: but that at least would be my advice to those who are ultimately the decision-makers. The accession countries will not have an opt-out clause. They will not have an opt-out clause like Denmark or the United Kingdom and so the process will be irreversible. You will become a member of the European Union first. Then they are expected to become a participant in ERM II. Finally
column362: there is the obligation to become a member of monetary union
column363: and to my mind the same holds true for Sweden.   Mr Jonckheer:  Mr President
column364: by reference to the public finances of the Member States and to what you have written in the first paragraph of your speech
column366: do you think that there is a correlation in a Member State between the level of the tax burden and macro economic performance? You refer to Denmark in one of your replies
column367: I think in Denmark there is a very high level tax burden but there is also very good economic and structural performance
column368: so I would like you to comment on that question. The second question is this
column369: in one of your replies to Mr Katiforis you said
column371: that national governments shouldn't start cutting taxes too quickly because the wind might change as you say. However
column372: I see in your text on page 7 that you approve tax reduction initiatives as long as they are consistent with the stability pact. But you don't say anything about reallocation of tax which I think is important. You say nothing about State revenue structures
column374: taxation of labour has increased considerably over the last 15 years. Since in the context of the macro economic dialogue
column375: the European Central Bank expresses public financing opinions concerning the Member States
column376: why don't you at least in your statement today say something about reallocating Member States revenues?   Mr Duisenberg:  Is there a correlation between the tax burden and economic performance? I think there certainly is and alleviating the tax burden
column377: which in some European countries has become rather high should have over the long run
column379: a high priority. It will increase dynamism in the economies and it will have the effect of no longer
column381: almost distorting the economic performance and it would therefore contribute to better incentives both for workers and for entrepreneurs to start working and to take initiatives. But that is a very general statement. Now on the reason why I am not very specific about how to reduce or to transform tax structures
column382: this has mainly to do with two factors. First of all it is not my area of competence
column383: but sometimes I am not too bothered whether it is in my field of competence. But second
column384: circumstances in the various Member States are very different
column385: so what could be recommended for one country could very well turn out to be very detrimental for another. Of course
column386: in the interest of employment and combating inflation
column387: the ECB would be very much in favour of responsible cuts. I mean cuts in the level of taxation
column388: that would alleviate the tax burden on lower paid jobs and make it easier for companies to hire and pay personnel at the lower end of the scale. In the interest of combating inflation I would be in favour to offset a change in the structure of taxation that leads to price increases
column389: I'm thinking for example of the value added tax
column390: by other measures to contain inflationary pressures. But they may be conflicting ends
column391: I realise that. A general shift from direct to indirect taxation goes against the
column393: trend to make indirect taxation contribute to the containment of inflation
column394: but we are often faced with awkward dilemmas in this sense.   Chair:  Thank you
column395: now on to practical questions relating to the introduction of the Euro. These are of great significance to our citizens and here the first question comes from Mr Marinos.   Mr Marinos:  Thank you. President Duisenberg
column396: the euro was created and the ambition is that it should become a strong reserve currency as a counterweight to the over-powerful dollar. Now those who believed in a strong euro invested in it and actually lost some of their capital in doing so. I know in a Financial Times article recently the former president of British Petroleum said that the Americans actually pretend that they actually want to see crude oil prices going down
column397: but in fact they are only pretending because the high oil prices mean that they make a lot of money
column399: oil companies and these are all promoted by American interests. Now if that is true
column400: could we suppose that through the increase in oil prices which plays into the hands of the US
column401: do you think that there is indirectly an attempt to weaken the euro in this way
column402: and isn't there an attempt to stop this becoming a strong currency and a dangerous rival for the dollar
column403: which as far as US interests are concerned would be something they would wish to achieve at all costs?  Thank you.   Mr Duisenberg:  I don't believe in such an evil or devilish conspiracy
column404: the internationalisation of the euro is mainly a market driven process
column405: and the Eurosystem will neither foster nor hinder the internationalisation of the euro. We will wait and see. The international use of the euro is no disappointment at all. The euro is by now the second most important currency in the world. Not as important admittedly as the dollar and we don't strive after that
column406: but far more important for example than the Japanese yen. If I may give you some figures
column407: with regard to the international private use of the euro. The use of the euro as a financing currency has been the most significant so far. Euro denominated gross issues of money market instruments
column408: bonds and notes by residents outside the euro area accounted for 28% of total issues denominated in a currency other than that of the geographical area of where the borrower resides. By comparison
column410: that same figure then for the ECU was 18%
column411: so that's a growth of 10%-point in the share already in one year. The euro's growth came mainly at the expense of the US dollar
column412: the share of which declined from 58% to 48% between 1998 and 1999. If one focuses on the bond and notes segment of the market
column413: then in 1999 the share of the euro with 33% was only just below the share of the US dollar which was 37%. That is also an indication that the position of the euro is getting stronger. International issues in euro have been growing consistently over the whole year. In the second half of 1999
column415: euro denominated bond issues have exceeded those in US dollar both at constant and current prices. Now in the area of the use of the euro
column417: the increase is slower than the use of the euro as a store of value. In particular
column418: it is likely that the share of the euro in trade invoicing is not significantly different from the weight of the euro area in international trade. As far as the use of the euro by Central Banks is concerned
column419: the euro is the second world reserve currency after the US dollar. It is dwarfed admittedly by the use of the dollar for that purpose. According to the latest provisional data
column420: at the end of 1999 the euro accounted for around 13% of official foreign reserve currency holdings of the world. But you have to realise that with the introduction of the euro there were two technical factors which dramatically changed the share of the euro in the world foreign reserves. Firstly
column421: there was the fact that those reserves of participating countries which were held in euro currencies
column422: in legacy currencies like Deutschmarks or French francs
column423: from one day to the other became domestic assets and were no longer foreign assets. The effect of that is equivalent to almost 20 billion euro that in one blow had to be deleted from the foreign exchange reserves figure. What is even more important
column424: on 31 December 1998 the euro system unwound into gold and US dollars
column425: the official ECUs which were issued to EU Central Banks through revolving swaps against the contribution of 20% of their gross gold holdings and US dollar reserves. Then you are talking about a total amount of 61 billion euro. So all in all
column426: the contraction on one day of the total reserves and then consequently of the share of European reserves in the world
column427: amounted to more than 80 billion euros. Now
column428: regarding the use of the euro by other countries in the world and on the use of the euro as an anchor currency
column429: there are some interesting figures. More than 50 countries in the world are currently using the euro in the context of various arrangements as an anchor currency. Out of 87 countries belonging to the so-called European hemisphere
column432: 35 countries already link their currencies to the euro. In addition
column433: the Rouble is co-moving with the euro much more closely than it did in the past with the Deutschmark. In the Western hemisphere the proportion of countries currently anchoring to the US dollar
column434: that is around 40% of the countries
column435: is similar to the proportion of European hemisphere countries anchoring to the euro. Now these figures I believe demonstrate that we are on the way up
column436: whether we like it or not
column438: because apart from benefits it also sometimes creates obligations. This may especially make my monetary policy experts sometimes somewhat nervous
column439: when they think of the impact on domestic monetary policy which may come from the behaviour of neighbouring countries who are not yet part of the euro area
column440: but have a special relation to the euro. But we still think that can be handled. Things are moving
column442: as I believe I have said before in this Parliament
column444: around the turn of the previous century
column446: the United States was already by far the most important economy in the world
column447: but it took them 60 years to let the dollar become the most important currency in the world. Before that it was sterling. Now I don't say that it will take the euro 60 years to become a significant currency in the world but it may take some time before it reaches its "steady-state" position.   Mr Karas:  We don't have much time and a lot of things have already been said
column449: but I would like to add something to what Mr Langen said. The euro's launch and the further stages for the introduction of the euro mean that we need an active political information policy. A very exemplary information policy
column450: and I think that now that we have had this declaration concerning all the technical precautions I don't think the declaration of technical precautions is enough. We've heard a lot about the external value of the euro and other things
column451: but I wonder whether it wouldn't be possible for you yourself to actually ensure that what you told us today could be told by you in all the Member States to the Presidents of the Central Banks. You could draw up with the Presidents of the National Banks the positive balance sheet of the euro and also you could talk about your goals
column453: not just looking at the reaction of the public but also what you demand now of politicians
column455: when it comes to their part in this communication and information policy. Thank you.   Mr Duisenberg:  Yes
column456: but with all due respect I believe that we are doing the maximum that we can
column461: with markets to the maximum extent possible across the euro area and beyond. It was a very deliberate decision to let every first meeting of the Governing Council in the month be followed by a very extended press conference
column462: to put not only the introductory statement of the press conference immediately on the website of the ECB
column463: but a few hours later you find all the questions and answers by about 200 journalists on the website as well. It was a deliberate decision and not required by the Treaty to let every meeting of the Governing Council
column464: the very first meeting be followed within a matter of a week and a half by a monthly bulletin
column466: in which much more elaborated than is possible in the press conference
column467: the decisions taken and the developments in Europe as far as the monetary aspects are concerned are explained. I am almost inclined to say that we are constantly working on that
column468: but I honestly don't know what more we can do.   Mrs Lulling:  Thank you
column470: that's all well and good what you just said to Mr Marinos in reply about the position of the euro
column471: but those citizens who lost a lot of money because of exaggerated trust or exaggerated expectations as regards the euro in May 1999
column473: they have actually lost their trust in the euro I am sure. I think in a lot of circles it is now being considered whether the euro should be introduced as a real currency in coins and notes and perhaps one should backtrack. I know that is out of the question
column474: but some people are thinking about backtracking and that sort of consideration should be met by you
column475: you should comment more on that sort of very negative reaction. As regards the practical aspects of the introduction of the euro
column476: a lot depends on the public acceptance of the euro
column477: acceptance of the euro by citizens
column478: also because of the weakness of the euro vis-à-vis the US dollar that has actually brought down the standard of living in the euro area. It's enough to look at inflation rates. I'd like to ask you
column479: recently I read that there are capital flights out of Europe now and a well known company
column481: is saying the euro weakness is the result of huge bureaucracy in the euro area
column482: which is the fault of the socialists who restrict the freedom of people
column483: and in the future the euro area will be thwarted and stifled by taxes and regulations
column484: what do you think of this? Do you think you need to be less discreet now about those people who are attacking the weakness of the euro? Thank you.   Mr Duisenberg:  Well
column485: the lucky thing about statements by all these investment banks is that they more often than not are contradictory amongst themselves. So I am not commenting on Merrill Lynch or Goldman Sachs or whoever
column486: they can fight amongst themselves. On 5 May
column487: I went to the rather unusual procedure of issuing a statement directed directly to the public at large in Europe telling them that despite all this hype about the depreciation of the euro the average European should not be afraid because we kept inflation under control. He or she should not be afraid that either his or her pension or savings would be undermined
column488: and that was a statement which was intended to appease somewhat the unrest we sensed amongst people all across Europe. I did not have in mind when I made that statement and I got letters afterwards
column489: those people who enjoy a pension in Europe and live in the Bahamas. They have suffered that is true.   Chair:  I have a question on the practical details of the introduction of the euro. The first question concerns the problem of supplying the population with cash; some Member States are providing kits as of mid-December next year. Will that really be enough to ensure that there is a proper supply of cash to the entire population because in the Netherlands I know each household will receive just 8.40 euros? Isn't that much too little? I wonder
column490: would it be necessary alongside coins to make available the small domination notes
column491: the 5 and 10 euro notes. Surely they should also be provided in advance to the population
column492: because otherwise there is a fear that there might well be a collapse of retail
column493: small commerce in January. Another thing that worries us a lot are rumours about the question of conversion fees in the banks
column494: we've heard that only in the first six weeks will there be free conversion
column495: and we've always told the people during the first 6 months there would be free conversion. That was actually laid down in the Treaty. The fact that now everything has to be exchanged by 28 February
column496: might that not lead to a situation whereby this promise made to the people might actually be relativised? I think that's an important point
column497: and also that we hear from you again about how you are going to provide people on the street with notes and coins
column498: that everyone can be sure that the Treaty norms can be fulfilled. And finally
column499: are you going to offer the banks a retail payments system? I don't think that we've made any progress with the private agreement with the banks.   Mr Duisenberg:  The coins are in the hands of the Ministers of Finance and are their competence. It is a national competence. There is agreement amongst the Ministers of Finance that they should
column501: feel free to give or sell so-called starter kits
column502: for example one coin per denomination to the public at large
column503: but not before the middle of December so as to avoid those coins coming into circulation. Now
column504: I know that some people do not fear these coming into circulation because these first coins will probably be kept as collectors items anyway and it is a small amount. To be very precise
column505: as far as my information goes
column506: it has been decided that this frontloading of coins to the general public in coin starter kits concerns in Austria the equivalent of 200 Austrian Schillings
column507: in Belgium the equivalent of 500 Belgian Francs
column509: in France to my information the equivalent of 100 French Francs
column510: in Germany the equivalent of 20 Deutschmarks
column513: in Luxembourg the equivalent of 500 Luxembourg Francs
column514: in the Netherlands the equivalent of 25 Dutch Guilders
column515: in Portugal and Spain none. But that is not meant to come into circulation. The motive is to let the people feel the coins and let them become accustomed to them. As far as the notes are concerned
column516: there is agreement among all of us
column517: and now I'm talking about Central Bankers
column518: that one situation which should be avoided is that the notes will be introduced at different periods of time over Europe. That they will be earlier in Germany than in France or vice-versa. They must be introduced all on the same day
column519: and the day we stick to is 1 January 2002. Now there is also agreement that we should prevent notes from coming into circulation amongst the general public before that date. That does not exclude that we want to facilitate the professionals
column520: and now I'm talking about banks
column523: to have the logistical stocks of notes already in store well before 1 January. I mean
column524: a retail store needs to distribute the logistical stocks over all its branches across the country
column525: whatever country it is. We will make available
column526: or the Central Banks will make available
column527: adequate supplies of notes to all the categories I mentioned as from 1 September 2001
column528: provided there are legal or contractual guarantees that they will keep them for themselves and that they will not be brought into circulation. So they have more than three months to start handling these huge volumes of notes. Now as far as the other practical questions are concerned
column529: we are still discussing and considering who bears the cost of having those notes. Suppose they have them already in huge quantities 3 months before they come into circulation
column530: who bears the costs of having them? A bank has to buy the new notes from the Central Bank
column531: but when will it be debited in the accounts for buying them? Now we are still discussing what we want
column532: which is to make it as cheap as possible and as costless as possible for the retail sector and the banking community. As to the conversion period
column534: the costs in this period we want to be minimal. I thought it was agreed to do it free of charge for conversion of 'household' amounts of money into euro. And as to the timing
column535: the Ministers have agreed that the period of dual circulation
column536: that is the period in which old and new notes and coins circulate together
column537: may differ from country to country. It will be limited to a period of between 4 and 8 weeks. That is in practice until the end of February 2002. As a personal note: whether they will be able to achieve that is a different matter. I personally have some doubts. The traditions and techniques are very different in the various countries concerned. The density for example of automatic teller machines
column538: from which you get the money out of the wall
column539: differs from one country to another. You have to give the people running automatic teller machines the opportunity
column540: even by working around the clock
column541: to adjust this large number of machines in time to accept the new notes rather than the old ones. Whether you can manage all that in such a brief period
column543: but we'll see. The intention is to do it within 2 months
column544: That is an agreement amongst the Ministers as far as the coins are concerned and as far as the notes are concerned it is somewhat easier. Now a final question is how long will you be able
column545: if you find an old note in an old sock
column546: to exchange that for a new note? The answer is that it also differs from country to country. In my country
column548: in some countries it is indefinite
column549: the minimum is 10 years. We will probably have to come up with a common measure
column550: but then it is only at the National Central Bank that it can be done. So after a period of 2 months it will no longer be possible to convert old notes into new ones at any bank or any grocery store. The Treaty says 6 months at most
column551: but the endeavour is to limit the actual period to 2 months.   Mr Goebbels:  I have a question on another area
column552: the Court of Auditors report on the efficiency of the EMI and the ECB in 1998 and it says that there is to be a special premium for staff to cover an amount of 1.9 million ECU. It turns out that
column553: according to the Court of Auditors
column554: that the services who are responsible for executing this decision have actually spent 2.8 million ECU without asking for the permission of Council. I hope that you have taken the necessary measures so that some of these things will not reoccur
column555: because I cannot imagine that you wanted to set a benchmark for wage moderation because the increase in wages went up to about 38% of the average wage in fact.   Mr Duisenberg:  That last comparison is a bit misleading. I believe
column557: what the Governing Council took responsibility for
column558: was that in the transition from the EMI to the ECB to grant to the existing staff who had been working
column560: I don't want to use the words I had in mind
column561: but who had been working like hell for more than a year
column562: to make that transition possible to give them a special bonus. The bonus was expressed as a percentage of their salary. It differed from staff member to staff member
column563: and also depending on how long he or she had been in the service of the EMI. Now indeed the costs of that were not
column565: 1.9 million ECU but I believe 2.8 million ECU
column566: and it will not happen again.   Mr Gasoliba:  I'll be very brief
column567: I just have a quick question and a comment. First of all
column568: it's a question of all institutions and the ECB wanting to underscore the positive aspects
column570: low inflation and interest rates and that is a sort of counterweight to the bad image and the negative image that the public have been receiving recently
column571: where there were only constant comparisons with the value of the US dollar. Secondly
column572: in your meetings with the national central banks and with the Civil Services of the Member States you should ensure that this information campaign for the introduction of the euro is a discussion that is taken down to regional and local level. This discussion is to take place at all levels
column573: so please work with regional authorities and local authorities. With some Member States this is very important
column574: for example in Germany and Spain. I have a third issue I wish to raise. Now
column575: in order to ensure there is more public acceptance of the euro and
column577: for our citizens this is a very important subject. I'm talking here about our citizens who travel
column578: there are many tourists for example from third countries who come into the EU
column579: and we have to ensure that these tourists are not completely taken by surprise when they arrive in Europe. So I think we need to think about an international campaign as well
column580: and our citizens when they then travel to third countries they must also be able to see that this new currency is recognised and accepted in third countries. Thank you.   Mr Duisenberg:  We are developing
column581: and it must come underway in a matter of months if not weeks
column582: a huge information campaign. The private contract as you know has been awarded to the Paris based company
column584: which was in the news for other reasons earlier this morning. It is a huge campaign
column585: costing about 80 million euro. It will be directed not only at a national level but also at regional levels
column587: in close co-operation with the national central banks
column588: so as to take into account cultural and regional differences which may be prevalent across Europe. The campaign will be conducted in the euro area now including Greece and beyond
column589: so also outside the euro area in non-European monetary union countries. It will also be focused on potential travellers
column591: on tourists and cash handlers of foreign currencies. So effectively
column592: although of course less intense the further you are away from Europe
column593: but effectively it will cover the world.   Mr Lipietz:  One of the characteristics of liquid currency for the citizen is that he is able to make purchases with it everywhere in the currency area. I think that
column594: until the banks realise that if you write a check and transfer a 100 euros you should be able to buy 100 euros worth of goods in Belgium
column596: it will not free up the citizen and the citizen will not accept it. So what do you intend to do to make inter-bank transfers within the EU free
column597: as they are within each Member State? At present it can cost as much as 60 euros for a 100 euro bank transfer.   Mr Duisenberg:  We are fully aware of that problem
column598: it is not in our hands. We have published on 13 September 1999 a press release and a report entitled "Improving Retail Cross Border Payment Services - The Eurosystem's View"
column599: and in that report we give seven objectives which have to be fulfilled by the banking industry in order to enhance the use of cross border retail payments. Also
column600: we have demanded from the banking sector that by 1 January 2002 they should have established the proper procedures which make cross border retail payments almost as quick and almost as cheap as domestic payments.  A transfer of money from Bank A in your country to bank B in that country takes about four days. It would be acceptable if you made it from Credit Agricole to the Commerzbank in five days One day extra would be acceptable
column601: but not five weeks as sometimes happens. So we are monitoring it
column602: the European Commission is very active in promoting also a smoother and cheaper application of the retail payments systems cross-border
column603: but ultimately it is in the hands of the private sector
column604: but the pressure and the competition is very large and intense of course
column605: and that is a great help.   Chair:  Unfortunately a lot of our citizens are still paying double fees
column606: which is a scandal. This is also an infringement of the Directive.   Mr Della Vedova:  Briefly
column607: I would like to pick up the last words spoken by President Duisenberg. The success of the euro will be decided by the financial markets
column608: but there's a first transition which will be the public acceptance and the acceptance by the businesses and companies
column609: and the actual introduction that will affect the success of the euro. Now on this
column611: I believe that this perception of the euro will depend on whether citizens and companies will feel they have the right services from their banks
column612: possibly better services than they had in the past. Do you think the European banking system has reached the right level of efficiency and competitiveness
column614: do you think the supervisory authorities for credit
column615: or the central bank as in my country
column616: the supervisory authorities are actually going to develop the credit system? Are they doing enough to help an integrated financial market of a competitive nature to arise in Europe?   Mr Duisenberg:  Well its not up to the supervisory authorities to be active in this field
column617: its up to the competition authorities to be active in this field
column618: and its not up to the central banks either I must say. Like you
column619: I have only evidence of my own experience - I regularly do retail payments in three countries
column620: and in one country it goes better than in the other
column621: and I wish ultimately that in Europe it goes as well as in the best of the three I experience.   Chair:  President
column622: I thank you very much for this very intensive dialogue which we've had this morning. It has been a long dialogue and I think it important that we keep up the regularity of our meetings. We will see whether any of your future monetary decisions draw our attention
column623: but first of all we will in the plenary be drawing up a balance sheet of the first year of the euro. I would close the meeting at this point and give the floor to Mr Garcia Margallo.
